    Verify resource limits across all nodes in the cluster
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Having the same resource limits across all nodes in the cluster allows the same level of service for all database nodes.



    Risk:

    Process startup failure due to maximum number of processes or open files limit reached.

    Action / Repair:

    Manually update the $GI_HOME/crs/install/s_crsconfig_<NODE>_env.txt and bounce the cluster.

    Note: Once the issue has been resolved, if you wish to validate this Exachk check individually, you may run the following command as "root" user:

        exachk -showpass -check 03167059021F9CCAE0639812F50A4422
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onCluster Wide
    

    


    Status on Cluster Wide:
    PASS => Resource limits match across cluster
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - Verify resource limits across all nodes in the cluster 



CRS_LIMIT_NPROC=400000
CRS_LIMIT_OPENFILE=400000
CRS_LIMIT_STACK=2048

DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - Verify resource limits across all nodes in the cluster 



CRS_LIMIT_NPROC=400000
CRS_LIMIT_OPENFILE=400000
CRS_LIMIT_STACK=2048

DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - Verify resource limits across all nodes in the cluster 



    
CRS_LIMIT_NPROC=400000
CRS_LIMIT_OPENFILE=400000
CRS_LIMIT_STACK=2048

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Check alerthistory for stateful alerts not cleared [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    There are two types of alerts maintained in the alerthistory of a storage or database server, stateful and stateless.

    A stateful alert is usually associated with a transient condition, often hardware related, and it will clear itself after that transient condition is corrected. These alerts age out of the alerthistory after 7 days (default time) once they are set to clear.

    The benefit of checking for stateful alerts that have not been cleared is faster problem resolution. The impact of correcting any stateful alert that has not been cleared depends upon each individual alert. 

    Risk:

    Failure to investigate a stateful alert that has not been cleared may result in significant impact, which varies by the particular alert.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared, as the root userid on each storage and database server execute the following commands:

    unset IMAGE_VERSION
    unset NODE_TYPE
    unset COMMAND_NAME
    unset NAME_ARRAY
    unset INDIVIDUAL_NAME
    unset SID
    unset SEVERITY
    unset MESSAGE
    unset ACTION
    unset OUTPUT_ARRAY
    if [ $(egrep -i node.type /opt/oracle.cellos/cell.conf | grep -i db | wc -l) -eq 1 ]
      then NODE_TYPE=db
    else
      NODE_TYPE=cell
    fi
    IMAGE_VERSION=$(imageinfo -version |tr -d '.'|cut -c1-6)
    if [ $NODE_TYPE = "cell" ]
    then
      COMMAND_NAME=cellcli
    else
      if [ $IMAGE_VERSION -ge 121211 ]
        then COMMAND_NAME=dbmcli
      fi;
    fi;
    if [ -n "$COMMAND_NAME" ]
    then
      NAME_ARRAY=$($COMMAND_NAME -e "list alerthistory attributes name where alerttype=stateful and endtime=null" | sed -e 's/^[ \t]*//');
      if [ -z "$NAME_ARRAY" ]
      then
        echo -e "SUCCESS: there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared."
      else
        for INDIVIDUAL_NAME in $NAME_ARRAY
        do
          NAME_RECORD=$($COMMAND_NAME -e "list alerthistory attributes alertsequenceid,severity,alertMessage,alertAction where name=$INDIVIDUAL_NAME" | tr -s "\t")
          SID=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f2 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          SEVERITY=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f3 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          MESSAGE=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f4 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          ACTION=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f5 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          OUTPUT_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\n";echo -e "SID:\t\t$SID";echo -e "NAME:\t\t$INDIVIDUAL_NAME";echo -e "SEVERITY:\t$SEVERITY";echo -e "MESSAGE:\t$MESSAGE";echo -e "ACTION:\t\t$ACTION")
        done
        echo -e -n "FAILURE: there are one or more stateful alerts that have not been cleared. Details:"
        echo -e "${OUTPUT_ARRAY[@]}"
      fi
    else
      echo "alerthistory is not available on database servers at image versions below 12.1.2.1.1: $NODE_TYPE $IMAGE_VERSION"
    fi

    The output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared.

    - OR -

    alerthistory is not available on database servers at image versions below 12.1.2.1.1: db 112322

    Example of a FAILURE result:

    FAILURE: there are one or more stateful alerts that have not been cleared. Details:

    SID:            1
    NAME:           1_2
    SEVERITY:       critical
    MESSAGE:        A IO subsystem component is suspected of causing a fault with a 100% certainty. Component Name : /SYS/MB/RISER3/PCIE3 Fault class : fault.io.intel.iio.pcie-downstream-devices Fault message : http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-QH
    ACTION:         For additional information, please refer to http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-QH This alert occurred while the Management Server was not available and is being sent out on restart of the Management Server. Note the event time may reflect the time when the alert was detected by the Management Server, not the time when the fault occurred. Diagnostic package is attached. It is also accessible at /opt/oracle/dbserver/dbms/deploy/log/scam07adm07_2014_08_11T17_40_33_1_2.tar.bz2

    SID:            2
    NAME:           2_1
    SEVERITY:       critical
    MESSAGE:        A processor component is suspected of causing a fault with a 100% certainty. Component Name : /SYS/MB/P0 Fault class : fault.cpu.intel.thermtrip Fault message : http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-K5
    ACTION:         For additional information, please refer to http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-K5 This alert occurred while the Management Server was not available and is being sent out on restart of the Management Server. Note the event time may reflect the time when the alert was detected by the Management Server, not the time when the fault occurred.

    If the output is not as expected, examine the full details for each alert that has not been cleared and follow the recommendations. 
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => No database server has stateful alerts that have not been cleared
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR CHECK ALERTHISTORY FOR STATEFUL ALERTS NOT CLEARED [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => No database server has stateful alerts that have not been cleared
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR CHECK ALERTHISTORY FOR STATEFUL ALERTS NOT CLEARED [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    WARN => One or more database servers have stateful alerts that have not been cleared
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR CHECK ALERTHISTORY FOR STATEFUL ALERTS NOT CLEARED [DATABASE SERVER]



FAILURE: there are one or more stateful alerts that have not been cleared. Details:

SID:		612
NAME:		612_1
SEVERITY:	warning
MESSAGE:	"Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment (AIDE) detected potential changes to software on this system. The changes are listed in /var/log/aide/aide.log and also at the end of this alert message.
Summary : :
Total number of files : 64363
Added files : 4
Removed files : 0
Changed files : 0
"
ACTION:		"Review the AIDE information below and determine if the changes are expected. If the changes are expected, then regenerate a new Intrusion Detection database to clear this alert. Log in as root and run 
# /opt/oracle.SupportTools/exadataAIDE -u 


    If the changes are not expected, then the system or security administrator should investigate the changes as a possible intrusion.
Added files: : 
added: : /root/2024-01-20T09:00:00+02:00
added: : /root/2024-04-20T09:00:00+02:00
added: : /root/2024-05-20T09:00:00+02:00
added: : /root/2024-08-20T09:00:00+02:00
"
    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Database Memory Allocation
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Optimizing database memory allocation ensures that application service levels are not impacted during normal runtime as well as during planned and unplanned outages.

    The main benefits of this best practice are:

      1. Ensuring memory is not oversubscribed, including the scenario of losing a database node
      2. Enabling a new formula to ensure large memory systems don't have too much memory allocated for the operating system (OS)
      3. Reporting when hugepages are allocated, but not in use by databases, so that memory can potentially be freed up and used for SGAs or PGAs
      4. Reporting when extra OS memory is available, but not used by databases, so it can be used for SGAs or PGAs

    Risk:

    Database performance and system stability can be significantly impacted when memory configuration is oversubscribed.

    Memory sizing should also consider high availability (HA) implications, such as the loss of a database node or instance.  In these cases, workload and their associated foreground process memory requirements will need to be redistributed over the surviving database nodes or instances. Therefore, some headroom should be allowed on each database node to ensure proper expected workload performance and stability in the case of HA impact.

    Action / Repair:

    There are two basic requirements for estimating memory allocation:
    1) Memory reserved for the OS
    2) Memory required for databases and applications:
        2.1) System Global Area (SGA) and
        2.2) Program Global Area (PGA)

    Therefore, the total use of memory on a database node may be accounted for:

        Total memory allocation = OS memory reservation + SGA (HugePages) allocation + PGA allocation


    1) Memory reserved for the OS

    The following formula is used to calculate the memory reserved for the OS:
        OS_MEMORY_RESERVATION = MIN(20 GB per CPU socket, ROUNDUP(25% of physical memory))

    Example 1: 2-socket VM with 75 GB of memory
        OS_MEMORY_RESERVATION = MIN(20 GB * 2, ROUNDUP(25% * 75 GB))
                              = MIN(40 GB, ROUNDUP(18.75 GB))
                              = 19 GB
    The remaining memory (in this example, 75 GB - 19 GB = 56 GB) can be allocated for databases and applications.
    The allocation of SGA and PGA is application-specific, so an exact formula is not provided.

    Example 2: 8-socket database node with 3 TB of memory
        OS_MEMORY_RESERVATION = MIN(20 GB * 8, ROUNDUP(25% * 3072 GB))
                              = MIN(160 GB, ROUNDUP(768 GB))
                              = 160 GB
    The remaining memory (in this example, 3072 GB - 160 GB = 2912 GB) can be allocated for databases and applications.
    The allocation of SGA and PGA is application-specific, so an exact formula is not provided.

    2) Memory required for databases and applications

    2.1) System Global Area (SGA)
    The memory used for SGA is allocated as HugePages.

    2.2) Program Global Area (PGA)
    The remaining memory in the system can be used by foreground processes in their PGA.  The total PGA allocation must account for some variation in PGA usage due to potential connection imbalances as well as the possibility that there could be a node failure, which redistributes that node's PGA requirements over the surviving nodes. The steps below show how to determine if the sum of PGA across all instances is sized properly to ensure there is enough memory for variations in the workload as well as the failure of one node.

    We use the following variables in our steps below:

        MAX_PGA_MEMORY: Maximum available memory on a node that could be allocated to PGA
        after reserving OS memory and SGA memory (discussed above as "PGA allocation").

        TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT: The total allocated PGA on a node based on the sum of
        PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT for all database instances.

        HA_PGA: PGA required to support one node failure.

        WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT: Workload variation factor that takes into account
        the uneven distribution of workload across nodes in the cluster.
        We typically use 1% to estimate this, but it can vary for different
        connection methods.

        N: Number of nodes in the cluster.


    We use the following 4-step procedure to determine the PGA memory allocation:

    1. Find the maximum amount of memory that could be allocated on a node for PGA:
        MAX_PGA_MEMORY = physical memory - OS_MEMORY_RESERVATION - HugePages allocated

    2. Find TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT by summing the PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT from all running database instances on the node.

    3. Find HA_PGA across all instances:
        HA_PGA = (1 / N) * TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT * (1 + WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT)

    4. Evaluate:
    If you set PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT for all databases to include the HA_PGA component, and their total is less than MAX_PGA_MEMORY, then the current PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT setting meets our recommendation.
    If you set PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT for all databases and didn't consider the HA_PGA component, make sure you have enough unallocated memory available to increase PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT in all databases to include the HA_PGA. If you don't have enough unallocated memory to support HA_PGA, database performance and system stability may be impacted during planned and unplanned outages.

    NOTE: The following formula can be applied to an individual database to calculate per database HA_PGA
        Per database HA_PGA = (1 / N) * PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT * (1 + WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT)

    Example 1: 2-socket VM 4-node cluster with 75 GB per VM
    In the first example above for a 2-socket VM with 75 GB of memory, 56 GB of memory is available for SGA and PGA after computing the OS_MEMORY_RESERVATION of 19 GB. We assume that we allocate 36 GB for SGA (HugePages allocated) and 14 GB for PGA (TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT). MAX_PGA_MEMORY is 20 GB (75 - 19 - 36).
    We further assume a 1% workload variation (WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT) and the potential loss of one node. This means the sum of HA_PGA of all instances is
        HA_PGA = (1 / N) *  TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT * (1 + WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT)
               = (1/4) * 14 GB * (1 + 1%) = 3.54 GB
    In this example we set TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT without considering the HA_PGA component. We need to change all database to account for the potential loss of one node, so the sum of all PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT values across all instances is increased by the HA_PGA value. The total of PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT across all databases would need to be 17.54 GB (3.54 + 14). The memory available for PGAs is 20 GB which means we have enough unallocated memory available to increase the PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT to support the additional workload due to a node failure.


    Example 2: 8-socket database node 2-node cluster with 3 TB per node
    In the second example above for an 8-socket database node with 3 TB of memory, 2912 GB of memory is available for SGA and PGA after computing the OS_MEMORY_RESERVATION of 160 GB. We assume that we allocate 50% to SGA (i.e., 1456 GB) and 50% to TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT (i.e., 1456 GB). MAX_PGA_MEMORY is 1456 GB (3TB - 160 GB - 1456 GB).
    We further assume a 1% workload variation (WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT) and the potential loss of one node. This means the sum of HA_PGA of all instances is:
        HA_PGA = (1 / N) * TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT * (1 + WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT)
               = (1/2) * 1456 GB * (1 + 1%) = 735.3 GB
    In this example we set TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT without considering the HA_PGA component. We need to change all database to account for the potential loss of one node, so the sum of all PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT values across all instances is increased by the HA_PGA value. The total of PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT across all databases would need to be 2191.3  GB (735.3 + 1456). The memory available for PGAs is 1420 GB which means we don't have enough unallocated memory available to increase the PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT to support the additional workload due to a node failure.




    This check performs three comparisons:

    1. On each node within the cluster, compare the allocated memory against the physical memory on each node within the cluster using the following formula:
        OS_MEMORY_RESERVATION + HugePages allocation + TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT + HA_PGA is less than or equal to the physical memory on the database node

    The expected output for each node would be:
        PASS: The sum of memory reserved for the OS (XX.XX GB) + HugePages allocated (XX.XX GB) + Total PGA memory (XX.XX GB) (total memory required of XX.XX GB) is less than or equal to physical memory (XX.XX GB)

    If a node has overallocated memory, the following output would be displayed:
        FAIL: The sum of memory reserved for the OS (XX.XX GB) + HugePages allocated (XX.XX GB) + Total PGA memory (XX.XX GB) (total memory required of XX.XX GB) is greater than physical memory (XX.XX GB)

    2. On each node within the cluster, calculate MAX_PGA_MEMORY and TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT.
    NOTE: If the comparison for physical memory fails, this check will be skipped and you will see the following output:
        WARN: This check has been skipped due to failure of the previous "Physical Memory" check. Failure of the "Physical Memory" check already asserts that there is not enough memory to support PGA HA considerations.


    If there is enough unallocated memory to support PGA HA considerations, the following output for each node would be:
        PASS: This check assumes that PGA allocation per node includes HA
        considerations to support the failure of a single node using the calculation:
            HA_PGA = (1 / N) * TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT * (1 + WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT)
        To support HA considerations, XX.XX GB of memory must be accounted for
        in PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT settings.There is unallocated memory of XX.XX GB for additional database allocation or other process utilization.
        If you considered the HA component in your Total PGA memory from all databases (XX.XX GB),
        then the current PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT setting meets our recommendation.
        If you have not considered the HA component in your PGA settings, you have
        enough unallocated memory (XX.XX) available to increase PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT in
        all databases to support the additional workload due to a node failure (XX.XX).

    If there is not enough unallocated memory to support PGA HA considerations, the following output for each node would be:
        WARN: This check assumes that PGA allocation per node includes HA
        considerations to support the failure of a single node using the calculation:
           HA_PGA = (1 / N) * TOTAL_DB_PGA_AGG_LIMIT * (1 + WORKLOAD_VARIATION_PCT)
        To support HA considerations, XX.XX GB of memory must be accounted for
        in PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT settings.There is unallocated memory of XX.XX GB for additional database allocation or other process utilization.
        If you have not considered the HA component in your PGA settings, you don't have
        enough unallocated memory (XX GB) available to increase PGA_AGGREGATE_LIMIT in
        all databases to support the additional workload due to a node failure (XX.XX).


    3. On each node within the cluster, compare the SGA allocation against the HugePages allocation.

    The expected output for each node would be:
        PASS: Total SGA memory in running databases XX.XX GB is equal to
        or within 3% of HugePages allocation of XX.XX GB; you do not appear to be
        over-allocating HugePages.

    If you are potentially wasting memory by allocating more HugePages than SGA is requesting, the output for the node would be:
        WARN: Total SGA Allocation in running databases of XX.XX GB is less than and is not within 3% 
        of HugePages Allocation of XX.XX GB; you may be over-allocating HugePages. Please review.

    If the SGA allocation is greater than the HugePages allocation, the USE_LARGE_PAGES database initialization parameter is not correctly configured:
        FAIL: Total SGA memory in running databases XX.XX GB is greater than
        HugePages allocation of XX.XX GB. You have not set the
        USE_LARGE_PAGES database initialization parameter correctly for one or
        more databases. Please review the output from the check “Check for
        parameter use_large_pages”.

    For any failures encountered in the list of nodes, review the settings per database and per node and adjust the memory allocations as required.  Note that reducing SGA_TARGET settings may also require a reduction in the HugePages allocation.



    After making the appropriate changes, rerun this check as follows:

    # exachk -check 9AD95A48A4CAE029E040E50A1EC062A1,9AD94FEDF63F8296E040E50A1EC06A28,54D911C87C5A4C85E0530C98EB0A78D4,135F449E978C3B44E05313C0E50ABE53
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:

    Check for tainted kernel by non-Oracle modules and 3rd party security software installed from package
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    You may load additional software on the database servers. However, to ensure best performance, Oracle discourages adding software except for agents, such as backup agents and security monitoring agents, on the database servers. 

    Risk:

    Loading non-standard kernel modules on the operating system of the database servers is allowed but discouraged. Oracle will not support questions or issues with the non-standard modules. If a server crashes, and Oracle suspects the crash may have been caused by a non-standard module, then Oracle support may refer you to the vendor of the non-standard module or ask that the issue be reproduced without the non-standard module. Modifying the database server operating system other than by applying official patches and upgrades is not supported.

    Action / Repair:

    In case of operational impact occurs, please refer to the vendors documentation to disable this software and reproduce the issue. Contact the vendor and follow their guidelines for support of the security software.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => No tainted modules or 3rd party security software installed from package detected in this system
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - CHECK FOR TAINTED KERNEL BY NON-ORACLE MODULES AND 3RD PARTY SECURITY SOFTWARE INSTALLED FROM PACKAGE 



SUCCESS: No tainted modules or 3rd party security software installed from package detected in this system
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => No tainted modules or 3rd party security software installed from package detected in this system
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - CHECK FOR TAINTED KERNEL BY NON-ORACLE MODULES AND 3RD PARTY SECURITY SOFTWARE INSTALLED FROM PACKAGE 



SUCCESS: No tainted modules or 3rd party security software installed from package detected in this system
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => No tainted modules or 3rd party security software installed from package detected in this system
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - CHECK FOR TAINTED KERNEL BY NON-ORACLE MODULES AND 3RD PARTY SECURITY SOFTWARE INSTALLED FROM PACKAGE 



SUCCESS: No tainted modules or 3rd party security software installed from package detected in this system
    


    Hide
    


    Check for CachedBy and CachingPolicy GridDisks attributes
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Systems can incur unpredictable performance degradation when the cachingPolicy attribute is not using flash or when the cachedBy attribute is not symmetrical across storage servers.
    Since March 2022 the cachingPolicy attribute is changed to default in Oracle Exadata System Software 22.1 or higher.
    For systems with XT storage servers, those storgae servers are skipped from this check automatically.

    Risk:

    Unpredictable performance degradation.

    Action / Repair:

    Make sure that all grid disks with cachingPolicy=default and cachedBy=[SOMEFLASH] and same number of flash devices specified per grid disk.
    1. Check to make sure all DATA and RECO grid disks have a cachingPolicy of default.
    2. Check to make sure all DATA and RECO grid disks have at least one flash device in the cachedBy attribute.
    3. Check to see if the cachedBy configuration is identical across all storage servers.


    Note: Once the issue has been resolved, if you wish to validate this Exachk check individually, you may run the following command as "root" user:

        exachk -showpass -check FE94289A829C6A2AE0539912F50AD188
    

    Needs attention on-

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Validate controlfile_record_keep_time is set correctly
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Control File sizes can impact database performance and stability. Controlfile (CF) Enqueue contention may occur when control file size gets very large and one of the key contributor of the size of the controlfile is controlfile_record_keep_time.  This check is to ensure that the spfile parameter controlfile_record_keep_time is set to 7 for databases that are using an RMAN catalog. Otherwise, the recommended value <= database recovery window (e.g. backup retention window) + 7 days.

    Risk:

    For databases with very large control files, CF Enqueue contention can occur and in rare circumstances can cause stalls or in the rare cases instance eviction.

    Action / Repair:

    Run the query below which reports the SUCCESS/FAILURE for the test

    WITH ro AS
       ( SELECT COUNT(1) found
           FROM DUAL
          WHERE EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM V$RMAN_OUTPUT WHERE OUTPUT = 'connected to recovery catalog database' )
       )
       , init AS
       ( SELECT TO_NUMBER(VALUE) value
           FROM V$PARAMETER WHERE NAME = 'control_file_record_keep_time' AND VALUE = '7'
       )
    SELECT CASE WHEN ro.found = 1 AND init.value = 7 THEN 'SUCCESS: RMAN Catalog used and control_file_record_keep_time = 7'
                WHEN ro.found = 1 AND init.value <> 7 THEN 'FAILURE: RMAN Catalog used and control_file_record_keep_time <> 7'
                WHEN ro.found = 0 AND init.value BETWEEN 1 AND 99 THEN 'SUCCESS: RMAN Catalog NOT used and control_file_record_keep_time between 1 and 99'
                ELSE 'FAILURE: RMAN Catalog NOT used and control_file_record_keep_time NOT between 1 and 99' END RESULTS
      FROM ro
         , init
    /

    If an RMAN Catalog is detected, but the control_file_record_keep_time <> 7 then change the parameter control_file_record_keep_time and restart the database

    ALTER SYSTEM SET control_file_record_keep_time = 7 SCOPE=SPFILE SID='*'
    /

    If an RMAN Catalog is NOT detected, and the control_file_record_keep_time is < 1 or > 99 then change the parameter control_file_record_keep_time and restart the database.  The value chosen should be <= database recovery window (e.g. backup retention window) +  7 days.

    ALTER SYSTEM SET control_file_record_keep_time = <value> SCOPE=SPFILE SID='*'

    /

    Once the issue has been resolved, this audit check can be invoked individually as root user as follows:
    # exachk -check FB7BBD8E8BC78623E0539812F50A0B81
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => control_file_record_keep_time parameter is set correctly
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Validate controlfile_record_keep_time is set correctly 



SUCCESS: RMAN Catalog NOT used and control_file_record_keep_time between 1 and 99
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => control_file_record_keep_time parameter is set correctly
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Validate controlfile_record_keep_time is set correctly 



SUCCESS: RMAN Catalog NOT used and control_file_record_keep_time between 1 and 99
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => control_file_record_keep_time parameter is set correctly
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Validate controlfile_record_keep_time is set correctly 



SUCCESS: RMAN Catalog used and control_file_record_keep_time = 7
    


    Hide
    


    Verify no duplicate parameter entries in database init.ora(spfile)

    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical issue EX14
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Description 
    ----------- 
    Bug 17021128 - RAID controller "Chip 0 Paused" loop causes high service time 
    on all Exadata Storage Server hard disk drives, which can lead to system 
    slowness or hang. 

    Bug 16365309 - Hard disk drives with high error counts are not confined, 
    which can lead to system slowness or hang. 

    Risk:

    If the installed Exadata Storage Server software does not have the fix for bug 17021128 or bug 16365309, then the system can run slowly or appear to hang on disk I/O operations.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX14 in MOS note 12700094.1 for fix or workaround.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX14
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical issue EX14 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical issue EX14 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Exadata Critical issue EX14 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Exadata Critical issue EX14 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

    


    Hide
    


    TFA Collector status
    


    

    Recommendation
    TFA Collector (aka TFA) is a diagnostic collection utility to simplify  diagnostic data collection on Oracle Clusterware/Grid Infrastructure and RAC  systems.  TFA is similar to the diagcollection utility packaged with Oracle  Clusterware in the fact that it collects and packages diagnostic data however  TFA is MUCH more powerful than diagcollection with its ability to centralize  and automate the collection of diagnostic information. This helps speed up  the data collection and upload process with Oracle Support, minimizing delays  in data requests and analysis.
    TFA provides the following key benefits:- 
      - Encapsulates diagnostic data collection for all CRS/GI and RAC components  on all cluster nodes into a single command executed from a single node 
      - Ability to "trim" diagnostic files during data collection to reduce data  upload size 
      - Ability to isolate diagnostic data collection to a given time period 
      - Ability to centralize collected diagnostic output to a single server in  the cluster 
      - Ability to isolate diagnostic collection to a particular product  component, e.g. ASM, RDBMS, Clusterware 
      - Optional Real Time Scan Alert Logs for conditions indicating a problem (DB 
      - Alert Logs, ASM Alert Logs, Clusterware Alert Logs, etc) 
      - Optional Automatic Data Collection based off of Real Time Scan findings 
      - Optional On Demand Scan (user initialted) of all log and trace files for  conditions indicating a problem 
      - Optional Automatic Data Collection based off of On Demand Scan findings 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1513912.1 - TFA Collector- The Preferred Tool for Automatic or ADHOC Diagnostic Gathering Across All Cluster Nodes
    2.  Trace File Analyzer Collector (TFA) 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => TFA Collector is installed and running
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - TFA COLLECTOR STATUS 




-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 36938 Jul 31 10:23 /etc/init.d/init.tfa 

-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7 Jul 31 10:23 /u01/app/oracle/oracle.ahf/data/exa3dbadm01/tfa/internal/.pidfile
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => TFA Collector is installed and running
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - TFA COLLECTOR STATUS 




-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 36938 Jul 31 10:26 /etc/init.d/init.tfa 

-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7 Jul 31 10:27 /u01/app/oracle/oracle.ahf/data/exa3dbadm03/tfa/internal/.pidfile

    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - TFA COLLECTOR STATUS

    Exadata Critical Issue EX78
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 34425639, a race condition during terminated database process cleanup on RoCE-based (i.e. X8M and X9M) Exadata Database Service and on-premises Exadata systems may cause excessively high global cache (GC) waits, resulting in database-wide hang. The race condition required to expose this issue has been seen only on very busy, large systems.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX78 in MOS note 1270094.1. 

    NOTE: If after corrective actions are completed you wish to run just this check without a full Exachk run, execute the following:

        ./exachk -check F2A064F1CC7B86C6E053D498EB0AE2DD
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX78
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX78

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX78

    Verify OSSCONF/cellinit.ora consistency across storage server
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Contents of $OSSCONF/cellinit.ora must match on all storage servers expect cell ip address.




    Action / Repair:

    Use following command on each storage server and output must be same on all cells

    sed '/^ipaddress/d;/^ *#/d' $OSSCONF/cellinit.ora | tr -d ' \t\r\f' | sort | awk 'NF' | md5sum
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1662018.1 - Oracle Sun Database Machine Cross Node Consistency Best Practice Checks
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => $OSSCONF/cellinit.ora matches across storage servers

    Exadata Critical Issue DB50
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Issue #1 - Bug 33610957, Bug 34534868 - During operating system startup Oracle Clusterware may not start because the CSS daemon (OCSSD process ocssd.bin) cannot be set to run with real-time scheduler priority.

    Issue #2 - (Bug 34286265 and Bug 34318125) or Bug 34672698 - Set process priority fails on
    critical database background processes, such as VMTK and LMS, which can result in performance degradation.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue DB50 in MOS note 1270094.1(below link)
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    Check for Underscore Parameter Without a Comment
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Underscore/Hidden parameters are typically set as a workaround to solve a known issue in a specific database version, but are usually set and forgotten even after upgrading to a future database version that contains the fix for the known issue. 
    Not knowing when or why an underscore parameter was set for a database causes confusion during the life cycle of a database. This is important for patching events and particularly important during database upgrades. 
    It is recommended to review underscore parameters before major database version upgrades - adding a descriptive comment allows the administrator to more easily determine if an underscore parameter is still needed.

    Risk:

    Not understanding why a database parameter was set can lead to confusion and potentially performance or stability impacts through the life cycle of a database.

    Action / Repair:

    The following SQL can be used to find underscore parameters which do not have comments

    select name, value from v$parameter where name LIKE '!_%' ESCAPE '!' AND update_comment IS NULL;


    When setting underscore parameters, always include a comment to show user, date and reason it was set.

    The following example shows a proper way of setting _gc_policy_minimum to 15000. Note that the example includes the MOS note number and its description as well as the date it was set and the user who set it:
    alter system set "_gc_policy_minimum"=15000 comment='user=Scott Tiger; Date=May 15, 2022; Reason=Best Practices and Recommendations for RAC databases with SGA size over 100GB (Doc ID 1619155.1)' scope=both sid='*';

    Another example is setting the underscore parameter due to a request from Oracle Support in a Service Request:
    alter system set "_gc_policy_minimum"=15000 comment='user=Scott Tiger; Date=May 15, 2022; Reason=SR SR number' scope=both sid='*';

    Another example are the few allowed underscore parameters for a specific database version, which are listed in check "Verify Hidden Database Initialization Parameter Usage" (Check Id 19DA5169713DA63BE0530A98EB0AAE45), e.g., for database version 19c:
    _assm_segment_repair_bg FALSE
    _parallel_adaptive_max_users 2
    _bct_public_dba_buffer_size 26214144
    _bct_buffer_allocation_max 1073741824
    _ipddb_enable TRUE
    For these allowed underscore parameters set the comment as in the following example for parameter _assm_segment_repair_bg:
    alter system set "_assm_segment_repair_bg"=FALSE comment='user=oeda; Date=May 15, 2022; Reason=OEDA' scope=both sid='*';


    After setting the underscore parameters with a comment, verify the comment is included by issuing the following command:
    select name, value, update_comment from v$parameter where name='<underscore parameter name>';


    Once the issue has been resolved, this audit check can be invoked individually as root user as follows:

        # exachk -check EB3693991E0AC815E053D298EB0AFB6B
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    WARN => There exists one or more underscore parameters without a comment
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Check for Underscore Parameter Without a Comment 



There exists one or more underscore parameters without a comment

_assm_segment_repair_bg
FALSE


_parallel_adaptive_max_users
2
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    WARN => There exists one or more underscore parameters without a comment
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Check for Underscore Parameter Without a Comment 



There exists one or more underscore parameters without a comment

_assm_segment_repair_bg
FALSE


_parallel_adaptive_max_users
2
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    WARN => There exists one or more underscore parameters without a comment
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Check for Underscore Parameter Without a Comment 



There exists one or more underscore parameters without a comment

_assm_segment_repair_bg
FALSE


_parallel_adaptive_max_users
2
    


    Hide
    


    Verify online (hot) patches are not applied on CRS_HOME
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Online patches are recommended when a downtime cannot be scheduled and the patch needs to be applied urgently



    Risk:

    Online patches consume additional memory and if kept permanently the memory consumption increases as the number of processes in the system increases.  Recycling the ASM instance with an online (hot) patch not replaced by the regular (offline) patch can severely degrade ASM performance.

    Action / Repair:

    It is strongly recommended to rollback all Online patches and replace them with regular (offline) patches on next instance shutdown or the earliest maintenance window.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 761111.1 - RDBMS Online Patching Aka Hot Patching
    2.  Online patching 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Online (hot) patches are not applied to CRS_HOME.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY ONLINE (HOT) PATCHES ARE NOT APPLIED ON CRS_HOME 



ls: cannot access /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/hpatch/: No such file or directory
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Online (hot) patches are not applied to CRS_HOME.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY ONLINE (HOT) PATCHES ARE NOT APPLIED ON CRS_HOME 



ls: cannot access /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/hpatch/: No such file or directory
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Online (hot) patches are not applied to CRS_HOME.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY ONLINE (HOT) PATCHES ARE NOT APPLIED ON CRS_HOME 



ls: cannot access /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/hpatch/: No such file or directory
    


    Hide
    


    Verify online (hot) patches are not applied on ORACLE_HOME
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Online patches are recommended when a downtime cannot be scheduled and the patch needs to be applied urgently.

    Risk:

    Online patches consume additional memory and if kept permanently the memory consumption increases as the number of processes in the system increases.  Recycling the database with an online (hot) patch not replaced by the regular (offline) patch can severely degrade database performance.

    Action / Repair:

    It is strongly recommended to rollback all Online patches and replace them with regular (offline) patches on next instance shutdown or the earliest maintenance window.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 761111.1 - RDBMS Online Patching Aka Hot Patching
    2.  Online patching 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3

    Hide
    


    Verify ILOM Power Up Configuration for HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE on storage server
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Verifying the ILOM power up configuration helps to ensure that a server (or more) are booted up after a power interruption as quickly as possible.



    Risk:

    Not verifying the ILOM power up configuration may result in unexpected server boot behavior after a power interruption.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify the ILOM power up configuration, as the root userid enter the following command on each database and storage server:

    if [ -x /usr/bin/ipmitool ]
    then
    #Linux
    ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    else
    #Solaris
    /opt/ipmitool/bin/ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    fi;

    The output varies by Exadata software version and should be similar to:

    Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.1 or higher:
    HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=disabled
    HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE=enabled

    Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.0 or lower:
    HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled
    HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE=disabled

    If the output is not as expected, as the root userid use the ipmitool "set /SP/policy" command. For example:
    # ipmitool sunoem cli force "set /SP/policy HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled"
    Connected. Use ^D to exit.
    -> set /SP/policy HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled
    Set 'HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON' to 'enabled'

    -> Session closed
    Disconnected
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1470536.1 - Exadata: Removing power from rack, system failed to power on after power was restored
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => ILOM Power Up Configuration for HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify ILOM Power Up Configuration for HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE on storage server

-> show /SP/policy

    Properties:
        DIMM_CE_MAP_OUT = enabled
        ENHANCED_PCIE_COOLING_MODE = disabled
        EXCESSIVE_CE_RESET = enabled
        HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON = disabled
        HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE = enabled

    Commands:

        set

            show

    Verify ILOM Power Up Configuration for HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON on storage server
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Verifying the ILOM power up configuration helps to ensure that a server (or more) are booted up after a power interruption as quickly as possible.



    Risk:

    Not verifying the ILOM power up configuration may result in unexpected server boot behavior after a power interruption.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify the ILOM power up configuration, as the root userid enter the following command on each database and storage server:

    if [ -x /usr/bin/ipmitool ]
    then
    #Linux
    ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    else
    #Solaris
    /opt/ipmitool/bin/ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    fi;

    The output varies by Exadata software version and should be similar to:

    Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.1 or higher:
    HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=disabled
    HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE=enabled

    Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.0 or lower:
    HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled
    HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE=disabled

    If the output is not as expected, as the root userid use the ipmitool "set /SP/policy" command. For example:
    # ipmitool sunoem cli force "set /SP/policy HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled"
    Connected. Use ^D to exit.
    -> set /SP/policy HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled
    Set 'HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON' to 'enabled'

    -> Session closed
    Disconnected

    Hide
    


    Verify Exadata Scrubbing is enabled
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Disk scrubbing is a feature introduced in Oracle 11.2.0.4 and Exadata 11.2.3.3.0 software version. Its purpose is to periodically validate the integrity of the mirrored ASM extents. Disk scrubbing is not performed if a device is busy (utilization > 15%).

    Risk:

    Disabling Exadata Scrubbing can prevent the detection of latent corruption.

    Action / Repair:

    To validate that Exadata Scrubbing is enabled, run the following command on all storage servers:
    LIST CELL ATTRIBUTES name,hardDiskScrubInterval

    The expected output in the Exachk report should be as follows:
    exatestcel12 biweekly                     

    If the output is not expected please set the to attribute hardDiskScrubInterval to "biweekly":
    ALTER CELL hardDiskScrubInterval=biweekly

    For additional details refer to MOS Note 2094581.1.

    Once the issue has been resolved, this audit check can be invoked individually as root user as follows:

        # exachk -check E7B1E74B54C34C9FE053D398EB0AD0B5
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => Disk scrubbing is enabled.
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify Exadata Scrubbing is enabled 


SUCCESS: Exadata Scrubbing is enabled with the recommended value biweekly.

Current Configuration:
cellcli -e list cell attributes name,hardDiskScrubInterval: 	 exa3celadm01	 biweekly

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify Exadata Scrubbing is enabled 


SUCCESS: Exadata Scrubbing is enabled with the recommended value biweekly.

Current Configuration:
cellcli -e list cell attributes name,hardDiskScrubInterval: 	 exa3celadm02	 biweekly

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify Exadata Scrubbing is enabled 



    SUCCESS: Exadata Scrubbing is enabled with the recommended value biweekly.

Current Configuration:
cellcli -e list cell attributes name,hardDiskScrubInterval: 	 exa3celadm03	 biweekly

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify Exadata Scrubbing is enabled 


SUCCESS: Exadata Scrubbing is enabled with the recommended value biweekly.

Current Configuration:
cellcli -e list cell attributes name,hardDiskScrubInterval: 	 exa3celadm04	 biweekly

    Click for more data

    Verify ExaWatcher is executing [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    ExaWatcher collects data on key metrics for both database and storage servers, which can be used for both troubleshooting and performance analysis.

    There is minimal impact to verify that ExaWatcher is executing, or from starting ExaWatcher if it is not executing.

    Risk:

    If ExaWatcher is not executing, valuable data for analysis is not collected.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that ExaWatcher is executing, as the "root" userid execute the following command set on each database and storage server in the cluster:

    NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS=$(ps -ef | grep -i exawatcher | grep -v grep | wc -l)
    if [[ $NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS -gt 0 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: ExaWatcher is executing.  Number of processes: $NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS"
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: ExaWatcher is not executing.  Number of processes: $NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS"
    fi

    The output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: ExaWatcher is executing.  Number of processes: 15

    NOTE: The number of processes may vary depending upon the site-specific configuration. 

    If ExaWatcher is not executing, please refer to the "System Diagnostics Data Gathering with sosreports and Oracle ExaWatcher" section of the "Oracle Exadata Storage Server Software User's Guide" that is for your specific installed version of Oracle Exadata Storage Server software.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 301137.1 - OS Watcher User Guide
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => ExaWatcher is running
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY EXAWATCHER IS EXECUTING [DATABASE SERVER] 



24
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => ExaWatcher is running
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY EXAWATCHER IS EXECUTING [DATABASE SERVER] 



23
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => ExaWatcher is running
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY EXAWATCHER IS EXECUTING [DATABASE SERVER] 



23
    


    Hide
    


    Verify ExaWatcher is executing [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    ExaWatcher collects data on key metrics for both database and storage servers, which can be used for both troubleshooting and performance analysis.

    There is minimal impact to verify that ExaWatcher is executing, or from starting ExaWatcher if it is not executing.

    Risk:

    If ExaWatcher is not executing, valuable data for analysis is not collected.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that ExaWatcher is executing, as the "root" userid execute the following command set on each database and storage server in the cluster:

    NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS=$(ps -ef | grep -i exawatcher | grep -v grep | wc -l)
    if [[ $NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS -gt 0 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: ExaWatcher is executing.  Number of processes: $NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS"
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: ExaWatcher is not executing.  Number of processes: $NUM_OF_EXAWATCHERS"
    fi

    The output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: ExaWatcher is executing.  Number of processes: 15

    NOTE: The number of processes may vary depending upon the site-specific configuration. 

    If ExaWatcher is not executing, please refer to the "System Diagnostics Data Gathering with sosreports and Oracle ExaWatcher" section of the "Oracle Exadata Storage Server Software User's Guide" that is for your specific installed version of Oracle Exadata Storage Server software.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02

    Hide
    


    Verify Exadata Smart Flash Cache is created
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    For the vast majority of situations, maximum performance is achieved by configuring the storage server flash memory as cache, allowing the Exadata software to determine the content of the cache.

    The impact of configuring storage server flash memory as cache at initial deployment is minimal. If there are already grid disks configured in the flash memory, consideration must be given as to the relocation of the data when converting the flash memory back to cache.

    NOTE: While not configuring the Exadata Smart Flash Log is permitted, it is recommended that the Exadata Smart Flash Log be configured. If a decision is made not to create the Exadata Smart Flash Log, the expected size for the Smart Flash Cache is shown in rows "Cache Size without Smart Flash Log" and "Cache Size with flashCacheCompression and no Smart Flash Log".

    NOTE: On storage servers that use only flash memory devices(no spinning disks), the Exadata Smart Flash Cache size is the same whether or not Exadata Smart Flash Log is created. Therefore, the order in which Exadata Smart Flash Log and Exadata Smart Flash Cache are created does not matter. 

    NOTE: It is extremely important that the root cause for the size not being as expected is understood before attempting corrective action. Because Smart Flash Log and Smart Flash Cache share the same physical memory structure on the storage servers, both are likely to be impacted by hardware failures, for example. Corrective action is also impacted by whether or not Write Back Flash Cache is in use, and solutions for the same root cause may vary if Write Back Flash Cache is in use.

    NOTE: See also "Verify Exadata Smart Flash Log is Created".

    Risk:

    Not configuring the storage server flash memory as cache may result in a degradation of overall performance.

    Action / Repair:

    To confirm all storage server flash memory is configured as smart flash cache, as root on each storage server execute the command:

    cellcli -e "list flashcache detail" | grep size

    The output will be similar to:
        size:                   1488.75G

    Starting with Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.0, the size of the storage server "flashcache" should match one of the entries in this table:

    Smart Flash Cache Expected Size Table
    -------------
    SD = System Description
    CN = Common Name
    CSwSFL = Cache Size with Smart Flash Log
    CSwoSFL = Cache Size without Smart Flash Log
    CSwFCC&SFL = Cache Size with flashCacheCompression(FCC) and Smart Flash Log
    CSwFCC&woSFL= Cache Size with FCC and no Smart Flash Log
    FCC-NA = FCC not available on this hardware

    SD: X4275
    CN: X2-2(4170)
    CSwSFL: 0.356201171875T -or- 364.75G
    CSwoSFL: 0.356689453125T -or- 365.25G
    FCC-NA

    SD: X4270 M2
    CN: X2-2, X2-8
    CSwSFL: 0.356201171875T -or- 364.75G
    CSwoSFL: 0.356689453125T -or- 365.25G
    FCC-NA

    SD: X4270 M3
    CN: X3-2, X3-8
    CSwSFL: 1.453857421875T -or- 1488.75G
    CSwoSFL: 1.454345703125T -or- 1489.25G
    CSwFCC&SFL: 2.908935546875T -or- 2978.75G
    CSwFCC&woSFL: 2.909423828125T -or- 2979.25G

    SD: X4270 M3
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 0.7266845703125T -or- 744.125G
    CSwoSFL: 0.7271728515625T -or- 744.625G
    CSwFCC&SFL: 1.4542236328125T -or- 1489.125G
    CSwFCC&woSFL: 1.4547119140625T -or- 1489.625G

    SD: X4-2L
    CN: X4-2
    CSwSFL: 2.908935546875T -or- 2978.75G
    CSwoSFL: 2.909423828125T -or- 2979.25G
    CSwFCC&SFL: 5.8193359375T -or- 5959G
    CSwFCC&woSFL: 5.81982421875T -or- 5959.5G

    SD: X4-2L
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 1.4542236328125T -or- 1489.125G
    CSwoSFL: 1.4547119140625T -or- 1489.625G
    CSwFCC&SFL: 2.909423828125T -or- 2979.25G
    CSwFCC&woSFL: 2.909912109375T -or- 2979.75G

    SD: X5-2L (disk)
    CN: X5-2, X5-8
    CSwSFL: 5.82122802734375T
    CSwoSFL: 5.82171630859375T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X5-2L (disk)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 2.910369873046875T
    CSwoSFL: 2.910858154296875T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X5-2L (all flash)
    CN: X5-2, X5-8
    CSwSFL: 0.5821533203125T -or- 596.125G
    CSwoSFL: 0.5821533203125T -or- 596.125G
    FCC-NA

    SD: X5-2L (all flash)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 0.29107666015625T -or- 298.0625G
    CSwoSFL: 0.29107666015625T -or- 298.0625G
    FCC-NA

    SD: X6-2L (disk)
    CN: X6-2, X6-8
    CSwSFL: 11.64312744140625T
    CSwoSFL: 11.64361572265625T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X6-2L (disk)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 5.821319580078125T
    CSwoSFL: 5.821807861328125T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X6-2L (all flash)
    CN: X6-2, X6-8
    CSwSFL: 1.164306640625T
    CSwoSFL: 1.164306640625T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X6-2L (all flash)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 0.5821533203125T
    CSwoSFL: 0.5821533203125T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X7-2L (disk)
    CN: X7-2
    CSwSFL: 23.28692626953125T
    CSwoSFL: 23.28741455078125T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X7-2L (disk)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 11.643218994140625T
    CSwoSFL: 11.643707275390625T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X7-2L (all flash)
    CN: X7-2
    CSwSFL: 2.3287353515625T
    CSwoSFL: 2.3287353515625T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X7-2L (all flash)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 1.16436767578125T
    CSwoSFL: 1.16436767578125T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X8-2L (disk)
    CN: X8-2, X8-8
    CSwSFL: 23.28692626953125T
    CSwoSFL: 23.28741455078125T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X8-2L (disk)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 11.643218994140625T
    CSwoSFL: 11.643707275390625T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X8-2L (all flash)
    CN: X8-2, X8-8
    CSwSFL: 2.3287353515625T
    CSwoSFL: 2.3287353515625T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X8-2L (all flash)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 1.16436767578125T
    CSwoSFL: 1.16436767578125T
    FCC-NA

    SD: X10-2L (all flash)
    CN: X10-2
    CSwSFL: 24.742431640625T
    CSwoSFL:
    FCC-NA

    SD: X10-2L (disk)
    CN: EIGHTH
    CSwSFL: 12.370971679687T
    CSwoSFL:
    FCC-NA

    SD: X10-2L (disk)
    CN: X10-2
    CSwSFL: 24.742431640625T
    CSwoSFL:
    FCC-NA

    If the size is not as expected, some of the storage server flash memory may be configured as grid disks, or there may be a hardware issue, or there may be a configuration issue.

    After determining the root cause, refer to the Database Machine Owner's Guide and the Exadata Software User's Guide for the appropriate corrective action steps.
    

    Needs attention onexa3celadm04
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm04:
    CRITICAL => Storage Server Flash Memory is not configured as Exadata Smart Flash Cache
    DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify Exadata Smart Flash Cache is created 


	 name:                   exa3celadm04_FLASHCACHE
	 cellDisk:               FD_01_exa3celadm04,FD_00_exa3celadm04,FD_03_exa3celadm04
	 creationTime:           2020-09-15T03:10:42+02:00
	 degradedCelldisks:      FD_02_exa3celadm04
	 effectiveCacheSize:     17.4651947021484375T

    Verify control_file_record_keep_time value is in recommended range
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    When a Recovery Manager catalog is not used, the initialization parameter "control_file_record_keep_time" controls the period of time for which circular reuse records are maintained within the database control file. RMAN repository records are kept in circular reuse records.  The optimal setting is the maximum number of days in the past that is required to restore and recover a specific database without the use of a RMAN recovery catalog.  Setting this parameter within a recommended range (1 to 9 days) has been shown to address most recovery scenarios by ensuring archive logs and backup records are not prematurely aged out making database recovery much more challenging.    

    Risk:

    If the control_file_record_keep_time is set to 0, no RMAN repository records are retained in the controlfile, which causes a much more challenging database recovery operation if RMAN recovery catalog is not available.

    If the control_file_record_keep_time is set too high, problems can arise with space management within the control file, expansion of the control file, and control file contention issues.

    The impact of verifying that the initialization parameter control_file_record_keep_time value is in the recommended range is minimal. Increasing this value will increase the size of the controlfile and possible query time for backup meta data and archive data.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that the FRA space management function is not blocked, as the owner userid of the oracle home with the environment properly set for the target database, execute the following command set:

    CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME="";
    CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME=$(echo -e "set heading off feedback off\n select value from V\$PARAMETER where name = 'control_file_record_keep_time';" | $ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba");
    if [[ $CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME -ge "1" && $CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME -le "9" ]]
    then echo -e "\nPASS:  control_file_record_keep_time is within recommended range [1-9]:" $CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME;
    elif [ $CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME -eq "0" ]
    then echo -e "\nFAIL:  control_file_record_keep_time is set to zero:" $CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME;
    else echo -e "\nWARNING:  control_file_record_keep_time is not within recommended range [1-9]:" $CF_RECORD_KEEP_TIME;
    fi;

    The expected output should be:

    PASS:  control_file_record_keep_time is within recommended range [1-9]: 7

    If the output is not as expected, investigate and correct the condition(s).

    NOTE: The use of an RMAN recovery catalog is recommended as the best way to avoid the loss of RMAN metadata because of overwritten control file records.
    

    Links
    1.  Initialization parameter CONTROL_FILE_RECORD_KEEP_TIME 
    2.  Oracle Database Backup and Recovery User's Guide 11g Release 2 (11.2) 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => control_file_record_keep_time is within recommended range [1-9]
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify control_file_record_keep_time value is in recommended range 



control_file_record_keep_time = 7
    


    Hide
    


    Verify rman controlfile autobackup is set to ON
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The control file is a binary file that records the physical structure of the database and contains important meta data required to recover the database. The database cannot startup or stay up unless all control files are valid. When a Recovery Manager catalog is not used, the control file is needed for database recovery because it contains all backup and recovery meta data.

    The impact of verifying and setting "CONTROLFILE AUTOBACKUP" to "ON" is minimal. 



    Risk:

    When a Recovery Manager catalog is not used, loss of the controlfile results in loss of all backup and recovery meta data, which causes a much more challenging database recovery operation



    Action / Repair:

    To verify that RMAN "CONTROLFILE AUTOBACKUP" is set to "ON", as the owner userid of the oracle home with the environment properly set for the target database, execute the following command set:

    RMAN_AUTOBACKUP_STATUS="";
    RMAN_AUTOBACKUP_STATUS=$(echo -e "set heading off feedback off\n select value from V\$RMAN_CONFIGURATION where name = 'CONTROLFILE AUTOBACKUP';" | $ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba");
    if [ -n "$RMAN_AUTOBACKUP_STATUS" ] && [ "$RMAN_AUTOBACKUP_STATUS" = "ON" ]
    then echo -e "\nPASS:  RMAN "CONTROLFILE AUTOBACKUP" is set to \"ON\":" $RMAN_AUTOBACKUP_STATUS;
    else
    echo -e "\nFAIL:  RMAN "CONTROLFILE AUTOBACKUP" should be set to \"ON\":" $RMAN_AUTOBACKUP_STATUS;
    fi;

    The expected output should be:

    PASS:  RMAN CONTROLFILE AUTOBACKUP is set to "ON": ON

    If the output is not as expected, investigate and correct the condition(s).

    For additional information, review information on CONFIGURE syntax in Oracle Database Backup and Recovery Reference 11g Release 2 (11.2).

    RMAN> CONFIGURE CONTROLFILE AUTOBACKUP ON;

    NOTE: Oracle MAA also recommends periodically backing up the controlfile to trace as additional backup.

    SQL> ALTER DATABASE BACKUP CONTROLFILE TO TRACE;
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => RMAN controlfile autobackup is set to ON
    'RMAN_CONFIGURATION='||NVL((SELECTUPPER(VALUE)FROMV$RMAN_CONFIGURATIONWHERENAME='CONTROLFILEAUTOBACKUP'),'ON') 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
rman_configuration = ON

    


    Hide
    


    Verify the Fast Recovery Area (FRA) has reclaimable space
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Oracle's Fast Recovery Area (FRA) manages archivelog files, flashback logs, and Oracle Recovery Manager (RMAN) backups. Before RMAN's space management can clean up files according to your configured retention and deletion policies, the database needs to be backed up periodically with RMAN. Without this RMAN backup information, the FRA space management function will not have any reclaimable space and thus you can run out of space resulting in a database hang.

    The impact of verifying that RMAN is used to ensure Fast Recovery Area (FRA) can manage the space is minimal.



    Risk:

    If RMAN is not used and FRA is being used, the space management function has no information to determine reclaimable space and the database may hang because it cannot archive a log to the FRA.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify that the FRA space management funcion is not blocked, as the owner userid of the oracle home with the environment properly set for the target database, execute the following command set:

    PROBLEM_FILE_TYPES_PRESENT=$(echo -e "set heading off feedback off\n select count(*) from V\$FLASH_RECOVERY_AREA_USAGE where file_type in ('ARCHIVED LOG', 'FLASHBACK LOG', 'BACKUP PIECE', 'IMAGE COPY') and number_of_files > 0 ;" | $ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba");
    RMAN_BACKUP_WITHIN_7_DAYS=$(echo -e "set heading off feedback off\n select count(*) from V\$BACKUP_SET where completion_time > sysdate-7;" | $ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba");
    if [ $PROBLEM_FILE_TYPES_PRESENT -eq "0" ]
    then echo -e "\nThis check is not applicable because file types 'ARCHIVED LOG', 'BACKUP PIECE', 'FLASHBACK LOG' or 'IMAGE COPY' are not present in V\$FLASH_RECOVERY_AREA_USAGE";
    else if [[ $PROBLEM_FILE_TYPES_PRESENT -ge "1" && $RMAN_BACKUP_WITHIN_7_DAYS -ge "1" ]]
    then echo -e "\nPASS:  FRA space management problem file types are present with an RMAN backup completion within the last 7 days."
    else echo -e "\nFAIL:  FRA space management problem file types are present without an RMAN backup completion within the last 7 days."
    fi;
    fi;

    The expected output should be:  PASS:  FRA space management problem file types are present with an RMAN backup completion within the last 7 days.

    If the output is not as expected, configure RMAN and make backups according to Oracle recommended best practices. In order to benefit from the FRA's space management system, you must use RMAN to backup your database on a regular basis.
    

    Links
    1.  Getting Started with RMAN 
    2.  Note: 360416.1 - Oracle10g / 11g - Getting Started with Recovery Manager (RMAN) (Doc ID 360416.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => FRA space management problem file types are present with an RMAN backup completion within the last 7 days
    FILE_TYPE    NUMBER_OF_FILES 
------------ --------------- 
ARCHIVED LOG              21
BACKUP PIECE             270
IMAGE COPY               122

    


    Hide
    


    Verify RoCE cabling and switch ports assignment
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The verify_roce_cables.py script determines the network topology and switch ports assignment of the RoCE Network Fabric in an Exadata rack. 

    Refer to My Oracle Support Doc ID 2587717.1 for download and usage instructions.

    Risk:

    Incorrect RoCE cabling causes unexpected behavior such as outages and performance degradation.

    Action / Repair:

    Initially you need to install the verify_roce_cables.py script and configure the input files on the database server from which you plan to run Exachk using the exact procedure as below:
    1) Create the directory /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/. 
    2) Link the files verify_roce_cables.py, setup_switch_ssh_equiv.sh, ... from the directory ibdiagtools to the directory ibdiagtools/exachk so that the verify_roce_cables.py script finds all required files:
    # ln /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/* /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/
    3) Create the input file nodes.lst in the directory /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/. The file contains the database servers and storage servers in the Exadata rack on separate lines. Use fully qualified domain names or IP addresses for each server.
    4) Create the input file switches.lst in the directory /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/. The file contains the RoCE switches in the Exadata rack on separate lines. Use fully qualified domain names or IP addresses for each switch.
    5) Ensure that ssh equivalency is configured between the nodes (hosts and switches).
    6) Manually run the verify_roce_cables.py script to ensure proper configuration: /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/verify_roce_cables.py -n /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/nodes.lst -s /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/switches.lst
    7) Ensure that the cabling is correct: for each switch port the two "CABLE OK?" columns should contain the "OK" status.

    Note: If the Exadata rack is part of a multi-rack cabling you need to perform the above procedure for each Exadata rack and run Exachk against each Exadata rack in the multi-rack cabling since the scope of the verify_roce_cables.py script is a single Exadata rack. Do not configure servers or switches from different Exadata racks in the nodes.lst or switches.lst input files.


    This initial configuration needs to be performed only once. After this initial configuration Exachk can run the script and will detect if there are cabling errors in the RoCE Network Fabric.

    If the script or one of the input files are are not configured in the directory /opt/oracle.SupportTools/ibdiagtools/exachk/, this is reported as: 
    "UNDETERMINED: One or more of the 3 required files do not exist."
    In this case, follow the above procedure to properly configure the script and the two input files, then re-run the check.

    If the script can not complete due to an error, this is reported as:
    "UNDETERMINED: The verify_roce_cables.py script can not complete."
    In this case, contact Oracle Support. 

    If the script can complete and detects no error in the network topology and switch ports assignment and the Exadata rack is part of a multi-rack cabling, this is reported as:
    "UNDETERMINED: This rack is part of a multi-rack cabling."
    In this case, perform the above procedure for each Exadata rack and run Exachk against each Exadata rack in the multi-rack cabling.

    If the script can complete and detects an error in the network topology and switch ports assignment (e.g., status "FAIL" or "SWAPPED" in column "CABLE OK?"), this is reported as:
    "FAILURE: RoCE cabling and switch ports assignment are not correct."
    In this case, contact Oracle Support. 

    If the script can complete and detects no error in the network topology and switch ports assignment, this is reported as:
    SUCCESS: RoCE cabling and switch ports assignment are correct."
    In this case, no further action is required.



    Note: Once the issue has been resolved, if you wish to validate this Exachk check individually, you may run the following command as "root" user:

        exachk -showpass -check E2966998CF731EF5E053D398EB0AB5BD
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    UNDETERMINED => The RoCE cabling and switch ports assignment are incorrect
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY ROCE CABLING AND SWITCH PORTS ASSIGNMENT



UNDETERMINED: One or more of the 3 required files do not exist.

    Exadata Critical Issue EX75
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 34034299, on Exadata Database Service and on-premises Exadata
    systems, database instances may fail to start with error ORA-600
    [pesldl03_MMap: errno 1 errmsg Operation not permitted] when PL/SQL compiled
    in NATIVE mode attempts execution during startup. This issue typically occurs
    when a database has all PL/SQL compiled in NATIVE mode and the Exadata
    software on the database server is updated.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX75 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3

    Local listener set to node VIP
    


    

    Recommendation
    The LOCAL_LISTENER parameter should be set to the node VIP. If you need fully qualified domain names, ensure that LOCAL_LISTENER is set to the fully qualified domain name (node-vip.mycompany.com). By default a local listener is created during cluster configuration that runs out of the grid infrastructure home and listens on the specified port(default is 1521) of the node VIP.

    Check the integrity of key GI startup files
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Integrity of key GI startup files is important for normal operations and for a clean startup of GI components. OCR and OLR are critical GI files and this check will validate that there are no corruption related errors for these files. This check will also validate that ASM credentials have been created properly across a multi-node cluster, and are consistent across the OCR, OLR, and password files.

    CRS takes a backup of OCR every 4 hours and a backup of OLR is performed once in 24 hours. Backup process checks the integrity of these files and makes sure that there are no corruptions and if there are any corruption related errors backup will not succeed. Existence of a current backup implies that there is no corruption in OCR and OLR at the time of the backup. We need to check if a successful backup was taken for these files in the specified timeframe and then check for any corruption related errors after the last backup to make sure the integrity of OCR and OLR is intact. OCR is global and if any corruption related errors are found, the errors will be displayed under each node in the report.

    The asmcmd "credverify" checks to see if credentials have been created properly across a multinode cluster, and are consistent across the OCR, OLR, and password file. The asmcmd "credfix" also does the same, but the command additionally deletes inconsistent credentials and adds new ones across the OCR, OLR, and password file. It also enables flex ASM if the GPnP profile has not been changed yet.

    Starting with GI 19.8 RU, you can use "asmcmd credverify" and "asmcmd credfix" to verify and fix the asm credential issue.

    Risk:

    If there is any corruption in the OCR and OLR files, normal GI operations would be impacted and a restart of GI stack will most likely fail.

    If there are invalid or missing ASM credentials across key GI files, it would result in ORA-01017: invalid username/password; logon denied errors.

    Action / Repair:

    Follow the below steps to correct the OCR or OLR corruption:
    Option 1: Restore consistent backup of OCR. Backup must be from before the change that introduced the corruption.
    See steps in note, How to Restore ASM Based OCR when OCR backup is located in ASM diskgroup? (Doc ID 2569847.1)
    Option 2: If OCR backup is not available, then rebuild OCR.
    See steps in  How to Deconfigure/Reconfigure(Rebuild OCR) or Deinstall Grid Infrastructure (Doc ID 1377349.1)

    If the following message is reported
        Oracle Cluster Registry (OCR): CRS-40021: The cluster activity log operation failed. Detailed error: 'ORA-28002: the password will expire within 1 days'
    and the GIMR (MGNTDB) is running on that system please run this command to fix the issue:
        mgmtca configRepos setpasswd -user calog
    or
        mgmtca configRepos setpasswd -allusers


    For credential related errors follow below MOS document: 
    User Guide for ASMCMDs "credverify" and "credfix" for ASM Credential Management (Doc ID 2717290.1)
    The credential resolution is typically done using $ORACLE_HOME/bin/asmcmd --nocp credfix. However depending upon the type of issue additional steps will be required. Hence please reach out to Oracle Support for assistance.

    Note: If after corrective actions are completed, you wish to run just this review manually without a full Exachk run, as the "root" userid execute the following Exachk command:

        exachk -check E0B03D017A2D4A2BE053D198EB0ADAE3 -showpass
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => The integrity check of key GI startup files succeeded
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - CHECK THE INTEGRITY OF KEY GI STARTUP FILES

    Click for more data
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => The integrity check of key GI startup files succeeded
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - CHECK THE INTEGRITY OF KEY GI STARTUP FILES
