    Hide
    


    Check Auto Extensible datafiles are expanding by at least one stripe width
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    When datafiles extend very frequently and using the default increment size, additional load can be put on the database engine which can lead to intermittent crashes.  By increasing the increment size to match the ASM disk group stripe width (1 x 4MB AU per ASM Disk) as a minimum, the chances of a database crash are reduced.

    Risk:

    The default increment size is 64MB or 100MB depending on the size of the datafile in question.  Both of these defaults are extremely low in an engineered system.  The default for a quarter rack will be only 144MB and the default for a full rack will be 672MB.  The default for an ExaCS full rack will be 576MB.  All of these increments are relatively small and therefore should impose no risk of using the increased size.

    Action / Repair:

    To see which datafiles are configured for auto extensible but using a small increment size, run the following query while connected as sysdba to the root container in multitenant container database or to the database in none multitenant:

    WITH data_dg AS
       ( SELECT REPLACE(value,'+') dg_value
           FROM v$parameter
          WHERE name = 'db_create_file_dest' )
       , au_size AS
       ( SELECT allocation_unit_size
           FROM v$asm_diskgroup_stat dg
              , data_dg
          WHERE name = data_dg.dg_value
            AND data_dg.dg_value = dg.name )
       , disk_cnt AS
       ( SELECT COUNT(*) value
           FROM v$asm_disk_stat d
              , v$asm_diskgroup_stat dg
              , data_dg
          WHERE dg.name = data_dg.dg_value
            AND dg.group_number = d.group_number)
       , stripe_size AS
       ( SELECT disk_cnt.value*au_size.allocation_unit_size value
           FROM au_size
              , disk_cnt )
    SELECT nvl(pdbs.name,'CDB$ROOT') ||
           '(' ||
           df.con_id ||
           '):Incremental size to small for file# ' ||
           df.file_id ||
           ', fname ' ||
           df.file_name ||
           ', incremental size ' ||
           (t.block_size * df.increment_by)/1024  ||
           'K, minimum recommended size ' ||
           stripe_size.value/1024 ||
           'K' text
      FROM cdb_data_files df
         , cdb_tablespaces t
         , stripe_size
         , v$pdbs pdbs
     WHERE df.con_id = t.con_id
       AND pdbs.con_id (+) = df.con_id
       AND df.tablespace_name = t.tablespace_name
       AND df.increment_by <> 0
       AND ( t.block_size * df.increment_by ) < stripe_size.value
    /


    Any rows returned means that those datafiles identified are configured for autoextend, but the increment size is smaller than the stripe width: 

    Sample output from a multi-tentant database is as follows

    PDB202149(4):Incremental size to small for file# 214, fname +DATAC1/CDB19RUA/D1E4416D853A72C0E053A50B200A2274/DATAFILE/aq_ts.5543.1089854819, incremental size 131072K, minimum recommended size 688128K


    Repair:

    For any files that are reported as being in error, the increment size can be increased by executing the command similar to

    SQL> alter session set container=PDB202149;

    Session altered.

    SQL> alter database datafile 214 autoextend on next 688128K;

    Database altered.
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    WARN => Some Auto Extensible datafiles are not expanding by at least one stripe width
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Check Auto Extensible datafiles are expanding by at least one stripe width

CDB$ROOT(0):Incremental size too small for file# 94, fname +DATA_EXA3/WHEXA3P3/DATAFILE/dmpersonal.369.1062498787, incremental size 10240K, minimum recommended size 196608K

CDB$ROOT(0):Incremental size too small for file# 101, fname +DATA_EXA3/WHEXA3P3/DATAFILE/ts_dwhmeta_e.379.1062503025, incremental size 131072K, minimum recommended size 196608K

    Hide
    


    Verify no ASM corruption is reported
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Verifying that ASM is not reporting corruption helps to avoid outages. If corruption is found, this proactive notification enables customers to perform root cause analysis and repair the issue before the corruption is encountered in their application.



    Risk:

    Application exposure to data corruption.



    Action / Repair:

    If an ASM rebalance or resync encounters an I/O error on the last mirror copy, ASM writes a well known string to the least number of blocks to avoid a diskgroup dismount. ASM provides notification on this event via it's alert log, but sometimes this notification can be missed.

    To verify that no ASM corruption has occurred, execute the following command as the "grid infrastructure owner" userid with the environment properly set for the target ASM instance, on each database server:

    alert_dest=$(echo -e "set heading off feedback off timing off lines 180\n select value from v\$parameter where name='background_dump_dest';"|$ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s / as sysdba|grep -v ^$|tail -1);
    alert_name=$(find $alert_dest -name 'alert_*.log' 2>/dev/null);
    if [ `grep -iw "with BADFDATA" $alert_name | wc -l` -ne "0" ]
    then
    echo -e "The following ASM alert logs were found to contain the string \"with BADFDATA\":\n"
    echo -e `grep -iw "with BADFDATA" $alert_name`
    else
    echo "No ASM alert logs were found to contain the string \"with BADFDATA\"."
    fi

    The expected result is:

    No ASM alert logs were found to contain the string "with BADFDATA".

    If the output is similar to:

    The following ASM alert logs were found to contain the string "with BADFDATA":

    /u01/app/grid/diag/asm/+asm/+ASM1/trace/alert_dummyfile.log:with BADFDATA

    Then a corruption has occurred. It is extremely important to identify the root cause and proactively deal with the corruption. For example, if it is an index block, the index can be recreated when convenient. 

    NOTE: There is no automatic correction of this condition. RCA MUST be conducted and the issue manually addressed. 

    NOTE: Exachk has no way to determine during an Exachk run if an issue uncovered in a sequence of alert logs has been corrected, because it has no way to determine what the root cause was, what the root cause specific correction should have been, whether or not the customer's application has accessed the involved blocks again, etc, etc.

    Customers should not follow the published guidelines for skipping this check, because then a future occurrence would be missed.

    After you have cleared the condition, and you know the database is clean, if you do not want to fail this check again for previously detected and corrected occurrences, the following actions are recommended:

    For alert log files that are not the current active alert log
    1) gzip the file in which the error was reported, after it has been confirmed that all the detected corruption has been corrected.  The detection command used will not search the gzip file.

    For the current active alert log
    1) Correct all detected corruptions
    2) execute the manual commands to check for new detected corruption.  If reported, correct.
    3) repeat 2) until no new corruptions reported.
    4) gzip the current active log.  ASM will create a new one as soon as it needs to write to the alert log.  The detection command used will not search the gzip file.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => There was no ASM corruption found.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY NO ASM CORRUPTION IS REPORTED 



    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => There was no ASM corruption found.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY NO ASM CORRUPTION IS REPORTED 



    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:+ASM2:
    PASS => There was no ASM corruption found.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY NO ASM CORRUPTION IS REPORTED 



    


    Hide
    


    Verify that packages exadata-sun-computenode-minimum and exadata-sun-computenode are installed
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Packages exadata-sun-computenode-minimum and exadata-sun-computenode must be installed.

    Note:
    On systems where the last update was an Exadata Live Update, it is expected that the exadata-sun-computenode* packages are not present. If a traditional software update is subsequently performed (not an Exadata Live Update), the exadata-sun-computenode* packages will be present again.

    Risk:

    Unpredicted behavior.

    Action / Repair:

    Ensure that packages exadata-sun-computenode-minimum and exadata-sun-computenode are installed on systems where the last update was not an Exadata Live Update.

    Note: If after corrective actions are completed, you wish to run just this review manually without a full Exachk run, as the "root" userid execute the following Exachk command:

        exachk -showpass -check DCAC61E06536FEDAE053D298EB0A9812
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 2676839.1 - Engineered Systems - Package exadata-sun-computenode-minimum Is Missing (Doc ID 2676839.1)
    

    Needs attention on-

    Check for parameter db_files
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized.

    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal.

    The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.

    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    The minimum recommended value for db_files is 1024.

    The default value (200) is typically too small for most customers.

    The values presented here are based upon internal testing and provide maximum reliability with generally acceptable performance.

    Customers should always perform due diligence testing based upon traditional application / system tuning, coupled with analysis of application uptime requirements, to determine the appropriate setting for their application environment.

    Once the appropriate testing has been done, customers may change this parameter as needed to meet their requirements and ignore this basic guidance.

    NOTE: Setting DB_FILES to a much larger value can increase pressure on the SGA (even if not all files permitted by the limit are actually created), possibly leading to a performance impact. The risk of performance impact is greater when both DB_FILES and PROCESSES are set to large values. A possible alternative to setting DB_FILES to a large value is to use "BIGFILE" tablespaces in conjunction with a reasonable DB_FILES value.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_FILES is set to a value greater than or equal to 1024. See detailed notes to verify
    whexa3p31.db_files = 1024
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_FILES is set to a value greater than or equal to 1024. See detailed notes to verify
    whexa3p33.db_files = 1024
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_FILES is set to a value greater than or equal to 1024. See detailed notes to verify
    whexa3p32.db_files = 1024
    


    Hide
    


    Verify release tracking bug on storage servers
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The release tracking bug output should match across storage servers. 



    Risk:

    If the output does not match then the cells might not have been patched correctly or are not on the same version 



    Action / Repair:

    The output is below for release tracking bug

    --
    cellcli -e "list cell attributes releaseTrackingBug"
             14394895
    --
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1662018.1 - Oracle Sun Database Machine Cross Node Consistency Best Practice Checks

    Hide
    


    Verify data files are recoverable
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    When you perform a DML or DDL operation using the NOLOGGING or UNRECOVERABLE clause, database backups made before the unrecoverable operation are invalidated and new backups are required. You can specify the SQL ALTER DATABASE or SQL ALTER TABLESPACE statement with the FORCE LOGGING clause to override the NOLOGGING setting; however, this statement will not repair a database that is already invalid.

    Risk:

    Changes under NOLOGGING will not be available after executing database recovery from a backup made before the unrecoverable change.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify that the data files are recoverable, execute the following RMAN command:

    RMAN> report unrecoverable database;

    If there are any unrecoverable actions, the output will be similar to:

    Report of files that need backup due to unrecoverable operations
    File   Type of Backup Required   Name
    ----   -----------------------   -----------------------------------
    <fno>  <full [or incremental]>   <file name>


    If nologging changes have occurred and the data must be recoverable then a backup of those datafiles that have nologging operations within should be done immediately:

        RMAN> backup [incremental] datafile [fno];

    Please consult the "Backup and Recovery User's Guide" for specific steps to resolve files that have unrecoverable changes.


    The standard best practice is to enable FORCE LOGGING at the database level (ALTER DATABASE FORCE LOGGING;) to ensure that all transactions are recoverable. However, placing the database in force logging mode for ETL operations can lead to unnecessary database overhead. MAA best practices call for isolating data that does not need to be recoverable. Such data would include:
        - data resulting from temporary loads,
        - data resulting from transient transformations,
        - any noncritical data.

    To reduce unnecessary redo generation, do the following:
    1) Specify FORCE LOGGING for all tablespaces that you explicitly wish to protect (ALTER TABLESPACE FORCE LOGGING;).
    2) Specify NO FORCE LOGGING for those tablespaces that do not need protection (ALTER TABLESPACE NO FORCE LOGGING;).
    3) Disable force logging at the database level (ALTER DATABASE NO FORCE LOGGING;) otherwise the database level settings will override the tablespace settings.

    Once the above is complete, redo logging will function as follows:

    Explicit no logging operations on objects in the no logging tablespace will not generate the normal redo (a small amount of redo is always generated for no logging operations to signal that a no logging operation was performed).

    All other operations on objects in the no logging tablespace will generate the normal redo.
    Operations performed on objects in the force logging tablespaces always generate normal redo.

    Note: Please seek assistance from Oracle Support to mitigate this problem. Upon their guidance, the following commands could help validate and identify corrupted blocks:

          oracle> dbv file=<data_file_returned_by_above_command> userid=sys/******
          RMAN> validate check logical database;
          SQL> select COUNT(*) from v$database_block_corruption;
    

    Links
    1.  Backing Up Database Files with RMAN 
    2.  Recovering NOLOGGING Tables and Indexes 
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-

    Exadata Critical Issue EX73
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 33580624, on X7 and later hardware running ILOM version 5, when
    patchmgr rolling update is performed, and ILOM firmware is upgraded to a
    higher version during the update, pre-staging of the new ILOM software may
    fail on multiple servers, causing unexpected simultaneous server reboot.  
    EX73 will affect this system only during rolling patchmgr update if it is
    done to Exadata version 21.2.0 through 21.2.7, inclusive.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX73 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX73
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX73 


imageinfo  -ver: 20.1.1.0.0
ipmitool sunoem: Version: 4.0.4.51 r134837
ipmitool user list 1 | grep -c -v '^ID': 4
ipmitool sunoem cli 'show /SP/preferences/password_policy' | grep -w policy: 8.

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX73 


imageinfo  -ver: 20.1.1.0.0
ipmitool sunoem: Version: 4.0.4.51 r134837
ipmitool user list 1 | grep -c -v '^ID': 4
ipmitool sunoem cli 'show /SP/preferences/password_policy' | grep -w policy: 8.

    imageinfo  -ver: 20.1.1.0.0

    Disks without Disk Group
    


    

    Recommendation
    The GROUP_NUMBER and DISK_NUMBER columns in GV$ASM_DISK will only be valid if the disk is part of a disk group which is currently mounted by the instance. Otherwise, GROUP_NUMBER will be 0, and DISK_NUMBER will be a unique value with respect to the other disks that also have a group number of 0. Run following query to find out the disks which are not part of any disk group.

    select name,path,HEADER_STATUS,GROUP_NUMBER  from gv$asm_disk where group_number=0;
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => No disks found which are not part of any disk group
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - DISKS WITHOUT DISK GROUP 




no rows selected
    


    Hide
    


    Oracle database version verification for platinum certification
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Customers with Platinum Certified Configurations can access the enhanced support of Oracle Platinum Services under their existing Oracle Premier Support agreement without paying extra.
    In addition to receiving the complete support essentials with Oracle Premier Support, qualifying Oracle Platinum Services customers also receive:
    24/7 Oracle remote fault monitoring
    Industry-leading response and restore times
      - 5 minute fault notification
      - 15 minute restoration or escalation to
        development
      - 30 minute joint debugging with development
    Patch deployment performed by Oracle four times per year

    Risk:

    In the event you do not meet the requirements or fulfil an obligation stated in the Oracle Platinum Support Policies you will no longer be eligible to receive Platinum Services, and Oracle, at its sole discretion, may discontinue providing the Platinum Services.

    Action / Repair:

    Contact your Platinum Services representative or check the Platinum Services FAQ
    Note: This check checks against the "Latest Certified Versions" from the Certified Platinum Configurations (https://www.oracle.com/us/support/library/certified-platinum-configs-1652888.pdf) - not against the "Earliest Compliant Versions".
    

    Links
    1.  Certified Platinum Configurations 
    2.  Note: 888828.1 - Exadata Database Machine and Exadata Storage Server Supported Versions
    3.  Oracle Platinum Services 
    4.  Oracle Platinum Services Frequently Asked Questions 
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3

    Optimizer bug fixes with disabled fix control In 19c
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    There are many optimizer bug fixes included into database base release as well as in every RU. Some of the Optimizer bug fixes (not all) are controlled by _FIX_CONTROL setting and are DISABLED by default when installed either through one-off backport or through RUs.

    Enabling the fix using fix control would help in avoiding known issues already reported and fixed by the product development but changing the _FIX_CONTROL parameter to enable optimizer fixes should be coupled with thorough testing of the application and database on a test/UAT environment to determine the appropriate setting.  Do not implement this change in a production environment before this testing is complete and the impact is understood.

    Risk:

    Keeping the fix in disabled state would not give any benefit out of the bug fix and there are likelihood of occurrence of known issues in Optimizer layer despite being fixed.

    Action / Repair:

    Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

    To enable the fix using fix control:-
    ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="<BUG_NO>:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

    For RAC environment:-
    ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="<BUG_NO>:1" SCOPE=BOTH SID='*';

    Example:
    ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29132869:1" SCOPE=BOTH;
    For RAC environment:-
    ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29132869:1" SCOPE=BOTH SID='*';

    To enable multiple fix control in single command:-
    Example:
    SQL> alter system set "_FIX_CONTROL"='28345522:ON', '22149010:ON', '25167306:ON', '29450812:ON', '28965084:ON', '28776811:ON' scope=both;
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 2702770.1 - Optimizer Bug Fixes With Disabled Fix Control In 19c
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    INFO => The Optimizer fixes for 19c database version is disabled by default for bugs with status value 0
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Optimizer bug fixes with disabled fix control In 19c 



--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 1   | No      | 22149010 | avoid multi-column semi join unnesting for NVL expressions
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 22149010 using fix control would help fixing the regression introduced with Bug 13704562 where the Optimizer chooses HASH JOIN RIGHT SEMI and takes long time instead of HASH UNIQUE.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan using HASH JOIN RIGHT SEMI due to regression with Bug 13704562. Use-case impacted: SQLs with multi-column NVL in subquery. Example: "col in NVL(col2,col3)". Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="22149010:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************

    

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 2   | No      | 25167306 | allow direct read on sql->plsql
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 25167306 using fix control would help allowing serial direct path read for SQL statements invoked from PLSQL objects.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan of not using direct path read for SQLs running from PLSQL objects. Use-case impacted: SQLs running from PL/SQL blocks or objects. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="25167306:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 3   | No      | 28345522 | skip join order sort elimination
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 28345522 using fix control would help avoiding the long parse time issues for queries with multiple tables in the join order and order by involved.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to long parse time for queries involving many tables in the join condition.  Use-case impacted: SQLs using multiple tables(>=14 tables) in join order and ORDER BY involved. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28345522:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 4   | No      | 29687220 | improve costing for indexes with empty statistics.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 29687220 using fix control would help Optimizer improve costing for indexes with empty statistics.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan chosen by Optimizer where index fast full scan is chosen over faster unique scan. Use-case impacted: SQL statement uses an index FFS when a unique scan is faster on empty tables with statistics. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29687220:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 5   | No      | 30232638 | Generate MIN estimates for cancelled cursor
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 30232638 using fix control would help resolving the issue related to cardinality feedback which is incorrectly calculated when cursor closed gracefully before fetching all the rows, especially during FIRST_ROWS_N optimizer mode.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan chosen for subsequent executions due to incorrect cardinality feedback calculated when cursor closed gracefully before fetching all the rows especially during FIRST_ROWS_N optimizer mode. Use-case impacted: SQL statements take long time to complete for subsequent executions with FIRST_ROWS_N optimizer mode. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="30232638:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 6   | No      | 28498976 | Allow legacy OR expansion for DML top query block
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 28498976 using fix control would help Optimizer choosing optimal plan using legacy OR expansion when Cost-based OR Expansion transformation is rejected.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan chosen by Optimizer when Cost-based OR expansion is rejected during the query transformation phase. Use-case impacted: DMLs with OR predicates. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28498976:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 7   | No      | 28965084 | try function-based indexes individually during inlist processing
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 28965084 using fix control would help Optimizer choosing optimal functional based index for SQL statements with the expressions involved in the INLIST predicate.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan of not using optimal functional based index for SQL statements with the expressions involved in the INLIST predicate. Use-case impacted: SQL statements with expressions involved in the INLIST predicates. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28965084:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 8   | No      | 28776811 | no replacement by transitive predicate for pushed join predicate
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 28776811 using fix control would help Optimizer choosing VIEW PUSHED PREDICATE / UNION ALL PUSHED PREDICATE and the SQL statement(s) run faster.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan for SQL statements by not using VIEW PUSHED PREDICATE / UNION ALL PUSHED PREDICATE transformation and the SQL(s) run slower. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28776811:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 9   | No      | 28567417 | delete orphan rows in sys.snap_logdep$ during drop mview log
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the fix 28567417 using fix control would help with orphaned entries in SYS.SNAP_LOGDEP$.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to orphaned entries in SYS.SNAP_LOGDEP$. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28567417:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
10   | No      | 29132869 | skip dynamic alternate fro for dynamic sampling query
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 29132869 using fix control would help avoiding error ORA-00918: column ambiguously defined for dynamic sampling query if the original plan is an adaptive plan.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to error ORA-00918: column ambiguously defined for dynamic sampling query using adaptive plan. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29132869 :1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
11   | No      | 28776431 | Use a limit for the number of nodes in bitmap indexes
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 28776431 using fix control would help avoiding ORA-00600 errors and also to avoid any instance crash incidents when SQL statements involve huge OR branches.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to ORA-600 errors or instance crash incidents when SQL statements involve huge no.of OR branches. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28776431:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
12   | No      | 28144569 | Allow onepass propagation for views
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the fix 28144569 using fix control would help an hybrid partition plan to be observed inside a view.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to a hybrid partition plan to not be observed inside a view. 
Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	alter system set "_fix_control"="28144569:1" scope=both;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
13   | No      | 29304314 | Allow legacy OR expansion when number of sub QB exceeds threshol
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 29304314 using fix control would help Optimizer to use legacy OR expansion when the Cost-based OR expansion is rejected due to the following message in the trace file. "ORE: number of subqueries (%d) exceeds threshold"

Risk:
	Optimizer Cost-Based Query Transformation and Optimizer OR Expansion gets rejected due to the number of subqueries are exceeded the threshold. Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan chosen for SQL statements without using OR expansion. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29304314:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
14   | No      | 29930457 | restrict _b_tree_bitmap_plans to single table access paths
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 29930457 using fix control would help Optimizer avoiding high parse time when exploring bitmap plans based on B-tree indexes. It also helps to avoid wrong results due to bitmap plans for b-tree indexes.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to high parse time or wrong results for SQL statements when Optimizer explores bitmap plans based on B-tree indexes. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29930457:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************
    Click for more data

	Enabling the Fix 22149010 using fix control would help fixing the regression introduced with Bug 13704562 where the Optimizer chooses HASH JOIN RIGHT SEMI and takes long time instead of HASH UNIQUE.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan using HASH JOIN RIGHT SEMI due to regression with Bug 13704562. Use-case impacted: SQLs with multi-column NVL in subquery. Example: "col in NVL(col2,col3)". Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

	Enabling the fix 28567417 using fix control would help with orphaned entries in SYS.SNAP_LOGDEP$.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to orphaned entries in SYS.SNAP_LOGDEP$. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28567417:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
10   | No      | 29132869 | skip dynamic alternate fro for dynamic sampling query
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 29132869 using fix control would help avoiding error ORA-00918: column ambiguously defined for dynamic sampling query if the original plan is an adaptive plan.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to error ORA-00918: column ambiguously defined for dynamic sampling query using adaptive plan. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29132869 :1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
11   | No      | 28776431 | Use a limit for the number of nodes in bitmap indexes
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 28776431 using fix control would help avoiding ORA-00600 errors and also to avoid any instance crash incidents when SQL statements involve huge OR branches.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to ORA-600 errors or instance crash incidents when SQL statements involve huge no.of OR branches. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="28776431:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
12   | No      | 28144569 | Allow onepass propagation for views
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the fix 28144569 using fix control would help an hybrid partition plan to be observed inside a view.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to a hybrid partition plan to not be observed inside a view. 
Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	alter system set "_fix_control"="28144569:1" scope=both;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
13   | No      | 29304314 | Allow legacy OR expansion when number of sub QB exceeds threshol
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 29304314 using fix control would help Optimizer to use legacy OR expansion when the Cost-based OR expansion is rejected due to the following message in the trace file. "ORE: number of subqueries (%d) exceeds threshold"

Risk:
	Optimizer Cost-Based Query Transformation and Optimizer OR Expansion gets rejected due to the number of subqueries are exceeded the threshold. Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to bad execution plan chosen for SQL statements without using OR expansion. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29304314:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
S.NO | ENABLED | BUG FIX  | BUG FIX DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
14   | No      | 29930457 | restrict _b_tree_bitmap_plans to single table access paths
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefit/Impact:
	Enabling the Fix 29930457 using fix control would help Optimizer avoiding high parse time when exploring bitmap plans based on B-tree indexes. It also helps to avoid wrong results due to bitmap plans for b-tree indexes.

Risk:
	Keeping the fix in disabled state might lead to high parse time or wrong results for SQL statements when Optimizer explores bitmap plans based on B-tree indexes. Enable the fix control with due diligence and evaluate the behavior of application SQL statements with above use-case in UAT before setting in PROD.

Action/Repair:
	ALTER SYSTEM SET "_FIX_CONTROL"="29930457:1" SCOPE=BOTH;

********************************************************************************
    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify config parameter vm.nr_hugepages value is same or less in initramfs [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If a database server memory is reduced, then you must first review and adjust the SGA size of the existing databases and operating system hugepages configuration accordingly. Hugepages configuration is controlled by the parameter "vm.nr_hugepages" in sysctl configuration file. This parameter could also be set in configuration file inside the /boot/initramfs-$(uname -r).img file which is used during the initial boot process. If the "vm.nr_hugepages" parameter exists in the config file inside initramfs image file then it is important that this parameter value is same or less than the value in the system config file.

    Risk:

    If the hugepages parameter exists in the initramfs config file and its value is set to a stale or incorrect higher value, then the database server may fail to restart and display OOM kill errors.

    Action / Repair:

    The expected output if parameter value is equal or lower is below:

    SUCCESS: vm.nr_hugepages parameter exists inside initramfs config file and value [nnnn] matches with /etc/sysctl.conf.
    or
    SUCCESS: vm.nr_hugepages parameter exists inside initramfs config file and its value [nnn] is less than the value [nnnn] in the system config file.
    or
    SUCCESS: vm.nr_hugepages parameter does not exist in initramfs image file. Comparison not needed.

    If parameter value is higher in initramfs then the output from the script would be:

    CRITICAL: vm.nr_hugepages parameter value [nnnnn] in initramfs config file is higher than the value [nnnn] in the system config file.


    If the initramfs parameter value is found to be higher, then use the below "dracut" command as "root" user to sync the initramfs image file. 

    # cp /boot/initramfs-$(uname -r).img <backup_directory>/initramfs-$(uname -r).img.bak
    # dracut --force 

    Note: Force option will overwrite the existing initramfs image file. 

    Run the check script again to validate the values.

    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => vm.nr_hugepages parameter value in initramfs config file matches or is less than value in system config file
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY SYSCTL.CONF PARAMETER VM.NR_HUGEPAGES VALUE IS SAME OR LESS IN INITRAMFS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: vm.nr_hugepages parameter does not exist in initramfs image file. Comparison not needed.

DETAILS:
  system sysctl config vm.nr_hugepages    : 50677
  initramfs sysctl config vm.nr_hugepages : hugepages not configured in initramfs config file
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => vm.nr_hugepages parameter value in initramfs config file matches or is less than value in system config file
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY SYSCTL.CONF PARAMETER VM.NR_HUGEPAGES VALUE IS SAME OR LESS IN INITRAMFS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: vm.nr_hugepages parameter does not exist in initramfs image file. Comparison not needed.

DETAILS:
  system sysctl config vm.nr_hugepages    : 50677
  initramfs sysctl config vm.nr_hugepages : hugepages not configured in initramfs config file
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => vm.nr_hugepages parameter value in initramfs config file matches or is less than value in system config file
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY SYSCTL.CONF PARAMETER VM.NR_HUGEPAGES VALUE IS SAME OR LESS IN INITRAMFS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: vm.nr_hugepages parameter does not exist in initramfs image file. Comparison not needed.

DETAILS:
  system sysctl config vm.nr_hugepages    : 50677
  initramfs sysctl config vm.nr_hugepages : hugepages not configured in initramfs config file
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX72
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 33703438, a database node (a physical server or a virtual KVM
    guest) on a RoCE-based  (i.e. X8M or X9M) Exadata system does not
    automatically restart if it is evicted by Oracle Clusterware Cluster
    Synchronization Services (CSS). The evicted node will remain unavailable
    until manual action is taken to reset the node.

    Action / Repair:

     See Exadata Critical Issue EX72 in MOS note 1270094.1. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX72
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX72 



imageinfo -ver: 20.1.1.0.0

Grid version: 19.8.0.0.0

rpm -q uptrack-updates-4.14.35-1902.304.6.4.el7uek.x86_64: package uptrack-updates-4.14.35-1902.304.6.4.el7uek.x86_64 is not installed

/etc/exadata/config/bug33703438fixed.txt does not exist

<GI_HOME>/bin/crsctl stat res ora.cssd -p -init | grep REBOOT_OPTS: "REBOOT_OPTS="

opatch lsinventory -disablelog -bugs_fixed -oh <GIHOME> | egrep '31411277|33563477|33731331': (no value returned)
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX72
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX72 



imageinfo -ver: 20.1.1.0.0

Grid version: 19.8.0.0.0

rpm -q uptrack-updates-4.14.35-1902.304.6.4.el7uek.x86_64: package uptrack-updates-4.14.35-1902.304.6.4.el7uek.x86_64 is not installed

/etc/exadata/config/bug33703438fixed.txt does not exist

<GI_HOME>/bin/crsctl stat res ora.cssd -p -init | grep REBOOT_OPTS: "REBOOT_OPTS="

opatch lsinventory -disablelog -bugs_fixed -oh <GIHOME> | egrep '31411277|33563477|33731331': (no value returned)
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX72
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX72 



imageinfo -ver: 20.1.1.0.0

Grid version: 19.8.0.0.0

<GI_HOME>/bin/crsctl stat res ora.cssd -p -init | grep REBOOT_OPTS: "REBOOT_OPTS="

opatch lsinventory -disablelog -bugs_fixed -oh <GIHOME> | egrep '31411277|33563477|33731331': (no value returned)

    Verify ILOM Power Up Configuration for HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE on database server
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Verifying the ILOM power up configuration helps to ensure that a server (or more) are booted up after a power interruption as quickly as possible.



    Risk:

    Not verifying the ILOM power up configuration may result in unexpected server boot behavior after a power interruption.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify the ILOM power up configuration, as the root userid enter the following command on each database and storage server:

    if [ -x /usr/bin/ipmitool ]
    then
    #Linux
    ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    else
    #Solaris
    /opt/ipmitool/bin/ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    fi;

    The output varies by Exadata software version and should be similar to:

    Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.1 or higher:
    HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=disabled
    HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE=enabled

    Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.0 or lower:
    HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled
    HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE=disabled

    If the output is not as expected, as the root userid use the ipmitool "set /SP/policy" command. For example:
    # ipmitool sunoem cli force "set /SP/policy HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled"
    Connected. Use ^D to exit.
    -> set /SP/policy HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled
    Set 'HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON' to 'enabled'

    -> Session closed
    Disconnected
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1470536.1 - Exadata: Removing power from rack, system failed to power on after power was restored
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => ILOM Power Up Configuration for HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY ILOM POWER UP CONFIGURATION FOR HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE



Connected. Use ^D to exit.
-> show /SP/policy

 /SP/policy
    Targets:

    Properties:
        DIMM_CE_MAP_OUT = enabled
        ENHANCED_PCIE_COOLING_MODE = disabled
        EXCESSIVE_CE_RESET = enabled
        HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON = disabled
        HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE = enabled

    Commands:
        cd

            set
        show

-> Session closed
Disconnected
    Click for more data
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => ILOM Power Up Configuration for HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY ILOM POWER UP CONFIGURATION FOR HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE



Connected. Use ^D to exit.
-> show /SP/policy

    Targets:

    Properties:
        DIMM_CE_MAP_OUT = enabled
        ENHANCED_PCIE_COOLING_MODE = disabled
        EXCESSIVE_CE_RESET = enabled

        HOST_LAST_POWER_STATE = enabled

    Commands:
        cd

            set
        show

-> Session closed

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Verifying the ILOM power up configuration helps to ensure that a server (or more) are booted up after a power interruption as quickly as possible.



    Risk:

    Not verifying the ILOM power up configuration may result in unexpected server boot behavior after a power interruption.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify the ILOM power up configuration, as the root userid enter the following command on each database and storage server:

    if [ -x /usr/bin/ipmitool ]
    then
    #Linux
    ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    else
    #Solaris
    /opt/ipmitool/bin/ipmitool sunoem cli force "show /SP/policy" | grep -i power
    fi;

    The output varies by Exadata software version and should be similar to:

    Exadata software version 11.2.3.2.1 or higher:

    HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled

    # ipmitool sunoem cli force "set /SP/policy HOST_AUTO_POWER_ON=enabled"

    Risk:

    Incorrect configuration could cause database connectivity issues.

File Verified OK:    /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/network/admin/sqlnet.ora
    


    Hide
    


    Verify DATA% diskgroup content type attribute is "data"
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If no high redundancy diskgroups are being used, the Grid Infrastructure release is 11.2.0.3 or higher, and the ASM diskgroup compatible.asm attribute is 11.2.0.3 or higher, then the content type attributes should be set for the standard three diskgroups, DATA, RECO, and DBFS_DG. Setting the content type attributes provides better recovery time objective (RTO) and recovery point objective (RPO or data loss tolerance) for half and full rack configurations, but still should be set for quarter rack configurations that meet the aforementioned criteria in case a future expansion occurs.



    Risk:

    Not setting the ASM diskgroup content type attributes leads to a greater exposure to downtime and data loss



    Action / Repair:

    The recommended ASM disk group configuration for Exadata is to use high redundancy ASM disk groups. If high redundancy ASM disk groups is not possible, then the recommended ASM disk group configuration is to have the standard three diskgroups, DATA, RECO, and DBFS_DG where DATA uses the 'data' content type, RECO uses the 'recovery' content type, and DBFS_DG uses the 'system' content type. Do not use content type to distinguish the availability characteristics of diskgroups that are used for a different purpose, such as those created in support of a particular service.

    To include the content type during diskgroup creation, simply add the attribute on the create command. Example:

    create diskgroup data normal redundancy
    DISK
    'o/*/DATA*'
    ATTRIBUTE
    'content.type' = 'DATA',
    'AU_SIZE' = '4M',
    'cell.smart_scan_capable'='TRUE',
    'compatible.rdbms'='11.2.0.2',
    'compatible.asm'='11.2.0.3';

    To add the content type to an existing diskgroup, simply add the attribute on the alter command, and run a rebalance. Note this rebalance can run quite long, but the diskgroup's data is fully redundant throughout. Example:

    alter diskgroup reco set attribute 'content.type'='recovery';
    alter diskgroup reco rebalance power <desired power setting> ; 

    To check that the content type is set properly, query v$asm_attribute. Example:

    SQL> select dg.name,a.value from v$asm_diskgroup_stat dg, v$asm_attribute a 
      2  where dg.group_number=a.group_number and a.name='content.type' 
      3  and (dg.name like 'DATA%' or dg.name like 'RECO%' or dg.name like 'DBFS_DG%');

    NAME                 VALUE
    -------------------- --------------------
    DATA                 data
    RECO                 recovery
    DBFS_DG              system
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => ASM gridisk data content type attribute is set to Oracle recommendation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY DATA% DISKGROUP CONTENT TYPE ATTRIBUTE IS "DATA" 



NAME
------------------------------
CONTENT_TYPE
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
DATA_EXA3
data
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => ASM gridisk data content type attribute is set to Oracle recommendation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY DATA% DISKGROUP CONTENT TYPE ATTRIBUTE IS "DATA" 



NAME
------------------------------
CONTENT_TYPE
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
DATA_EXA3
data
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:+ASM2:
    PASS => ASM gridisk data content type attribute is set to Oracle recommendation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY DATA% DISKGROUP CONTENT TYPE ATTRIBUTE IS "DATA" 



NAME
------------------------------
CONTENT_TYPE
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
DATA_EXA3
data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify RECO% diskgroup content type attribute is "recovery"
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If no high redundancy diskgroups are being used, the Grid Infrastructure release is 11.2.0.3 or higher, and the ASM diskgroup compatible.asm attribute is 11.2.0.3 or higher, then the content type attributes should be set for the standard three diskgroups, DATA, RECO, and DBFS_DG. Setting the content type attributes provides better recovery time objective (RTO) and recovery point objective (RPO or data loss tolerance) for half and full rack configurations, but still should be set for quarter rack configurations that meet the aforementioned criteria in case a future expansion occurs.



    Risk:

    Not setting the ASM diskgroup content type attributes leads to a greater exposure to downtime and data loss



    Action / Repair:

    The recommended ASM disk group configuration for Exadata is to use high redundancy ASM disk groups. If high redundancy ASM disk groups is not possible, then the recommended ASM disk group configuration is to have the standard three diskgroups, DATA, RECO, and DBFS_DG where DATA uses the 'data' content type, RECO uses the 'recovery' content type, and DBFS_DG uses the 'system' content type. Do not use content type to distinguish the availability characteristics of diskgroups that are used for a different purpose, such as those created in support of a particular service.

    To include the content type during diskgroup creation, simply add the attribute on the create command. Example:

    create diskgroup data normal redundancy
    DISK
    'o/*/DATA*'
    ATTRIBUTE
    'content.type' = 'DATA',
    'AU_SIZE' = '4M',
    'cell.smart_scan_capable'='TRUE',
    'compatible.rdbms'='11.2.0.2',
    'compatible.asm'='11.2.0.3';

    To add the content type to an existing diskgroup, simply add the attribute on the alter command, and run a rebalance. Note this rebalance can run quite long, but the diskgroup's data is fully redundant throughout. Example:

    alter diskgroup reco set attribute 'content.type'='recovery';
    alter diskgroup reco rebalance power <desired power setting> ; 

    To check that the content type is set properly, query v$asm_attribute. Example:

    SQL> select dg.name,a.value from v$asm_diskgroup_stat dg, v$asm_attribute a 
      2  where dg.group_number=a.group_number and a.name='content.type' 
      3  and (dg.name like 'DATA%' or dg.name like 'RECO%' or dg.name like 'DBFS_DG%');

    NAME                 VALUE
    -------------------- --------------------
    DATA                 data
    RECO                 recovery
    DBFS_DG              system
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:

    Verify no ASM unprotected templates exist
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    ASM redundancy prevents data loss


    Risk:

    Unprotected ASM templates and/or external redundancy diskgroups can cause data loss.



    Action / Repair:

    To check the types of ASM templates in use, use the following SQL statement in the ASM instance. The result should be HIGH or MIRROR.

    SQL> select distinct redundancy from v$asm_template;

    REDUND
    ------
    HIGH

    To check the redundancy of mounted ASM diskgroups, use the following SQL statement in the ASM instance. The result should be HIGH or NORMAL

    SQL> select distinct type from v$asm_diskgroup_stat;

    TYPE
    ------
    HIGH

    If either ASM unprotected templates or external redundancy diskgroups exist, investigate and correct the condition. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => There are no ASM unprotected templates.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY NO ASM UNPROTECTED TEMPLATES EXIST 



There were no ASM templates with redundancy other than HIGH or MIRROR
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => There are no ASM unprotected templates.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY NO ASM UNPROTECTED TEMPLATES EXIST 



There were no ASM templates with redundancy other than HIGH or MIRROR
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:+ASM2:
    PASS => There are no ASM unprotected templates.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY NO ASM UNPROTECTED TEMPLATES EXIST 



There were no ASM templates with redundancy other than HIGH or MIRROR
    


    Hide

    Hide
    


    Verify filesystems housing oracle homes do not have "nosuid" mount option set
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    All filesystems housing oracle homes will be checked to make sure 'nosuid' mount option is not present. If filesystems containing DB oracle homes are mounted with the 'nosuid' option then 'oradism' executable is unable to elevate the priority of critical processes like LMS and VKTM. If the LMS process is not running at the proper scheduling priority it can lead to instance evictions due to IPC send timeouts at times of high CPU utilization. Using Oracle 19c and higher, if 'oradism' is unable to elevate the priority of critical background processes there could be ORA-00800 [SET PRIORITY FAILED] error.

    The 'oradism' executable is invoked after database startup and must be allowed to change the scheduling priority of LMS and other database background processes to the realtime scheduling class in order to maximize the ability of these key processes to be scheduled on the CPU in a timely way at times of high CPU utilization.

    If GI oracle home is mounted with 'nosuid' option there could be errors in mounting ACFS filesystem and other unexpected issues.

    Risk:

    Software instability and unexpected behavior.

    Action / Repair:

    Example output returned by the check for success scenario:

    SUCCESS: Filesystem housing oracle home ($ORACLE_HOME) is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.

    Example output returned by the check for failure scenario:

    FAILURE: Following filesystem housing oracle home $(ORACLE_HOME) is mounted with 'nosuid' option. Remove the 'nosuid' option (ex: from /etc/fstab) and remount: Filesystem /dev/mapper/VGExaDb-LVDbOra1 mounted on /u01
    If any FAILURE is reported, then investigate and remove the 'nosuid' mount option from the filesystems and remount.

    Note: Error ORA-00800 [SET PRIORITY FAILED] can occur for other reasons. Please review MOS documents in links section for more information.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 2551359.1 - ORA-00800: Soft External Error, Arguments: [Set Priority Failed], [VKTM] [Check traces and OS configuration]
    2.  Note: 2718971.1 - ORA-00800: soft external error, arguments: [Set Priority Failed], [VKTM], for Oracle Linux (Doc ID 2718971.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm03:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm02:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => Filesystem housing oracle home is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify filesystems housing oracle homes do not have "nosuid" mount option set 



SUCCESS: Filesystem housing oracle home /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.
/etc/mtab entry: /dev/mapper/VGExaDb-LVDbOra1 /u01 xfs rw,nodev,relatime,attr2,inode64,sunit=2048,swidth=2048,noquota 0 0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => Filesystem housing oracle home is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify filesystems housing oracle homes do not have "nosuid" mount option set 



SUCCESS: Filesystem housing oracle home /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.
/etc/mtab entry: /dev/mapper/VGExaDb-LVDbOra1 /u01 xfs rw,nodev,relatime,attr2,inode64,sunit=2048,swidth=2048,noquota 0 0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => Filesystem housing oracle home is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify filesystems housing oracle homes do not have "nosuid" mount option set 



SUCCESS: Filesystem housing oracle home /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.
/etc/mtab entry: /dev/mapper/VGExaDb-LVDbOra1 /u01 xfs rw,nodev,relatime,attr2,inode64,sunit=2048,swidth=2048,noquota 0 0
    


    Hide
    


    Verify filesystems housing Grid Infrastructure home does not have "nosuid" mount option set
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    All filesystems housing oracle homes will be checked to make sure 'nosuid' mount option is not present. If filesystems containing DB oracle homes are mounted with the 'nosuid' option then 'oradism' executable is unable to elevate the priority of critical processes like LMS and VKTM. If the LMS process is not running at the proper scheduling priority it can lead to instance evictions due to IPC send timeouts at times of high CPU utilization. Using Oracle 19c and higher, if 'oradism' is unable to elevate the priority of critical background processes there could be ORA-00800 [SET PRIORITY FAILED] error.

    The 'oradism' executable is invoked after database startup and must be allowed to change the scheduling priority of LMS and other database background processes to the realtime scheduling class in order to maximize the ability of these key processes to be scheduled on the CPU in a timely way at times of high CPU utilization.

    If GI oracle home is mounted with 'nosuid' option there could be errors in mounting ACFS filesystem and other unexpected issues.

    Risk:

    Software instability and unexpected behavior.

    Action / Repair:

    Example output returned by the check for success scenario:

    SUCCESS: Filesystem housing oracle home ($ORACLE_HOME) is not mounted with 'nosuid' option.

    Example output returned by the check for failure scenario:

    FAILURE: Following filesystem housing oracle home $(ORACLE_HOME) is mounted with 'nosuid' option. Remove the 'nosuid' option (ex: from /etc/fstab) and remount: Filesystem /dev/mapper/VGExaDb-LVDbOra1 mounted on /u01
    If any FAILURE is reported, then investigate and remove the 'nosuid' mount option from the filesystems and remount.


    Note: Error ORA-00800 [SET PRIORITY FAILED] can occur for other reasons. Please review MOS documents in links section for more information.
    

    Links

    2.  Note: 2718971.1 - ORA-00800: soft external error, arguments: [Set Priority Failed], [VKTM], for Oracle Linux (Doc ID 2718971.1)

    Hide
    


    Primary database protection with Data Guard
    


    

    Recommendation
    Active Data Guard is the real-time data protection and availability solution that eliminates single point of failure by maintaining one or more synchronized physical replicas of the production database. If an unplanned outage of any kind impacts the production database, applications and users can quickly failover to a synchronized standby, minimizing downtime and preventing data loss. An Active Data Guard standby can be used to offload read-only applications, ad-hoc queries, and backups from the primary database or be dual-purposed as a test system at the same time it provides disaster protection. An Active Data Guard standby can also be used to minimize downtime for planned maintenance when upgrading to new Oracle Database patch sets and major database releases and for select migrations.  
     
    For zero data loss protection and fastest recovery time, deploy a local Data Guard standby database with Data Guard Fast-Start Failover and integrated client failover. For protection against outages impacting the entire data center, or a broad geography, deploy a Data Guard standby database at a remote location. Oracle 12c Far Sync Standby can achieve zero data loss protection across Wide Area Network or across regions.

    Key HA Benefits:

    • Active Data Guard provides optimal data protection by using physical replication and comprehensive Oracle validation to maintain an exact byte-for-byte copy of the primary database that can be open read-only to offload reporting, ad-hoc queries and backups.

    • With Oracle 11g release 2 and higher Active Data Guard and real time apply, data block corruptions can be repaired automatically and downtime can be reduced from hours and days of application impact to zero downtime with zero data loss.

    • With MAA best practices, Data Guard Fast-Start Failover and integrated client failover, downtime from database, cluster and site failures can be reduced from hours to days to seconds.

    • With remote standby database (Disaster Recovery Site), you have protection from complete site failures.

    • In all cases, the Active Data Guard instances can be active and used for other activities.

    • Data Guard can reduce risks and downtime for planned maintenance activities by using Database rolling upgrade with transient logical standby or DBMS rolling, standby-first patch apply and database migrations.

    • For other advanced replication requirements where read-write access to a replica database is required while it is being synchronized with the primary database see Oracle GoldenGate logical replication. Oracle GoldenGate can be used to support heterogeneous database platforms and database releases, an effective read-write full or subset logical replica and to reduce or eliminate downtime for application, database or system changes. Oracle GoldenGate flexible logical replication solution's main trade-off is the additional administration for application developer and database administrators.

    

    Links
    1.  Goldengate resources 
    2.  HABP: Chapter 9: Configuring Oracle Data Guard 11gR2 
    3.  Note: 1265700.1 - Oracle Patch Assurance - Data Guard Standby-First Patch Apply
    4.  Note: 1302539.1 - Best Practices for Corruption Detection, Prevention, and Automatic Repair - in a Data Guard Configuration
    5.  Oracle Data Guard: Disaster  Recovery for Oracle Exadata Database Machine 
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    INFO => Primary database is not protected with Data Guard (standby database) for real-time data protection and availability
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Primary database protection with Data Guard 



No standby database is configured.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    INFO => Primary database is not protected with Data Guard (standby database) for real-time data protection and availability
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Primary database protection with Data Guard 



No standby database is configured.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    INFO => Primary database is not protected with Data Guard (standby database) for real-time data protection and availability
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Primary database protection with Data Guard 



No standby database is configured.
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX69
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 33042327, soft-offlined memory pages may be reused while marked poisoned when DIMM correctable errors (CE) occur. Exadata systems affected by this issue may experience node crashes, corruption, instance crashes, process kills, or internal errors.

    Action / Repair:

     See Exadata Critical Issue EX69 in MOS note 1270094.1. 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    CRITICAL => System is exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX69
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX69 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0

uptrack-show | grep 'Possible memory corruption when allocating huge pages' did not return any row

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX69 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0

uptrack-show | grep 'Possible memory corruption when allocating huge pages' did not return any row

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX69 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0


    uptrack-show | grep 'Possible memory corruption when allocating huge pages' did not return any row

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX69 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0

uptrack-show | grep 'Possible memory corruption when allocating huge pages' did not return any row

    Exadata Critical Issue EX69

    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:
