    Locally managed tablespaces
    


    

    Recommendation
    In order to reduce contention to the data dictionary, rollback data, and reduce the amount of generated redo, locally managed tablespaces should be used rather than dictionary managed tablespaces.Please refer to the below referenced notes for more information about benefits of locally managed tablespace and how to migrate a tablespace from dictionary managed to locally managed.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 105120.1 - 	Advantages of Using Locally Managed vs Dictionary Managed Tablespaces
    2.  Use Locally Managed Tablespaces 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => All tablespaces are locally managed tablespace
    'DICTIONARY_MANAGED_TABLESPACE_COUNT='||COUNT(EXTENT_MANAGEMENT) 
---------------------------------------------------------------- 
dictionary_managed_tablespace_count = 0

    


    Hide
    


    Automatic segment storage management
    


    

    Recommendation
    Starting with Oracle 9i Auto Segment Space Management (ASSM) can be used by specifying the SEGMENT SPACE MANAGEMENT clause, set to AUTO in the CREATE TABLESPACE statement. Implementing the ASSM feature allows Oracle to use bitmaps to manage the free space within segments. The bitmap describes the status of each data block within a segment, with respect to the amount of space in the block available for inserting rows. The current status of the space available in a data block is reflected in the bitmap allowing for Oracle to manage free space automatically with ASSM. ASSM tablespaces automate freelist management and remove the requirement/ability to specify PCTUSED, FREELISTS, and FREELIST GROUPS storage parameters for individual tables and indexes created in these tablespaces. 
    

    Links
    1.  Use Automatic Segment Space Management 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => All tablespaces are using Automatic segment storage management
    Query returned no rows which is expected when the SQL check passes.

    


    Hide
    


    Default Temporary Tablespace
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Its recommended to set default temporary tablespace at database level to achieve optimal performance for queries which requires sorting the data.


    Action / Repair:

    If default temporary tablespace is not set at database level, it's recommended to follow the instructions given in Note 1498442.1

    SQL> SELECT PROPERTY_NAME,PROPERTY_VALUE
         FROM database_properties
         PROPERTY_NAME ='DEFAULT_TEMP_TABLESPACE';
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1498442.1 - Overview of Oracle Temporary Tablespaces
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => Default temporary tablespace is set
    PROPERTY_NAME           PROPERTY_VALUE 
----------------------- -------------- 
DEFAULT_TEMP_TABLESPACE TEMP

    


    Hide
    


    Archivelog Mode
    


    

    Recommendation
    Running the database in ARCHIVELOG mode and using database FORCE LOGGING mode are prerequisites for database recovery operations. The ARCHIVELOG mode enables online database backup and is necessary to recover the database to a point in time later than what has been restored. Features such as Oracle Data Guard and Flashback Database require that the production database run in ARCHIVELOG mode.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 69739.1 - How to Turn Archiving ON and OFF in Oracle RDBMS
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database Archivelog Mode is set to ARCHIVELOG
    'ARCHIVELOGMODE='||UPPER(LOG_MODE) 
---------------------------------- 
Archivelog Mode = ARCHIVELOG

    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter undo_management
    


    

    Recommendation
    Oracle provides a fully automated mechanism, referred to as automatic undo management, for managing undo information and space. In this management mode, you create an undo tablespace, and the server automatically manages undo segments and space among the various active sessions.You should set the UNDO_MANAGEMENT initialization parameter to AUTO to enable automatic undo management.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Instance is using Automatic Undo Management
    whexa3p31.undo_management = AUTO
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Instance is using Automatic Undo Management
    whexa3p33.undo_management = AUTO
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Instance is using Automatic Undo Management
    whexa3p32.undo_management = AUTO
    


    Hide
    


    Verify AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables use Automatic Segment Space Management
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    With AUDIT_TRAIL set for database (AUDIT_TRAIL=db), and the AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables located in a dictionary segment space managed SYSTEM tablespace, "gc" wait events are sometimes observed during heavy periods of database logon activity. Testing has shown that under such conditions, placing the AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables in the SYSAUX tablespace, which uses automatic segment space management, reduces the space related wait events.

    The impact of verifying that the AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables are in the SYSAUX table space is low. Moving them if they are not located in the SYSAUX does not require an outage, but should be done during a scheduled maintenance period or slow audit record generation window.

    If Unified Auditing feature is enabled, unified audit records doesn't get inserted into the AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables, and instead uses AUDSYS.AUD$UNIFIED which by default gets created in SYSAUX tablespace. SYSAUX tablespace uses ASSM by default. So if Unified Audit feature is enabled, then it's ok to leave AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables in the SYSTEM as it will be empty.

    Risk:

    If Unified Audit feature is not used, and if AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables are not verified to use automatic segment space management, there is a risk of a performance slowdown during periods of high database login activity.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify if Unified Auditing is enabled, use the following Sqlplus command :

    select value from v$option where parameter = 'Unified Auditing';

    If enabled the output should be:
    VALUE
    ----------------------------------------------------------------
    TRUE

    To verify the segment space management policy currently in use by the AUD$ and FGA_LOG$ tables, use the following Sqlplus command:

    select t.table_name,ts.segment_space_management from dba_tables t, dba_tablespaces ts where ts.tablespace_name = t.tablespace_name and t.table_name in ('AUD$','FGA_LOG$');

    The output should be:

    TABLE_NAME                     SEGMEN
    ------------------------------ ------
    FGA_LOG$                       AUTO
    AUD$                           AUTO 

    If one or both of the AUD$ or FGA_LOG$ tables return "MANUAL", use the DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT package to move them to the SYSAUX tablespace:

    BEGIN
    DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.set_audit_trail_location(audit_trail_type => DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.AUDIT_TRAIL_AUD_STD,--this moves table AUD$ 
    audit_trail_location_value => 'SYSAUX');  
    END;  
    /

    BEGIN
    DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.set_audit_trail_location(audit_trail_type => DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.AUDIT_TRAIL_FGA_STD,--this moves table FGA_LOG$ 
    audit_trail_location_value => 'SYSAUX');
    END;
    /   

    The output should be similar to:

    PL/SQL procedure successfully completed. 

    If the output is not as above, investigate and correct the condition.

        NOTE: This "DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.set_audit_trail" command should be executed as part of the dbca template post processing scripts, but for existing databases, the command can be executed, but since it moves the AUD$ & FGA_LOG$ tables using "alter table ... move" command, it should be executed at a "quiet" time


    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check CB95A1BF5B1160ACE0431EC0E50A12EE".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair CB95A1BF5B1160ACE0431EC0E50A12EE".
    

    Links
    1.  Use Automatic Segment Space Management 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => Table AUD$[FGA_LOG$] uses Automatic Segment Space Management
    Unified Auditing is enabled.

    


    Hide

    Block Corruptions
    


    

    Recommendation
    The V$DATABASE_BLOCK_CORRUPTION view displays blocks marked corrupt by Oracle Database components such as RMAN commands, ANALYZE, dbv, SQL queries, and so on. Any process that encounters a corrupt block records the block corruption in this view.  Repair techniques include block media recovery, restoring data files, recovering with incremental backups, and block newing. Block media recovery can repair physical corruptions, but not logical corruptions. It is also recommended to use RMAN "CHECK LOGICAL" option to check for data block corruptions periodically. Please consult the Oracle Database Backup and Recovery User's Guide for repair instructions
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => No reported block corruptions in V$DATABASE_BLOCK_CORRUPTIONS
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Block Corruptions 



0 block_corruptions found in v$database_block_corruptions
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => No reported block corruptions in V$DATABASE_BLOCK_CORRUPTIONS
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Block Corruptions 



0 block_corruptions found in v$database_block_corruptions
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => No reported block corruptions in V$DATABASE_BLOCK_CORRUPTIONS
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Block Corruptions 



0 block_corruptions found in v$database_block_corruptions
    


    Hide
    


    Redo Log File Size
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    For performance reasons redo logs should be sized so that they do not switch more than once every 10 minutes or 7 switches in an hour during peak throughput.

    Risk:

    Switching logs too often causes poor recovery performance on the standby as recovery only checkpoints at a log boundary which pauses recovery while the buffer cache is flushed.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify redo log size, as the owner userid of a given database, and with the environment properly set to access that database, execute the following command set:

    function logswitches {
    $ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s '/ as sysdba' <<EOF
    set feedback off newpage none termout on
    alter session set nls_date_format='YYYY/MM/DD HH24:MI:SS';
    select * from (
    select thread#,sequence#,first_time "LOG START TIME",(blocks*block_size/1024/1024)/((next_time-first_time)*86400) "REDO RATE(MB/s)", \
    (((blocks*block_size)/a.average)*100) pct_full
    from v\$archived_log, (select avg(bytes) average from v\$log) a
    where ((next_time-first_time)*86400<300)
    and first_time > (sysdate-90)
    and (((blocks*block_size)/a.average)*100)>80
    and dest_id=1
    order by 4 desc
    )
    where rownum<11;
    exit
    EOF
    }

    export SWITCHES=$(logswitches)

    if [ $(echo "$SWITCHES"| wc -l) -le 1 ]
     then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: Redo logs are appropriately sized"
     else
      echo
      echo -e "WARNING: Redo logs are potentially mis-sized.  Below is a list of archived logs from"
      echo -e "the previous 90 days which were active for less than 5 minutes and the redo rate seen"
      echo -e "for the duration of that log.  These indicate the peak redo rate. Resizing of the log"
      echo -e "files to accomodate this rate may be required.\n"
      echo "$SWITCHES"
    fi

    The expected output is:

    SUCCESS: Redo logs are appropriately sized

    Example of a "WARNING" result:

    WARNING: Redo logs are potentially mis-sized.  Below is a list of archived logs from
    the previous 90 days which were active for less than 5 minutes and the redo rate seen
    for the duration of that log.  These indicate the peak redo rate. Resizing of the log
    files to accomodate this rate may be required.

       THREAD#  SEQUENCE# LOG START TIME      REDO RATE(MB/s)   PCT_FULL
    ---------- ---------- ------------------- --------------- ----------
             2      12374 2017/02/24 15:03:04      412.881913 95.7611859
             2      12382 2017/02/24 15:15:10       408.75571 89.8144871
             2      12296 2017/02/24 12:06:26       396.99937 92.0774907
             2      12380 2017/02/24 15:09:31      371.651196 90.7351553
             2      12385 2017/02/24 15:17:28      370.488538 90.4513031
             2      12378 2017/02/24 15:06:18      362.405012 95.1136202
             2      12389 2017/02/24 15:20:51      356.672996 95.7862049
             2      12377 2017/02/24 15:05:32      354.660687 99.5751441
             2      12350 2017/02/24 13:27:40      353.577854  97.113058
             2      12354 2017/02/24 13:30:45      347.344079 97.5209206

    If logs are frequently switching, the redo logs should be increased in size according to the following chart:

    Peak redo rate according
    to EM or AWR reports 	     Recommended redo log group size
    <1 MB/sec 	                     1 GB
    <=3 MB/sec 	                     3 GB
    <= 5 MB/sec 	                     4 GB
    <= 25 MB/sec 	             16 GB
    <= 50 MB/sec 	             32 GB
    > 50 MB/sec 	                     64 GB
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:

    Exadata Critical Issue DB48
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 30227028, clusterware reconfiguration may hang on one or more nodes in a cluster with three or more nodes when one node is shutdown abruptly or encounters a node eviction, which can cause cluster-wide outage.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue DB48 in MOS note 1270094.1(below link)
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    High Redundancy Controlfile
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The control file is a critical database file that stores metadata for a given database.  When a control file becomes unavailable, the database instance fails.  Control files are also essential for database and instance recovery.
    Proper control file configuration helps to reduce database outages, improve performance, and shorten database or instance recovery time.

    The impact of verifying the database control file configuration is minimal.  The impact of changing the control file configuration varies based on specific circumstances and cannot be estimated here.

    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 


    Action / Repair:

    Oracle recommends that the control files be configured (via the control_files database initialization parameter) as shown:

    Either DATA or RECO alone are high redundancy:

        one controlfile in DATA - PASS
        one controlfile in RECO - PASS

        NOTE: Following the above recommendation maintains High Availability while reducing the overall number of control file writes.

    both DATA and RECO are high redundancy:

        one controlfile in DATA - PASS
        one controlfile in RECO - WARN

        NOTE: It is preferred the control file be in DATA with all of the other database files.

        one controlfile in both DATA and RECO - WARN
        both controlfile in both DATA - WARN
        both controlfile in both RECO - WARN

        NOTE: The above recommendation results in more control file writes than are necessary.

    only normal redundancy disk groups exist, both DATA and RECO:

        one controlfile in DATA with Data Guard in use - WARN

        NOTE: The above recommendation is high impact because if the control file is lost, a complete fail over to the standby is required!

        one controlfile in DATA with current backup controlfile in RECO diskgroup - WARN

        NOTE: Regardless of the specific control file configuration, it is recommended that rman contolfile autobackup always be on. For additional information and specific evaluation see the "Verify rman controlfile autobackup is set to ON" section in the MAA Scorecard.

    ANY OTHER CONTROLFILE CONFIGURATION - FAIL
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Database control files are not configured as recommended
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - High Redundancy Controlfile 



Control files = +DATA_EXA3/WHEXA3P3/CONTROLFILE/current.259.1051182763
+RECO_EXA3/WHEXA3P3/CONTROLFILE/current.513.1061307037

High redundancy diskgroups = 0

High redundancy diskgroups where control files are multiplexed = 0

Normal redundancy diskgroups where control files are multiplexed = 2

Flash Recovery Area disk group Name = +RECO_EXA3

Data Guard in-use = 0

RMAN control file auto backup = 1
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Database control files are not configured as recommended
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - High Redundancy Controlfile

    Identify OBJ$.OBJ# reaching maximum limit
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If obj$.obj# reaches the maximum limit of 4294967293 then ORA-600 [kkdlron-max-objid] would be encountered.


    Risk:

    Potential Database Outage.

    Action / Repair:

    When OBJ$.OBJ# reaches maximum limit of 4294967293, Database will no longer be usable. The only available solution would be to rebuild the database before reaching the limit. If limit has already reached, customer need to apply patch for bug 20529650 and rebuild the database immediately.

    Note: Bug 20529650 is not a fix. It only provides an extra headroom for rebuilding the database by providing additional 39 million object numbers. Customers will need to use this window to rebuild their database immediately. 

    Customer is also advised to change the application to prevent consuming the object numbers at a high rate. 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 20529650.8 - Bug 20529650 - ORA-600 [kkdlron-max-objid], [4254950911] (Doc ID 20529650.8)
    2.  Note: 2660231.1 -  Internal Database Limits on Number of Objects, Constraints, and Users (Doc ID 2660231.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => OBJ$.OBJ# is within maximum limit
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Identify OBJ$.OBJ# reaching maximum limit 



 

PDB 0 : PASS: obj# max value: 12432432 is within threshold value: 4284967293.

    Identify CON$.CON# reaching maximum limit
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If con$.con# reaches the maximum limit of 4294967293 then ORA-600 [12807] would be encountered.

    Risk:

    Potential Database Outage.

    Action / Repair:

    For the con$.con# reaching maximum limit of 4294967293, patch 25343563 would need to be applied which provides a mechanism to reuse the con# which are unused in the system due to fragmentation.

    If 25343563 is already applied, please ensure that you have enough gaps in con$ for con#.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 13781691.8 - Bug 13781691 - ORA-600 [12807] if CON$.CON# very high due to bug 13784384 (Doc ID 13781691.8)
    2.  Note: 2660231.1 -  Internal Database Limits on Number of Objects, Constraints, and Users (Doc ID 2660231.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => CON$.CON# is within maximum limit
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Identify CON$.CON# reaching maximum limit

    Hide
    


    Verify v$asm_disk os_mb and total_mb values are the same
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    By default on Exadata, ASM disk groups will be created with disks that are the same size as the Exadata grid disks. This simplifies overall administration and management. It also enables Exadata auto disk management to work properly.

    Risk:

    When the ASM disk size differs from the Exadata grid disk size, commands that add a disk to the disk group, such as those run by Exadata auto disk management, will fail. This can typically occur after a failed disk is replaced.

    The most common reason for this condition to occur is when incorrect ASM disk sizes are specified on the ASM create disk group command, or if a wrong size is specified using the ASM RESIZE DISK command.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that all diskgroups have the same OS_MB and TOTAL_MB values, as the grid home owner userid, and with the environment set to access the ASM instance on one database server, execute the following code:

    UNSET DISK_SIZE_DATA
    DISK_SIZE_DATA=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set newpage none head on lines 80 pagesize 32000 feedback on timing off serveroutput on
    column group_number heading 'Group|Number'
    column name heading 'Name'
    column os_mb heading 'Operating|System MB'
    column total_mb heading "Total MB"
    select group_number,name,os_mb,total_mb
    from v\$asm_disk_stat
    where os_mb != total_mb and failgroup_type='REGULAR'
    order by group_number,failgroup,name;
    exit
    EOF
    )
    if [[ $(echo $DISK_SIZE_DATA | egrep -i "no rows selected" | wc -l) -eq 1 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: os_mb and total_mb values matched for all disks.  Details:\n$DISK_SIZE_DATA"
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: os_mb and total_mb values did not match for one or more disks.  Details:\n$DISK_SIZE_DATA"
    fi

    The expected output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: os_mb and total_mb values matched for all disks.  Details:

    no rows selected

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE: os_mb and total_mb values did not match for one or more disks.  Details:
         Group                                 Operating
        Number Name                            System MB   Total MB
    ---------- ------------------------------ ---------- ----------
             2 RECOC1_FD_00_RANDOM05CELADM10     1161664    1160656
             2 RECOC1_FD_01_RANDOM05CELADM10     1161664    1160656
             2 RECOC1_FD_02_RANDOM05CELADM10     1161664    1160656
    <example data truncated for brevity>
             2 RECOC1_FD_04_RANDOM05CELADM14     1161664    1160656
             2 RECOC1_FD_05_RANDOM05CELADM14     1161664    1160656
             2 RECOC1_FD_06_RANDOM05CELADM14     1161664    1160656
             2 RECOC1_FD_07_RANDOM05CELADM14     1161664    1160656

    40 rows selected.

    If a result other than "SUCCESS:" is returned, identify the reason for having a different value and take corrective action.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => v$asm_disk os_mb and total_mb values are the same
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY V$ASM_DISK OS_MB AND TOTAL_MB VALUES ARE THE SAME 



SUCCESS: os_mb and total_mb values matched for all disks.  Details:

no rows selected
    


    Hide
    


    Identify OBJ$.OBJ# reaching maximum limit
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If obj$.obj# reaches the maximum limit of 4294967293 then ORA-600 [kkdlron-max-objid] would be encountered.


    Risk:

    Potential Database Outage.

    Action / Repair:

    When OBJ$.OBJ# reaches maximum limit of 4294967293, Database will no longer be usable. The only available solution would be to rebuild the database before reaching the limit. If limit has already reached, customer need to apply patch for bug 20529650 and rebuild the database immediately.

    Note: Bug 20529650 is not a fix. It only provides an extra headroom for rebuilding the database by providing additional 39 million object numbers. Customers will need to use this window to rebuild their database immediately. 

    Customer is also advised to change the application to prevent consuming the object numbers at a high rate. 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 20529650.8 - Bug 20529650 - ORA-600 [kkdlron-max-objid], [4254950911] (Doc ID 20529650.8)
    2.  Note: 2660231.1 -  Internal Database Limits on Number of Objects, Constraints, and Users (Doc ID 2660231.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => OBJ$.OBJ# is within maximum limit

12385825 12387309 12392005 12393463 12395342 12397729 12397729 12401066 12401066 12402947 12404180 12405512 12412042 12413133 12413170 12414311 12417548 12419966 12423427 12424542 12424574 12425691 12428178 12429281 12429293 12430385 12430455 12431545
    


    Hide
    


    Invalid application objects
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Verifying application code is properly compiled can prevent potential impacts to performance and to ensure that users do not encounter application errors.

    Risk:

    Although invalid objects are recompiled automatically on use, compiling objects prior to operation will either eliminate or minimize subsequent latencies due to on-demand automatic recompilation at runtime. Objects which are invalid due to coding errors may cause the calling applications to fail. The recommended approach to recompile objects using the utlrp.sql script will only compile invalid objects. There is no impact to valid objects which may be in use. 

    Action / Repair:

    The following script can be run to recompile invalid objects:

    $ORACLE_HOME/perl/bin/perl catcon.pl --n 1 --echo --log_file_base utlrp --script_dir . utlrp.sql


    Review the log file for "OBJECTS WITH ERRORS" and "ERRORS DURING RECOMPILATION". Further documentation can be found here:

    https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/ladbi/recompiling-all-invalid-objects.html


    Invalid objects can also be listed using the following SQL:

    SELECT owner, object_name, object_type 
      FROM dba_objects 
     WHERE status != 'VALID' 
       AND owner not in ('SYS','SYSTEM') 
       AND object_name NOT LIKE 'BIN$%';


    Note: Once the issue has been resolved, if you wish to validate this Exachk check individually, run the following command as "root" user:

        exachk -showpass -check BCE22AC1A8B1190DE0431EC0E50A453A
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 837570.1 - Complete Checklist for Manual Upgrades to 11gR2
    

    Needs attention onwhexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    WARN => Application objects were found to be invalid
    OWNER               OBJECT_NAME                                   OBJECT_TYPE       
------------------- --------------------------------------------- -----------------

DWHAPLVIEW          DKAG_GRUPPEN                                  VIEW

    Hide
    


    Check for parameter recyclebin
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice  values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization  parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance  maximized. 
    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting  these parameters is minimal.  The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance  settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact. 
      


    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization  parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 
      


    Action / Repair:

    "RECYCLEBIN = ON" provides higher availability by enabling the Flashback Drop  feature. "ON" is the default value and should not be changed. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => RECYCLEBIN on PRIMARY is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p31.recyclebin = on
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => RECYCLEBIN on PRIMARY is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p33.recyclebin = on
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => RECYCLEBIN on PRIMARY is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p32.recyclebin = on
    


    Hide
    


    Verify griddisk ASM status
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The correct configuration and maintenance of storage server griddisks is critical for optimal performance and outage avoidance.

    The impact of verifying the storage server griddisk configuration is minimal. Correcting any abnormalities is dependent upon the reason for the anomaly, so the impact cannot be estimated here.



    Risk:

    If the storage server griddisk configuration as recommended, poor performance or unexpected outages may occur.

    Action / Repair:

    NOTE: On a storage server configured according to Oracle best practices, all griddisks should have these recommended attributes:
    Griddisk Attribute 	Recommended Value
    status 	active
    asmmodestatus 	ONLINE
    asmdeactivationoutcome 	Yes

    To verify the storage server griddisk ASM status, execute the following command as the "root" userid on each storage server:

    unset BASE_DATA GD_COUNT BAD_GD_LIST
    #capture the base data
    BASE_DATA=$(cellcli -e "list griddisk attributes name,status,asmmodestatus,asmdeactivationoutcome" 2>&1)
    #count griddisks
    GD_COUNT=$(echo "$BASE_DATA" | wc -l)
    #gridisks out of recommendation
    BAD_GD_LIST=$(echo "$BASE_DATA" | egrep -v ".*\<active\>.*\<ONLINE\>.*\<Yes\>")
    if [[ -z $BAD_GD_LIST ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: $GD_COUNT griddisks were examined and found to be configured as recommended."
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: $GD_COUNT griddisks were examined and one or more griddisks were found not to be configured as recommended.  Details:\n$BAD_GD_LIST"
    fi

    The expected output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: 46 griddisks were examined and found to be configured as recommended.

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE: 46 griddisks were examined and one or more griddisks were found not to be configured as recommended.  Details:
             ACFSC1_CD_00_busm01celadm01     active  OFFLINE  Yes
             ACFSC1_CD_01_busm01celadm01     active  OFFLINE  Yes
             ACFSC1_CD_02_busm01celadm01     active  OFFLINE  Yes

    If the output is not as expected, investigate the condition and take corrective action based upon the root cause of the unexpected result.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => All griddisks examined were configured as recommended
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify griddisk ASM status 


SUCCESS: 24 griddisks were examined and found to be configured as recommended.

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify griddisk ASM status 


SUCCESS: 24 griddisks were examined and found to be configured as recommended.

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify griddisk ASM status 


SUCCESS: 24 griddisks were examined and found to be configured as recommended.

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify griddisk ASM status 


SUCCESS: 24 griddisks were examined and found to be configured as recommended.

    


    Hide
    


    Verify average ping times to DNS nameserver [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Secure Shell (SSH) remote login procedures require communication between the remote target device and the DNS nameserver. Minimal average ping times to the DNS nameserver improve SSH login times and help to avoid problems such as timeouts or failed connection attempts.

    The impact of verifying average ping times to the DNS nameserver is minimal. The impact required to minimize average ping times to the DNS nameserver varies by configuration and cannot be estimated here.

    Risk:

    Long ping times between remote SSH targets and the active DNS server may cause remote login failures, performance issues, or dropped application connections.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify average ping times to DNS nameserver, enter the following command set as the "root" userid on each database server, storage server, and RDMA Network Fabric switch:

    HOST_NAME=$(hostname);
    if [ -s /usr/local/bin/version ]
    then
      DNS_SERVER=$(grep -o '[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}' /etc/resolv.conf | head -1);
    else
      DNS_SERVER=$(nslookup $HOST_NAME | head -1 | cut -d: -f2 | sed -e 's/^[ \t]*//');
    fi;
    OS_TYPE=$(uname);
    if [ $OS_TYPE = "Linux" ]
    then
      PING_COMM="ping -c10 $DNS_SERVER";
    else
      PING_COMM="ping -s $DNS_SERVER 56 5";
    fi;
    AVG_PING_TIME=$($PING_COMM | egrep avg | cut -d"/" -f5);
    TRNC_AVG_PING_TIME=$(echo $AVG_PING_TIME | cut -d"." -f1);  
    if [ "$TRNC_AVG_PING_TIME" -le "3" ];
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting SSH operations: $AVG_PING_TIME";
      echo -e "Active DNS Server IP:  $DNS_SERVER\n";
    else
      echo -e "WARNING: Average ping times to DNS nameserver may be negatively impacting SSH operations:  $AVG_PING_TIME";
      echo -e "Active DNS Server IP:  $DNS_SERVER\n";
    fi;

    The output should be similar to the following:

    SUCCESS: Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting operations: 3.255
    Active DNS Server IP:  111.222.333.444

    If the result is a "WARNING", first repeat the command set several times at different intervals to determine if the results are consistent. The command set is one spot check for ten pings. The environment could normally have a short delay and an execution just happened to catch a period of poor response, or it could normally have a long delay and an execution just happened to catch a period of good response. If the results are consistent, determine the root cause and take appropriate corrective action.

    NOTE: The result of this command set is a reflection of how DNS is implemented in the environment and not evidence in itself of a defect in the Oracle Exadata Database Machine.

    NOTE: A "WARNING" result does not prove that a delay is causing SSH connectivity problems in the environment. A "WARNING" result should always be evaluated in conjunction with a review of SSH connectivity issues in the environment. If there are other SSH connectivity issues present, evaluate if reducing or stabilizing the average ping times to the DNS nameserver may correct the issues.

    NOTE: As with many other network performance metrics, the average ping times to DNS nameserver should be "minimal". However, it is possible that any given environment may return a result that exceeds the threshold used in this command set, yet it is satisfactory given the overall environment characteristics and lack of other related problems. IF NO OTHER PROBLEMS related to DNS exist other than this command set returning a "WARNING", and the numbers reported are acceptable after a "baseline" for the given environment has been established by repeated sampling, then the documented procedures for bypassing this check in Exachk may be implemented.

    NOTE: Due to the differences in available commands for the RDMA Network Fabric switch, the command set assumes the first "nameserver" in /etc/resolv.conf is the "active" DNS server.

    NOTE: The use of the Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) may also mitigate the effects of long average ping times to DNS nameserver. For more information see: Verify the Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) is Running
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting SSH operations.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY AVERAGE PING TIMES TO DNS NAMESERVER [DATABASE SERVER] 



Active DNS Server IP:		 10.5.5.5
Average for 10 pings in ms:	 0.844
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting SSH operations.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY AVERAGE PING TIMES TO DNS NAMESERVER [DATABASE SERVER] 



Active DNS Server IP:		 10.5.5.5
Average for 10 pings in ms:	 0.826
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting SSH operations.
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY AVERAGE PING TIMES TO DNS NAMESERVER [DATABASE SERVER] 



Active DNS Server IP:		 10.5.5.5
Average for 10 pings in ms:	 0.809
    


    Hide
    


    Verify average ping times to DNS nameserver [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Secure Shell (SSH) remote login procedures require communication between the remote target device and the DNS nameserver. Minimal average ping times to the DNS nameserver improve SSH login times and help to avoid problems such as timeouts or failed connection attempts.

    The impact of verifying average ping times to the DNS nameserver is minimal. The impact required to minimize average ping times to the DNS nameserver varies by configuration and cannot be estimated here.



    Risk:

    Long ping times between remote SSH targets and the active DNS server may cause remote login failures, performance issues, or dropped application connections.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify average ping times to DNS nameserver, enter the following command set as the "root" userid on each database server, storage server, and RDMA Network Fabric switch:

    HOST_NAME=$(hostname);
    if [ -s /usr/local/bin/version ]
    then
      DNS_SERVER=$(grep -o '[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}' /etc/resolv.conf | head -1);
    else
      DNS_SERVER=$(nslookup $HOST_NAME | head -1 | cut -d: -f2 | sed -e 's/^[ \t]*//');
    fi;
    OS_TYPE=$(uname);
    if [ $OS_TYPE = "Linux" ]
    then
      PING_COMM="ping -c10 $DNS_SERVER";
    else
      PING_COMM="ping -s $DNS_SERVER 56 5";
    fi;
    AVG_PING_TIME=$($PING_COMM | egrep avg | cut -d"/" -f5);
    TRNC_AVG_PING_TIME=$(echo $AVG_PING_TIME | cut -d"." -f1);  
    if [ "$TRNC_AVG_PING_TIME" -le "3" ];
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting SSH operations: $AVG_PING_TIME";
      echo -e "Active DNS Server IP:  $DNS_SERVER\n";
    else
      echo -e "WARNING: Average ping times to DNS nameserver may be negatively impacting SSH operations:  $AVG_PING_TIME";
      echo -e "Active DNS Server IP:  $DNS_SERVER\n";
    fi;

    The output should be similar to the following:

    SUCCESS: Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting operations: 3.255
    Active DNS Server IP:  111.222.333.444

    If the result is a "WARNING", first repeat the command set several times at different intervals to determine if the results are consistent. The command set is one spot check for ten pings. The environment could normally have a short delay and an execution just happened to catch a period of poor response, or it could normally have a long delay and an execution just happened to catch a period of good response. If the results are consistent, determine the root cause and take appropriate corrective action.

    NOTE: The result of this command set is a reflection of how DNS is implemented in the environment and not evidence in itself of a defect in the Oracle Exadata Database Machine.

    NOTE: A "WARNING" result does not prove that a delay is causing SSH connectivity problems in the environment. A "WARNING" result should always be evaluated in conjunction with a review of SSH connectivity issues in the environment. If there are other SSH connectivity issues present, evaluate if reducing or stabilizing the average ping times to the DNS nameserver may correct the issues.

    NOTE: As with many other network performance metrics, the average ping times to DNS nameserver should be "minimal". However, it is possible that any given environment may return a result that exceeds the threshold used in this command set, yet it is satisfactory given the overall environment characteristics and lack of other related problems. IF NO OTHER PROBLEMS related to DNS exist other than this command set returning a "WARNING", and the numbers reported are acceptable after a "baseline" for the given environment has been established by repeated sampling, then the documented procedures for bypassing this check in Exachk may be implemented.

    NOTE: Due to the differences in available commands for the RDMA Network Fabric switch, the command set assumes the first "nameserver" in /etc/resolv.conf is the "active" DNS server.

    NOTE: The use of the Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) may also mitigate the effects of long average ping times to DNS nameserver. For more information see: Verify the Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) is Running
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => Average ping times to DNS nameserver should not be negatively impacting SSH operations.
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify average ping times to DNS nameserver [Storage Server] 


Active DNS Server IP:		 10.25.64.48
Average for 10 pings in ms:	 0.806

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify average ping times to DNS nameserver [Storage Server] 


Active DNS Server IP:		 10.25.64.48
Average for 10 pings in ms:	 0.819

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify average ping times to DNS nameserver [Storage Server] 


Active DNS Server IP:		 10.25.64.48
Average for 10 pings in ms:	 0.803

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify average ping times to DNS nameserver [Storage Server] 

    

Active DNS Server IP:		 10.25.64.48
Average for 10 pings in ms:	 0.861

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter memory_max_target
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain ASM initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. 

    By setting these ASM initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. 

    The parameters are specific to the ASM instances. Unless otherwise specified, the 
    value is for both X2-2 and X2-8 Database Machines. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal. 



    Risk:

    If the ASM initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 
     


    Action / Repair:

    Setting MEMORY_MAX_TARGET to 0 disables MEMORY_MAX_TARGET for the ASM instance
     
    NOTE: The proper way to implement the memory related parameters is as follows. This is important as it works around an issue where memory_target remains set despite setting it to 0. 
     
        * alter system set pga_aggregate_target=400M sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system set memory_target=0 sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system set memory_max_target=0 sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system reset memory_max_target sid='*' scope=spfile; 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1373255.1 - 	11.2.0.1/11.2.0.2 to 11.2.0.3 Database Upgrade on Exadata Database Machine
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed on+ASM3, +ASM1, +ASM2
    

    


    Status on +ASM1:
    PASS => ASM parameter MEMORY_MAX_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM1.memory_max_target = 0
    

    Status on +ASM3:
    PASS => ASM parameter MEMORY_MAX_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM3.memory_max_target = 0
    

    Status on +ASM2:
    PASS => ASM parameter MEMORY_MAX_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM2.memory_max_target = 0
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter pga_aggregate_target
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain ASM initialization parameters 
    should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at 
    deployment time. By setting these ASM initialization parameters as 
    recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The 
    parameters are specific to the ASM instances. The impact of setting 
    these parameters is minimal. 
     


    Risk:

    If the ASM initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of 
    issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is 
    not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 
     


    Action / Repair:

    This disables memory_target for the ASM instance and setting PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET to 400M provides the ASM instance sufficient PGA memory
     
    NOTE: The proper way to implement the memory related parameters is as 
    follows. This is important as it works around an issue where memory_target 
    remains set despite setting it to 0. 
     
        * alter system set pga_aggregate_target=400M sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system set memory_target=0 sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system set memory_max_target=0 sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system reset memory_max_target sid='*' scope=spfile; 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed on+ASM3, +ASM1, +ASM2
    

    


    Status on +ASM1:
    PASS => ASM parameter PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM1.pga_aggregate_target = 419430400
    

    Status on +ASM3:
    PASS => ASM parameter PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM3.pga_aggregate_target = 419430400
    

    Status on +ASM2:
    PASS => ASM parameter PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM2.pga_aggregate_target = 419430400
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter memory_target
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain ASM initialization parameters 
    should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at 
    deployment time. By setting these ASM initialization parameters as 
    recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The 
    parameters are specific to the ASM instances. Unless otherwise specified, the 
    value is for both X2-2 and X2-8 Database Machines. The impact of setting 
    these parameters is minimal. 
     


    Risk:

    If the ASM initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of 
    issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is 
    not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 
     


    Action / Repair:

    This disables memory_target for the ASM instance. 
     
    NOTE: The proper way to implement the memory related parameters is as 
    follows. This is important as it works around an issue where memory_target 
    remains set despite setting it to 0. 

        * alter system set pga_aggregate_target=400M sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system set memory_target=0 sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system set memory_max_target=0 sid='*' scope=spfile; 
        * alter system reset memory_max_target sid='*' scope=spfile; 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1373255.1 - 	11.2.0.1/11.2.0.2 to 11.2.0.3 Database Upgrade on Exadata Database Machine

    +ASM1.memory_target = 0

    PASS => ASM parameter MEMORY_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM3.memory_target = 0

    PASS => ASM parameter MEMORY_TARGET is set according to recommended value
    +ASM2.memory_target = 0

    Verify RDMA Network Fabric kernel parameters on database servers
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    There are RDMA Network Fabric kernel parameter settings required for Exadata to work correctly that vary depending upon if a specific interface (RoCE or RDMA Network Fabric) is configured as active/passive or active/active.

    For an active/passive configuration, the network kernel parameter settings for all RDMA Fabric interfaces (only RDMA Network Fabric on older Exadata systems) should be:
    Network Kernel Parameter	Value
    accept_local	1
    rp_filter	0

    For an active/active configuration, the network kernel parameter settings for all RDMA Fabric interfaces should be:
    Network Kernel Parameter	Value
    accept_local	1
    rp_filter	0
    arp_announce	2
    - AND the three single kernel parameters
    Network Kernel Parameter	Value
    net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter	0
    net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter	0
    net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local	1

    The impact of verifying the RDMA Network Fabric kernel parameters is minimal. Correcting a network kernel parameter requires updating the boot configuration file and restarting the interface(s). 

    NOTE: These recommendations are for the RDMA Fabric interfaces on database servers only! They do not apply to the Ethernet interfaces on the database servers. No changes are permitted on the storage servers.

    Risk:

    Incorrect RDMA Network Fabric kernel parameter settings may prevent RAC from starting, or result in dropped packets and inconsistent RAC operation.  For the Ethernet RoCE network it could cause all systems connected to freeze.

    Action / Repair:

    The expected output should be similar to (2 socket active/active example).  The first section are the values of the running configuration.  The second section are how they are configured at boot.

    SUCCESS:  All RDMA Fabric kernel parameter settings are as recommended for an active/active interface: running kernel parameters
    net.ipv4.conf.re0.accept_local=1
    net.ipv4.conf.re1.accept_local=1
    net.ipv4.conf.re0.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.re1.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.re0.arp_announce=2
    net.ipv4.conf.re1.arp_announce=2
    net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local=1
    SUCCESS:  All RDMA Fabric kernel parameter settings are as recommended for an active/active interface: kernel parameters at boot
    net.ipv4.conf.re0.accept_local=1
    net.ipv4.conf.re1.accept_local=1
    net.ipv4.conf.re0.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.re1.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.re0.arp_announce=2
    net.ipv4.conf.re1.arp_announce=2
    net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local=1

    - OR - (8 socket active/active example)

    SUCCESS:  All RDMA Fabric kernel parameter settings are as recommended for an active/active interface: running kernel parameters
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.accept_local=1
    <outpout truncated>
    net.ipv4.conf.ib7.accept_local=1
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.rp_filter=0
    <outpout truncated>
    net.ipv4.conf.ib7.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.arp_announce=2
    <outpout truncated>
    net.ipv4.conf.ib7.arp_announce=2
    net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local=1
    SUCCESS:  All RDMA Fabric kernel parameter settings are as recommended for an active/active interface: kernel parameters at boot
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.accept_local=1
    <outpout truncated>
    net.ipv4.conf.ib7.accept_local=1
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.rp_filter=0
    <outpout truncated>
    net.ipv4.conf.ib7.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.arp_announce=2
    <outpout truncated>
    net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter=0
    net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local=1  

    If a "FAILURE: ..." message appears, investigate for root cause, make the necessary edits to the boot configuration file, and restart the interface(s).  A failure example:

    FAILURE:  One or more RDMA Fabric kernel parameter settings are not as recommended for an active/passive interface: running kernel parameters
    net.ipv4.conf.bondib0.accept_local=0
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.accept_local=0
    net.ipv4.conf.ib1.accept_local=0
    net.ipv4.conf.bondib0.rp_filter=1
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.rp_filter=1
    net.ipv4.conf.ib1.rp_filter=1
    net.ipv4.conf.bondib0.arp_announce=0
    net.ipv4.conf.ib0.arp_announce=0
    net.ipv4.conf.ib1.arp_announce=0
    net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=1
    net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter=1
    net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local=0
    FAILURE:  One or more RDMA Fabric kernel parameter settings are not as recommended for an active/passive interface: kernel parameters at boot
    accept_local not found
    rp_filter not found
    arp_announce not found
    net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter not found
    net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter=1
    net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local not found

    If the kernel parameters were not configured in the boot configuration file, this is noted as "not found".


    NOTE: These recommendations are for the RDMA Fabric interfaces on database servers only! They do not apply to the Ethernet interfaces on the database servers. No changes are permitted on the storage servers.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => All RDMA Network Fabric kernel parameters on database servers are as expected
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY RDMA NETWORK FABRIC KERNEL PARAMETERS ON DATABASE SERVERS

net.ipv4.conf.re1.rp_filter=0
net.ipv4.conf.re0.arp_announce=2
net.ipv4.conf.re1.arp_announce=2
net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=0
net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter=0
net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_local=1

net.ipv4.conf.re0.accept_local=1

    net.ipv4.conf.re0.arp_announce=2

    Exadata Critical Issue EX64
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 31784659 and bug 31648140, RDS connection establishment may be slow or hang resulting in node eviction, slow or hung clusterware/ASM startup, offline ASM disks, and slow or hung database(s). RDS connection establishment occurs during normal activity in many circumstances, including after restart of a fabric switch, database server, or storage server.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX64 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    CRITICAL => System is exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX64
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX64



kernel version = 4.14.35.1902.304.6.4.el7uek.x86_64
Exadata image version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808
uptrack-updates RPM version = package uptrack-updates-4.14.35-1902.304.6.4.el7uek.x86_64 is not installed
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    CRITICAL => System is exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX64
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX64

Exadata image version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808
uptrack-updates RPM version = package uptrack-updates-4.14.35-1902.304.6.4.el7uek.x86_64 is not installed
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:

    Exadata Critical Issue EX64
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 31784659 and bug 31648140, RDS connection establishment may be slow or hang resulting in node eviction, slow or hung clusterware/ASM startup, offline ASM disks, and slow or hung database(s). RDS connection establishment occurs during normal activity in many circumstances, including after restart of a fabric switch, database server, or storage server.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX64 in MOS note 1270094.1.

    Exadata Critical Issue EX65
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 31898529, the use of diagnostic collection script sundiag.sh may result in flash card failure on Exadata X7 and X8 storage servers, which can cause disk group dismount and data loss, particularly when invoked using dcli across multiple storage servers.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX65 in below MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:

    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX65

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX65

Sundiag Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

    Sundiag Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX65 


Exadata Image Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

Sundiag Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify TCP Selective Acknowledgement is enabled
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    For maximum performance with large data transfers, TCP Selective Acknowledgement should be enabled. 

    Risk:

    If TCP Selective Acknowledgement is not enabled, there may be severe network throughput degradation for large data transfers during operations such as RMAN backup or restore, database migrations, cloning, instantiation, or Data Guard transport. Network throughput has been observed to reduce by a factor of 10 in some cases. 

    Action / Repair:

    NOTE: Even if a database server has TCP Selective Acknowledgement enabled (e.g: Exadata default), end to end network throughput can still degrade if any participating client or sender database server does not have it enabled.

    To verify TCP Selective Acknowledgement is enabled, as the root userid on each database server execute the following code:

    RAW_DSACK_DATA=$(sysctl net.ipv4.tcp_dsack)
    DSACK_VALUE=$(echo "$RAW_DSACK_DATA" | cut -d"=" -f2 | tr -dc [[:digit:]])
    RAW_SACK_DATA=$(sysctl net.ipv4.tcp_sack)
    SACK_VALUE=$(echo "$RAW_SACK_DATA" | cut -d"=" -f2 | tr -dc [[:digit:]])
    if [[ $DSACK_VALUE = "1" && $SACK_VALUE = "1" ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled.  Details:\n$RAW_DSACK_DATA\n$RAW_SACK_DATA"
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: TCP Selective Acknowledgment is not enabled.  Details:\n$RAW_DSACK_DATA\n$RAW_SACK_DATA"
    fi

    The expected output is:

    SUCCESS: TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled.  Details:
    net.ipv4.tcp_dsack = 1
    net.ipv4.tcp_sack = 1

    A "FAILURE" example:

    FAILURE: TCP Selective Acknowledgment is not enabled.  Details:
    net.ipv4.tcp_dsack = 1
    net.ipv4.tcp_sack = 0

    If TCP Selective acknowlegement is not enabled, execute the following code as the root userid:

    sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_dsack=1
    sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_sack=1
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY TCP SELECTIVE ACKNOWLEDGEMENT IS ENABLED



SUCCESS: TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled.  Details:
net.ipv4.tcp_dsack = 1
net.ipv4.tcp_sack = 1
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY TCP SELECTIVE ACKNOWLEDGEMENT IS ENABLED



SUCCESS: TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled.  Details:
net.ipv4.tcp_dsack = 1
net.ipv4.tcp_sack = 1
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY TCP SELECTIVE ACKNOWLEDGEMENT IS ENABLED



SUCCESS: TCP Selective Acknowledgment is enabled.  Details:
net.ipv4.tcp_dsack = 1
net.ipv4.tcp_sack = 1
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter fast_start_mttr_target
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Relaxing aggressive checkpointing prevents outliers and improves performance.



    Risk:

    Too small of a value results in aggresive checkpoint rates, uneven and reduced performance.



    Action / Repair:

    Check that its set and not less than 300.

    NOTE: you must disable or remove the FAST_START_IO_TARGET, LOG_CHECKPOINT_INTERVAL, and LOG_CHECKPOINT_TIMEOUT initialization parameters when using FAST_START_MTTR_TARGET. Setting these parameters interferes with the mechanisms used to manage cache recovery time to meet FAST_START_MTTR_TARGET.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => fast_start_mttr_target is greater than or equal to 300
    whexa3p31.fast_start_mttr_target = 3600
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => fast_start_mttr_target is greater than or equal to 300
    whexa3p33.fast_start_mttr_target = 3600
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => fast_start_mttr_target is greater than or equal to 300
    whexa3p32.fast_start_mttr_target = 3600
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter undo_retention
    


    

    Recommendation
    Oracle Flashback Technology enables fast logical failure repair. Oracle recommends that you use automatic undo management with sufficient space to attain your desired undo retention guarantee, enable Oracle Flashback Database, and allocate sufficient space and I/O bandwidth in the fast recovery area.  Application monitoring is required for early detection.  Effective and fast repair comes from leveraging and rehearsing the most common application specific logical failures and using the different flashback features effectively (e.g flashback query, flashback version query, flashback transaction query, flashback transaction, flashback drop, flashback table, and flashback database, and 12.2 flashback pluggable database (PDB)).

    Key HA Benefits:

    • With application monitoring and rehearsed repair actions with flashback technologies, application downtime can reduce from hours and days to the time to detect the logical inconsistency.

    • Fast repair for logical failures caused by malicious or accidental DML or DDL operations.

    • Effect fast point-in-time repair at the appropriate level of granularity: transaction, table, pluggable database, or database.

    Questions that need to be addressed by your application and operations team:

    1. Can your application or monitoring infrastructure detect logical inconsistencies?

    2. Is your operations team prepared to use various flashback technologies to repair quickly and efficiently?

    3. Is security practices enforced to prevent unauthorized privileges that can result logical inconsistencies?

    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter UNDO_RETENTION on PRIMARY is not null
    whexa3p31.undo_retention = 900
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter UNDO_RETENTION on PRIMARY is not null
    whexa3p33.undo_retention = 900
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter UNDO_RETENTION on PRIMARY is not null
    whexa3p32.undo_retention = 900
    


    Hide

    Hide
    


    Flashback database on primary
    


    

    Recommendation
    Oracle Flashback Technology enables fast logical failure repair. Oracle recommends that you use automatic undo management with sufficient space to attain your desired undo retention guarantee, enable Oracle Flashback Database, and allocate sufficient space and I/O bandwidth in the fast recovery area.  Application monitoring is required for early detection.  Effective and fast repair comes from leveraging and rehearsing the most common application specific logical failures and using the different flashback features effectively (e.g flashback query, flashback version query, flashback transaction query, flashback transaction, flashback drop, flashback table, and flashback database, and 12.2 flashback pluggable database (PDB)).

    Key HA Benefits:

    • With application monitoring and rehearsed repair actions with flashback technologies, application downtime can reduce from hours and days to the time to detect the logical inconsistency.

    • Fast repair for logical failures caused by malicious or accidental DML or DDL operations.

    • Effect fast point-in-time repair at the appropriate level of granularity: transaction, table, pluggable database, or database.

    Questions that need to be addressed by your application and operations team:

    1. Can your application or monitoring infrastructure detect logical inconsistencies?

    2. Is your operations team prepared to use various flashback technologies to repair quickly and efficiently?

    3. Is security practices enforced to prevent unauthorized privileges that can result logical inconsistencies?

    

    Links
    1.  HABP: Chapter 5.1.4: Enable Flashback Database in 11gR2 
    

    Needs attention onwhexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Flashback on primary is not configured
    'FLASHBACKSTATUS='||UPPER(FLASHBACK_ON) 
--------------------------------------- 
Flashback status = NO

    


    Hide
    


    Verify diskgroup attributes are set to enable Hardware Assisted Resilient Data (HARD) capability
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    There are specific diskgroup attributes that allow the detection of a extent mismatch between the partners during a rebalance operation. When a valid copy is found on any of the mirrors, it is used to repair the invalid copy, keeping the consistency of the data.

    Risk:

    An incorrect setting of diskgroup attributes will disable HARD check detection during rebalance operations. When a corrupted block is found it could be moved to any of the mirrors, potentially replacing a valid copy. The higher the number of rebalance operations, the higher the chance to loose all the valid block copies.

    Action / Repair:

    The correct diskgroup attribute values vary by software version level. Exachk runs the appropriate checks based upon the discovered environment configuration. To verify diskgroup attributes are set to enable Hardware Assisted Resilient Data (HARD) capability, run Exachk and review the provided report.

    NOTE: This best practice will only succeed if all the following are true:
    For grid version series 12 or 18:
    Attribute Name 	Value
    content.check 	FALSE
    hard_check.enabled 	TRUE

    For grid version 19 or higher:
    Attribute Name 	Value
    content.check 	TRUE
    hard_check.enabled 	TRUE 

    The expected output in the Exachk report should be as follows:

    In the "Findings Passed" summary section of the report, the overall result should be "PASS":

    PASS   OS Check   All diskgroup attributes are set to enable Hardware Assisted Resilient Data (HARD) capability   All Database Servers   View

    In the "View" detail section of the report for each individual database server:

    Status on randomadm01:
    PASS => All diskgroup attributes are set to enable Hardware Assisted Resilient Data (HARD) capability

    DATA FROM RANDOMADM01 FOR VERIFY DISKGROUP ATTRIBUTES ARE SET TO ENABLE HARDWARE ASSISTED RESILIENT DATA (HARD) CAPABILITY

    SUCCESS: Diskgroups have the correct values for HARD check attributes

    A "FAIL" result view detail example:

    Status on randomadm01:
    CRITICAL => One or more diskgroup attributes are not set to enable Hardware Assisted Resilient Data (HARD) capability

    DATA FROM RANDOMADM01 FOR VERIFY DISKGROUP ATTRIBUTES ARE SET TO ENABLE HARDWARE ASSISTED RESILIENT DATA (HARD) CAPABILITY

    For Grid Infrastructure version 19 or higher, the expected values are:
    content.check TRUE ; hidden attribute hard_check.enabled TRUE

    FAILURE: Diskgroup DATAC1 have incorrect attributes. Please review the list: content.check: FALSE hard_check.enable: TRUE
    FAILURE: Diskgroup RECOC1 have incorrect attributes. Please review the list: content.check: FALSE hard_check.enable: TRUE
    IMPORTANT: Incorrect set of attributes could cause ASM rebalance not detecting HARD check violations (corrupted blocks)
               This will spread corruption through the mirrored cells, leading to complete data corruption

    If a "FAILURE:" result is returned, refer to the appropriate version specific documentation to set the attributes as recommended.

        NOTE: If after corrective actions are completed you wish to run just this check without a full Exachk run, execute the following as the root userid:

        exachk -check B01200FAD7E0711CE053D498EB0AD42C
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => All diskgroup attributes are set to enable Hardware Assisted Resilient Data (HARD) capability
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY DISKGROUP ATTRIBUTES ARE SET TO ENABLE HARDWARE ASSISTED RESILIENT DATA (HARD) CAPABILITY 



SUCCESS: Diskgroups have the expected values for HARD check attributes
    


    Hide
    


    Verify RoCE Interfaces Status [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    For maximum throughput and protection, all available RoCE interfaces on the database and storage servers should have a state of "UP".

    Risk:

    Not having all RoCE interfaces "UP" may lead to reduced performance and introduce single points of failure.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify RoCE Interfaces Status, as the "root" userid, execute the following on each database and storage server:

    #gather data
    RAW_DATA=$(ip addr | egrep "re[[:digit:]]:|re[[:digit:]]pf" | egrep -v "inet")
    UP_INTERFACES=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    UP_INTRFCE_CNT=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep -c "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    BAD_INTERFACES=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep -v "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    BAD_INTRFCE_CNT=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep -cv "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    #analyze data
    if [[ $BAD_INTRFCE_CNT -gt 0 ]]
    then
      echo -e "FAILURE:  one or more RoCE interfaces had a state other than \"UP\".  Details:\n$BAD_INTERFACES"
    else
      echo -e "SUCCESS: $UP_INTRFCE_CNT RoCE interfaces had a state of \"UP\""
    fi

    The expected output should be similar to the following:

    SUCCESS: 4 RoCE interfaces had a state of "UP"

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE:  one or more RoCE interfaces had a state other than "UP".  Details:
    19: re1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 2300 qdisc mq state DOWN group default qlen 1000
    24: re6: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 2300 qdisc mq state DOWN group default qlen 1000

    If a "FAILURE" result is returned, investigate for root cause and take corrective action. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => All RoCE interfaces have a status of "UP"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY ROCE INTERFACES STATUS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: 2 RoCE interfaces had a state of "UP"
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => All RoCE interfaces have a status of "UP"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY ROCE INTERFACES STATUS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: 2 RoCE interfaces had a state of "UP"
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => All RoCE interfaces have a status of "UP"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY ROCE INTERFACES STATUS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: 2 RoCE interfaces had a state of "UP"
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Exadata Smart Flash Log is Created
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    When created, Exadata Smart Flash Log uses 512MB of flash memory per storage server by default to help minimize redo log write latency.

    The impact of verifying that Exadata Smart Flash Log is created is minimal.



    Risk:

    Without Exadata Smart Flash Log, the LGWR process may be delayed causing longer "log file parallel write" and "log file sync" waits.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify that Exadata Smart Flash Log is created, execute the following cellcli command as the "celladmin" user on each storage server:

    list flashlog attributes size,status

    The output should be similar to:

        512M    normal

    If the size is not as expected, Exadata Smart Flash Log may not be created, or there may be a hardware issue, or there may be a configuration issue.

    It is extremely important that the root cause for the size not being as expected is understood before attempting corrective action. Because Smart Flash Log and Smart Flash Cache share the same physical memory structure on the storage servers, both are likely to be impacted by hardware failures, for example. Corrective action is also impacted by whether or not Write Back Flash Cache is in use, and solutions for the same root cause may vary if Write Back Flash Cache is in use.

    After determining the root cause, refer to the Database Machine Owner's Guide and the Exadata Software User's Guide for the appropriate corrective action steps.

    Because they share the same storage server physical flash memory, there is a space usage relationship between Exadata Smart Flash Log and Exadata Smart Flash Cache. Exadata Smart Flash Log should be created before Exadata Smart Flash Cache, because the default configuration for Exadata Smart Flash Cache will use all available storage server flash memory. If Exadata Smart Flash Cache already exists, a subsequent attempt to create Exadata Smart Flash Log will fail because all the available storage server flash memory is in use.

        NOTE: Exadata Smart Flash Log is created by default with Exadata Storage Server Software version 11.2.2.4.0 and above.

        NOTE: Exadata Smart Flash Log will be used by Oracle software 11.2.0.2 Bundle Patch 9 (or higher) or 11.2.0.3.0. The recommended Oracle software version levels are 11.2.0.2 Bundle Patch 11 (or higher) or 11.2.0.3 Bundle Patch 1 (or higher).

        NOTE: The default Exadata Smart Flash Log size of 512MB is the recommended value.

        NOTE: On storage servers that use only flash memory devices(no spinning disks), the Exadata Smart Flash Cache size is the same whether or not Exadata Smart Flash Log is created. Therefore, the order in which Exadata Smart Flash Log and Exadata Smart Flash Cache are created does not matter. 

        NOTE: See also "Verify Exadata Smart Flash Cache is Created" 
    

    Needs attention onexa3celadm04
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm04:
    CRITICAL => Smart flash log is not created on one or more storage server
    DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify Exadata Smart Flash Log is Created 


	 name:                   exa3celadm04_FLASHLOG
	 cellDisk:               FD_03_exa3celadm04,FD_00_exa3celadm04,FD_01_exa3celadm04
	 creationTime:           2020-09-15T03:10:39+02:00
	 degradedCelldisks:      FD_02_exa3celadm04
	 effectiveSize:          384M
	 efficiency:             100.0
	 id:                     ae31f84b-b755-4683-83f8-dfa7a2fa47c8
	 size:                   512M
	 status:                 warning - degraded

DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify Exadata Smart Flash Log is Created 


	 name:                   exa3celadm01_FLASHLOG
	 cellDisk:               FD_01_exa3celadm01,FD_03_exa3celadm01,FD_02_exa3celadm01,FD_00_exa3celadm01
	 creationTime:           2020-09-15T03:09:57+02:00
	 degradedCelldisks:      
	 effectiveSize:          512M
	 efficiency:             100.0
	 id:                     3691a471-42ac-40fd-a535-f598d865168c
	 size:                   512M
	 status:                 normal

	 cellDisk:               FD_01_exa3celadm02,FD_03_exa3celadm02,FD_02_exa3celadm02,FD_00_exa3celadm02
	 creationTime:           2020-09-15T03:10:24+02:00

    	 degradedCelldisks:

	 size:                   512M

	 cellDisk:               FD_03_exa3celadm03,FD_02_exa3celadm03,FD_00_exa3celadm03,FD_01_exa3celadm03
	 creationTime:           2020-09-15T03:10:27+02:00
	 degradedCelldisks:      
	 effectiveSize:          512M
	 efficiency:             100.0
	 id:                     a80ff11a-45ce-4d8c-8291-935f7898af2b
	 size:                   512M
	 status:                 normal

    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03:
    PASS => Smart flash log is not created on one or more storage server
