    Verify Storage Server Hidden Parameter Usage
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Hidden storage server parameters are typically set as a workaround to solve a specific problem, and should be removed once a system has been upgraded to a version level that contains the fix for the specific problem. Often they are not removed during the upgrade process to the version level that contains the correct fix. Verifying the hidden storage server parameter usage helps avoid hidden parameters being used any longer than necessary.

        NOTE: In some future version, the upgrade process for Exadata Storage Server software will remove unacceptable hidden storage server parameters.

    Risk:

    Use of hidden storage server parameters not recommended by Oracle development in an Exadata environment can cause instability, performance problems, corruptions, and crashes.

    Action / Repair:

    Exachk contains current data on acceptable storage server parameters. Run Exachk and observe the result.

    The expected output in the Exachk report should be as follows:

    In the "Findings Passed" summary section of the report, the overall result should be "PASS":

    PASS   OS Check   No unacceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered   All Storage Servers   View

    In the "View" detail section of the report for each individual storage server:

    Status on random01celadm01:
    PASS => No unacceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered

    DATA FROM RANDOM01CELADM01 FOR VERIFY STORAGE SERVER HIDDEN PARAMETER USAGE

    SUCCESS: 2 acceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered.  Details:
    _cell_ramcache_mode=On
    _cell_fc_persistence_state=WriteBack

    A "FAIL" result view detail example:

    Status on random01celadm02:
    FAIL => one or more unacceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered

    DATA FROM RANDOM01CELADM02 FOR VERIFY STORAGE SERVER HIDDEN PARAMETER USAGE

    FAILURE: one or more unacceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered.  Details:
    _cellrsdef_max_auto_timeout=6
    _cellrsos_max_auto_timeout=6
    _cellrsdef_heartbeat_timeout=6
    _alert_for_ms_internal_error=true
    _cellrsos_heartbeat_timeout=6

        NOTE: If after corrective actions are completed you wish to run just this check without a full Exachk run, execute the following:

        ./exachk -check AF70591C902FC534E053D498EB0AD8BC,AF70591C9039C534E053D498EB0AD8BC

    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => No unacceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify Storage Server Hidden Parameter Usage 


SUCCESS: 1 acceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered.  Details:
_cell_fc_persistence_state=WriteBack

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify Storage Server Hidden Parameter Usage 


SUCCESS: 1 acceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered.  Details:
_cell_fc_persistence_state=WriteBack

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify Storage Server Hidden Parameter Usage 


SUCCESS: 1 acceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered.  Details:
_cell_fc_persistence_state=WriteBack

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify Storage Server Hidden Parameter Usage 

    

SUCCESS: 1 acceptable storage server hidden parameters were discovered.  Details:
_cell_fc_persistence_state=WriteBack

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify RoCE Interfaces Status [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    For maximum throughput and protection, all available RoCE interfaces on the database and storage servers should have a state of "UP".

    Risk:

    Not having all RoCE interfaces "UP" may lead to reduced performance and introduce single points of failure.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify RoCE Interfaces Status, as the "root" userid, execute the following on each database and storage server:

    #gather data
    RAW_DATA=$(ip addr | egrep "re[[:digit:]]:|re[[:digit:]]pf" | egrep -v "inet")
    UP_INTERFACES=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    UP_INTRFCE_CNT=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep -c "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    BAD_INTERFACES=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep -v "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    BAD_INTRFCE_CNT=$(echo "$RAW_DATA" | egrep -cv "[[:space:]]UP[[:space:]]")
    #analyze data
    if [[ $BAD_INTRFCE_CNT -gt 0 ]]
    then
      echo -e "FAILURE:  one or more RoCE interfaces had a state other than \"UP\".  Details:\n$BAD_INTERFACES"
    else
      echo -e "SUCCESS: $UP_INTRFCE_CNT RoCE interfaces had a state of \"UP\""
    fi

    The expected output should be similar to the following:

    SUCCESS: 4 RoCE interfaces had a state of "UP"

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE:  one or more RoCE interfaces had a state other than "UP".  Details:
    19: re1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 2300 qdisc mq state DOWN group default qlen 1000
    24: re6: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 2300 qdisc mq state DOWN group default qlen 1000

    If a "FAILURE" result is returned, investigate for root cause and take corrective action. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => All RoCE interfaces have a status of "UP"
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify RoCE Interfaces Status [Storage Server]

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify RoCE Interfaces Status [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS: 2 RoCE interfaces had a state of "UP"

    


    Hide
    


    Database init parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKING on primary
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Initially db_block_checking is set to off due to potential performance impact. Performance testing is particularly important given that overhead is incurred on every block change. Block checking typically causes 1% to 10% overhead, but for update and insert intensive applications (such as Redo Apply at a standby database) the overhead can be much higher. OLTP compressed tables also require additional checks that can result in higher overhead depending on the frequency of updates to those tables. Workload specific testing is required to assess whether the performance overhead is acceptable.



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    Based on performance testing results set the primary or standby database to either medium or full depending on the impact. If performance concerns prevent setting DB_BLOCK_CHECKING to either FULL or MEDIUM at a primary database, then it becomes even more important to enable this at the standby database. This protects the standby database from logical corruption that would be undetected at the primary database.
    For higher data corruption detection and prevention, enable this setting but performance impacts vary per workload.Evaluate performance impact.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1302539.1 - Best Practices for Corruption Detection, Prevention, and Automatic Repair - in a Data Guard Configuration
    2.  Protect Against Data Corruption 
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKING on primary is not set to the recommended value.
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Database init parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKING on primary 



DB_BLOCK_CHECKING = FALSE
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKING on primary is not set to the recommended value.
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Database init parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKING on primary 



DB_BLOCK_CHECKING = FALSE
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKING on primary is not set to the recommended value.
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Database init parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKING on primary 



DB_BLOCK_CHECKING = FALSE
    


    Hide
    


    Older CVU trace files needing deletion
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Filesystem maintenance to minimize space usage



    Risk:

    Oracle 11.2 contains automations for the cycling and purging of most log/trace files but in some cases manual cleanup is required. Known cases are:
    CRS_HOME/cv/log and ORACLE_HOME/cv/log - log files may not be cleaned up
    CRS_HOME/cdata - some old OCR backups may not be removed, thereby needing manual cleanup



    Action / Repair:

    Manually remove older log or trace files from 

    CRS_HOME/cv/log
    ORACLE_HOME/cv/log
    CRS_HOME/cdata
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => NO old CVU log files found in $CRS_HOME/cv/log
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - OLDER CVU TRACE FILES NEEDING DELETION 




Number of cvutrace.log files last modified more than 15 days ago =  0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => NO old CVU log files found in $CRS_HOME/cv/log
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - OLDER CVU TRACE FILES NEEDING DELETION 




Number of cvutrace.log files last modified more than 15 days ago =  0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => NO old CVU log files found in $CRS_HOME/cv/log
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - OLDER CVU TRACE FILES NEEDING DELETION 




Number of cvutrace.log files last modified more than 15 days ago =  0

    Verify imageinfo on storage server
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The imageinfo output should match across storage cells, with the possible exception that the 'Cell boot usb partition:' may be reported as sdmn, where m is a character and n is a number.  The output should also make sense for the deployment and upgrade history
    of the cluster. 



    Risk:

    If the output particularly the version does not match then the cells might not have been patched correctly or are not on the same version 



    Action / Repair:

    The output is below for imageinfo

    --
    imageinfo

    Kernel version: 2.6.18-194.3.1.0.3.el5 #1 SMP Tue Aug 31 22:41:13 EDT 2010 x86_6                                                                                                                               4
    Cell version: OSS_11.2.0.3.0_LINUX.X64_101206.2
    Cell rpm version: cell-11.2.2.2.0_LINUX.X64_101206.2-1

    Active image version: 11.2.2.2.0.101206.2
    Active image activated: 2011-03-07 10:38:52 -0800
    Active image status: success
    Active system partition on device: /dev/md5
    Active software partition on device: /dev/md7

    In partition rollback: Impossible

    Cell boot usb partition: /dev/sdac1
    Cell boot usb version: 11.2.2.2.0.101206.2

    Inactive image version: undefined
    Rollback to the inactive partitions: Impossible
    --
    The active version needs to match on all the Oracle Storage Servers otherwise the patching needs to be revisited 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1662018.1 - Oracle Sun Database Machine Cross Node Consistency Best Practice Checks
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => imageinfo version matches on all storage servers
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify imageinfo on storage server 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify imageinfo on storage server 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify imageinfo on storage server 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify imageinfo on storage server 


20.1.1.0.0.200808

    


    Hide
    


    Verify Proper ASM Failure Group Configuration
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    ASM Failure groups are used to place mirrored copies of data so that each copy is on a disk in a different failure group so that the simultaneous failure of all disks in a failure group does not result in data loss. On Exadata, by default, all grid disks in a single Exadata Storage Server (or cell) belong to the same failure group to tolerate the failure of a single storage server. 

    Risk:

    If a single storage server contains grid disks for a disk group that reside in more than one failure group, then it is possible for the disk group to be taken offline, causing the database to crash, if that single storage server is taken offline (e.g. for planned maintenance) or fails.

    In a rare circumstance, systems with 11.2.0.2 BP6 installed, but missing required overlay patch 12530803 (as documented in Support Note 888828.1), can have ASM disks in a disk group mistakenly added back into an incorrect failure group automatically, thus causing the grid disks for a disk group in one storage server to belong to more than one failure group. 



    Action / Repair:

    To verify the proper ASM failure group configuration, run Exachk and examine the HTML report. The expected output is for the check to pass. If the check passes, no action is required.

    If the check fails, following the manual corrective instructions in: Document 1351036.1. Re-run Exachk after the manual repairs to validate that the check passes. 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1351036.1 - Validate and Fix Proper ASM Failure Group Configuration on Oracle Exadata Database Machine
    2.  Note: 787205.1 - Setting up DCLI Utility on Oracle DB host
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => The ASM failure group configuration is as recommended
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY PROPER ASM FAILURE GROUP CONFIGURATION

Model:Oracle Corporation ORACLE SERVER X8-2L High Capacity
Cell :exa3celadm03

Cell :exa3celadm02

     [OK] For this Grid disk: RECO_EXA3  have correct number of grid disks for Failgroup: EXA3CELADM02
 [OK] For this Grid disk: RECO_EXA3  have correct number of grid disks for Failgroup: EXA3CELADM03
 [OK] For this Grid disk: RECO_EXA3  have correct number of grid disks for Failgroup: EXA3CELADM04

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify storage server metric CD_IO_ST_RQ
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Under certain rare conditions, an underperforming conventional or flash disk may not be proactively dropped. This condition results in a severe performance impact. The storage server metric "CD_IO_ST_RQ" over the past hour is a reliable indicator of this condition. If "CD_IO_ST_RQ" is found greater than or equal to 300000 microseconds for conventional disks or 100000 microseconds for flash devices over the last hour, investigate further.

    There is minimal impact to verify the storage server metric "CD_IO_ST_RQ". If found, an underperforming device may need to be scheduled for replacement.

    Risk:

    If the underperforming device is not proactively dropped, or found by verifying the storage server metric "CD_IO_ST_RQ", performance will be sub-optimal. 

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that the storage server metric CD_IO_ST_RQ is below the target value, execute the following command set as the "root" userid on each storage server:

    ct=$(cellcli -e list metriccurrent CL_TEMP attributes collectionTime | awk -F"\\t" '{print $2}');
    dt=$(echo "${ct}" | cut -dT -f1);
    hr=$(echo "${ct}" | cut -dT -f2);
    hh=$(echo ${hr} | cut -d: -f1);
    mm=$(echo ${hr} | cut -d: -f2);
    tzss=$(echo ${hr} | cut -d: -f4);
    tzmm=$(echo ${hr} | cut -d: -f3);
    if [ $hh > "00" ]; 
      then hh=$(expr $hh - 1);
    else 
      hh=0;
      mm=0;
    fi;
    lht=$(printf " %sT%02d:%02d:%s:%s\\n" ${dt} ${hh} ${mm} ${tzmm} ${tzss} );
    cd=$(cellcli -e "list metrichistory CD_IO_ST_RQ where metricObjectName like 'CD.*' and collectionTime > '$lht' and metricValue > 300000");
    fd=$(cellcli -e "list metrichistory CD_IO_ST_RQ where metricObjectName like 'FD.*' and collectionTime > '$lht' and metricValue > 100000");
    nl=$(echo -e "Poor performing disks\\n$cd$fd" |wc -l);
    if [ $nl -gt 2 ]; 
      then echo -e "\nFAILURE: flash or hard disks were found with metric CD_IO_ST_RQ beyond target value:\n\n$cd\n$fd";
    else 
      echo -e "\nSUCCESS: no flash or hard disks were found with metric CD_IO_ST_RQ beyond target value.";
    fi;

    The expected output should be:

    SUCCESS: no flash or hard disks were found with metric CD_IO_ST_RQ beyond target value.

    If the output returned is similar to:

    FAILURE: flash or hard disks were found with metric CD_IO_ST_RQ beyond target value:

             CD_IO_ST_RQ     CD_00_randomcel05       30,918 us/request        2015-03-18T08:27:26-06:00
             CD_IO_ST_RQ     CD_01_randomcel05       30,666 us/request        2015-03-18T08:27:26-06:00
             <sample output truncated>
             CD_IO_ST_RQ     CD_10_randomcel05       30,806 us/request        2015-03-18T08:27:26-06:00
             CD_IO_ST_RQ     CD_11_randomcel05       30,272 us/request        2015-03-18T08:27:26-06:00

    Investigate the status and performance of the devices listed, and correct any issues discovered.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => No flash or hard disks were found with metric CD_IO_ST_RQ beyond target value
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify storage server metric CD_IO_ST_RQ 





DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify storage server metric CD_IO_ST_RQ 





DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify storage server metric CD_IO_ST_RQ 





DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify storage server metric CD_IO_ST_RQ 

    




    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    High Redundancy Redolog files
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal. The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact. 



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 



    Action / Repair:

    Ensure the db_create_online_log_dest_n is configured for a high redundancy diskgroup

    A high redundancy diskgroup optimizes availability.

    If a high redundancy disk group is available, use the first high ASM redundancy disk group for all your Online Redo Logs or Standby Redo Logs. Use only one log member to minimize performance impact.

    If a high redundancy disk group is not available, multiplex redo log members across DATA and RECO ASM disk groups for additional protection.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter Db_create_online_log_dest_n is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - High Redundancy Redolog files 



High redundancy disk groups = 0

Number of redo log groups with more than 1 member = 12

Number of diskgroup where redo log members are multiplexed = 2
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter Db_create_online_log_dest_n is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - High Redundancy Redolog files 



High redundancy disk groups = 0

Number of redo log groups with more than 1 member = 12

Number of diskgroup where redo log members are multiplexed = 2
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter Db_create_online_log_dest_n is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - High Redundancy Redolog files 



High redundancy disk groups = 0

Number of redo log groups with more than 1 member = 12

Number of diskgroup where redo log members are multiplexed = 2
    


    Hide
    


    Check for COMPATIBLE
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal. The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact. 



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 



    Action / Repair:

    Set database parameter COMPATIBLE to current RDBMS version in use out to the fourth digit (ex: 11.2.0.2).
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3

    db_recovery_file_dest_size
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal. The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact. 



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 



    Action / Repair:

    Ensure db_recovery_file_dest_size <= 90% of the Recovery Area diskgroup TOTAL_MB size
    

    Needs attention on-

    Processes parameter for ASM instance
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain ASM initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these ASM initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The parameters are specific to the ASM instances. Unless otherwise specified, the value is for both X2-2 and X2-8 Database Machines. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal. 



    Risk:

    If the ASM initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value. 



    Action / Repair:

    This avoids issues observed when ASM hits max # of processes.
    For < 10 instances per node, set processes=1024

    For >= 10 instances per node,set processes using the following formula

    MAX((50*MIN(db_instances_per_node+1,11))+(10*MAX(db_instances_per_node-10,0)),1024)

    This new formula accommodates the consolidation case where there are a lot of instances per node.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1274318.1 - Oracle Sun Database Machine X2-2 Setup/Configuration Best Practices (Doc ID 1274318.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => ASM processes parameter is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - PROCESSES PARAMETER FOR ASM INSTANCE 



Processes parameter set on +ASM1 = 1024 
Number of RDBMS instances running = 1
Recommended value for Processes parameter for +ASM1 = 1024
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => ASM processes parameter is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - PROCESSES PARAMETER FOR ASM INSTANCE 



Processes parameter set on +ASM3 = 1024 
Number of RDBMS instances running = 1
Recommended value for Processes parameter for +ASM3 = 1024
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:+ASM2:
    PASS => ASM processes parameter is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - PROCESSES PARAMETER FOR ASM INSTANCE 



Processes parameter set on +ASM2 = 1024 
Number of RDBMS instances running = 1
Recommended value for Processes parameter for +ASM2 = 1024
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Oracle Database instances communication uses the Private Network
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The private network (either RDMA Network Fabric or RoCE) in an Oracle Exadata Database Machine provides superior performance and throughput characteristics that allow Oracle Clusterware, ASM, and databases to operate at optimal efficiency. 
    The private interconnect used by database instances, available in the v$cluster_interconnects view, should match both the IP addresses configured on the private network interfaces.

    NOTE: Properly configuring the Exadata environment to use the private network avoids using the Clusterware HAIP address which is not supported on Exadata. HAIP was disabled during deployment time in OEDA version 12.1.2.4 for all versions (bug 23627471) and is disabled automatically on Exadata by CRS scripts in GI version 12.2 (bug 24420871).

    Risk:

    If a database instance does not use the private network for communication between cluster nodes, performance will be sub-optimal and service blackouts may occur, especially during internal network failures or planned maintenance.

    Action / Repair:

    If the v$cluster_interconnects IP_ADDRESS column contains IP addresses different than the Exadata private network interfaces (returned by "/sbin/ip show address" command), check for misconfiguration in the following two areas:
    1) CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS database initialization parameter and 
    2) oifcfg getif for cluster interconnect. 
    Ideally the CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS initialization parameter should not be set and automatically uses the private network interfaces identified by the Clusterware. If the CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS initialization parameter is set, the check ensures the parameter is set to the correct value.

    Once the issue has been resolved, this audit check can be invoked individually as root user as follows:

        # exachk -check AA53138B0B7E3B86E040E50A1EC07003

    

    Links
    1.  Note: 2353240.1 - Exachk - Database parameter CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS is not set to the recommended value (Doc ID 2353240.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS is set to the recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify Oracle Database instances communication uses the Private Network 



1) Cluster Interconnect Value from instance:
 100.66.132.43 100.66.132.44 

3) Network card name and IP address from oifcfg:  
re0 = 100.66.132.43 
re1 = 100.66.132.44
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS is set to the recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify Oracle Database instances communication uses the Private Network 



1) Cluster Interconnect Value from instance:
 100.66.132.47 100.66.132.48 

3) Network card name and IP address from oifcfg:  
re0 = 100.66.132.47 
re1 = 100.66.132.48
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS is set to the recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify Oracle Database instances communication uses the Private Network 



1) Cluster Interconnect Value from instance:
 100.66.132.45 100.66.132.46 

3) Network card name and IP address from oifcfg:  
re0 = 100.66.132.45 
re1 = 100.66.132.46
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Oracle ASM instances communication uses the Private Network
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The private network (either RDMA Network Fabric or RoCE) in an Oracle Exadata Database Machine provides superior performance and throughput characteristics that allow Oracle Clusterware, ASM, and databases to operate at optimal efficiency. 
    The private interconnect used by ASM instances, available in the v$cluster_interconnects view, should match both the ip addresses configured on the private network interfaces.

    NOTE: Properly configuring the Exadata environment to use the private network avoids using the Clusterware HAIP address which is not supported on Exadata. HAIP was disabled during deployment time in OEDA version 12.1.2.4 for all versions (bug 23627471) and is disabled automatically on Exadata by CRS scripts in GI version 12.2 (bug 24420871).

    Risk:

    If an ASM instance does not use the private network for communication between cluster nodes, performance will be sub-optimal and service blackouts may occur, especially during internal network failures or planned maintenance.

    Action / Repair:

    If the v$cluster_interconnects IP_ADDRESS column contains IP addresses different than the Exadata private network interfaces (returned by "/sbin/ip show address" command), check for misconfiguration in the following two areas:
    1) CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS database initialization parameter and 
    2) oifcfg getif for cluster interconnect. 
    Ideally the CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS initialization parameter should not be set and automatically uses the private network interfaces identified by the Clusterware. If the CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS initialization parameter is set, the check ensures the parameter is set to the correct value.

    Once the issue has been resolved, this audit check can be invoked individually as root user as follows:

        # exachk -check AA53138B0B7D3B86E040E50A1EC07003

    

    Links
    1.  Note: 2353240.1 - Exachk - Database parameter CLUSTER_INTERCONNECTS is not set to the recommended value (Doc ID 2353240.1)

    Check for parameter sql92_security
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized.
    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal.
    The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    SQL92_SECURITY = TRUE is a security optimization
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter sql92_security is set to recommended value
    whexa3p31.sql92_security = TRUE
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter sql92_security is set to recommended value
    whexa3p33.sql92_security = TRUE
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter sql92_security is set to recommended value
    whexa3p32.sql92_security = TRUE
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter use_large_pages
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Benefits: Memory savings and reduce paging and swapping

    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    USE_LARGE_PAGES = ONLY ensures the entire SGA is stored in hugepages for Linux based systems only.

    NOTE: Please refer to My Oracle Support notes 401749.1, 361323.1, and 1392497.1 in the Links section for additional details on configuring hugepages.

    NOTE: If you have not reviewed My Oracle Support notes 401749.1, 361323.1, and 1392497.1 and followed their guidance BEFORE using the database parameter "use_large_pages=only", this check will pass the environment but you will still not be able to start instances once the configured pool of operating system hugepages have been consumed by instance startups. If that should happen, you will need to change the "use_large_pages" initialization parameter to one of the other values, restart the instance, and follow the instructions in My Oracle Support notes 401749.1 and 361323.1. The brute force alternative is to increase the huge page count until the newest instance will start, and then adjust the huge page count after you can see the estimated requirements for all currently active SGAs.

    NOTE: While it is possible to modify the number of hugepages in active memory in the running kernel, it is not recommended for two reasons:
    1) The hugepages pool must be contiguous, and it may not be possible to find enough contiguous pages to meet a request in the running kernel active memory.
    2) Setting the value in the kernel configuration files and rebooting ensures the expected number of hugepages is properly configured and available. Misconfigurations in this area can impact server availability so following this operational best practice prevents an unexpected outage caused by user error.

    NOTE: With the fix for bug 32498459, the Oracle database will enforce the use of large pages regardless of the setting of this parameter when the SGA is 32GB or higher. Release 19.12 and 21.3 include this fix.

    NOTE: After applying DBRU 19.27 or DBRU 23.8, small pages are not allowed for the SGA in Exadata. Please refer to My Oracle Support note 3081878.1 in the Links section for additional details on this change.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1392497.1 - USE_LARGE_PAGES To Enable HugePages (Doc ID 1392497.1)
    2.  Note: 3081878.1 - Starting DBRU 19.27 and 23.8 Small Pages Are Not Allowed for RDBMS SGA In Exadata.
    3.  Note: 361323.1 - HugePages on Linux: What It Is... and What It Is Not...
    4.  Note: 401749.1 - Shell Script to Calculate Values Recommended Linux HugePages / HugeTLB
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter USE_LARGE_PAGES is set to recommended value
    whexa3p31.use_large_pages = ONLY
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter USE_LARGE_PAGES is set to recommended value
    whexa3p33.use_large_pages = ONLY
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter USE_LARGE_PAGES is set to recommended value
    whexa3p32.use_large_pages = ONLY
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter os_authent_prefix
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized.
    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal.
    The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    OS_AUTHENT_PREFIX =  is a security optimization (ie., null string)

    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check A98AC77CA837A489E040E50A1EC014A6".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair A98AC77CA837A489E040E50A1EC014A6".
    

    Links
    1.  Setting OS_AUTHENT_PREFIX to a Null Value 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter OS_AUTHENT_PREFIX is set to recommended value
    whexa3p31.os_authent_prefix = 
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter OS_AUTHENT_PREFIX is set to recommended value
    whexa3p33.os_authent_prefix = 
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter OS_AUTHENT_PREFIX is set to recommended value
    whexa3p32.os_authent_prefix = 
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter parallel_threads_per_cpu
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized.
    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal.
    The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    PARALLEL_THREADS_PER_CPU = 1 properly accounts for hyper threading

    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check A98A14A7D1CB386DE040E50A1EC01EBD".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair A98A14A7D1CB386DE040E50A1EC01EBD".
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1274318.1 - Oracle Sun Database Machine X2-2 Setup/Configuration Best Practices (Doc ID 1274318.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter PARALLEL_THREADS_PER_CPU is set to recommended value
    whexa3p31.parallel_threads_per_cpu = 1
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter PARALLEL_THREADS_PER_CPU is set to recommended value
    whexa3p33.parallel_threads_per_cpu = 1
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter PARALLEL_THREADS_PER_CPU is set to recommended value
    whexa3p32.parallel_threads_per_cpu = 1
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter db_lost_write_protect
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized.
    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal.
    The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    This is important for data block lost write detection and repair. Enable for
    primary and standby databases.

    See referenced MOS notes for more info.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1265884.1 - Resolving ORA-752 or ORA-600 [3020] During Standby Recovery
    2.  Note: 1302539.1 - Best Practices for Corruption Detection, Prevention, and Automatic Repair - in a Data Guard Configuration
    3.  Protect Against Data Corruption 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_LOST_WRITE_PROTECT is set to recommended value
    whexa3p31.db_lost_write_protect = typical
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_LOST_WRITE_PROTECT is set to recommended value
    whexa3p33.db_lost_write_protect = typical
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_LOST_WRITE_PROTECT is set to recommended value
    whexa3p32.db_lost_write_protect = typical
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue DB47
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to 
    performance or availability. 

    Risk:

    Due to bug 31228670, a lost write may occur if, while a database instance remains up, a disk is taken offline (due to planned maintenance or an unplanned event), brought back online, and then again taken offline due to a write error.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue DB47 in below MOS note 1270094.1. 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue DB47

ASM RECO_EXA3.compatible.rdbms = 12.1.0.2
/u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid has the patch for bug 31228670
/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 has the patch for bug 31228670

    Exadata Critical Issue EX62
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 30767693, Trace File Analyzer (TFA), part of Autonomous Health Framework (AHF), uses excessive kernel memory on database servers, which leads to severe performance degradation, or database server instability.  As the number of databases and cluster resources increase the issue is more pronounced.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX62 in below MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues

    Exadata Critical Issue EX61
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 31139162, Exadata X8M storage servers experience low or out-of-memory memory conditions, which leads to severe performance degradation, or cluster-wide instability.  This issue affects Exadata X8M storage servers only (i.e. storage servers containing persistent memory (PMEM)). It does not affect Exadata X8 or earlier generation Exadata storage servers, or any generation ZDLRA storage servers.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX61 in below MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02

    Hide
    


    Verify Data Network is Separate from Management Network
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    It is a requirement that the management network be on a different non-overlapping sub-net than the RDMA Network Fabric network and the client access network. This is necessary for better network security, better client access bandwidths, and for Auto Service Request (ASR) to work correctly.
    The management network comprises of the eth0 network interface in the database and storage servers, the ILOM network interfaces of the database and storage servers, and the Ethernet management interfaces of the RDMA Network Fabric switches and PDUs.


    Risk:

    Having the management network on the same subnet as the client access network will reduce network security, potentially restrict the client access bandwidth to/from the Database Machine to a single 1GbE link, and will prevent ASR from working correctly.


    Action / Repair:

    To verify that the management network interface (eth0) is on a separate network from other network interfaces, execute the following command as the "root" userid on both storage and database servers:
    grep -i network /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg* | cut -f5 -d"/" | grep -v "#"
     
    The output will be similar to:
    ifcfg-bondeth0:NETWORK=10.204.77.0
    ifcfg-bondib0:NETWORK=192.168.76.0
    ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.204.78.0
    ifcfg-lo:NETWORK=127.0.0.0
    The expected result is that the network values are different. If they are not, investigate and correct the condition.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => Management network is separate from data network on all storage servers
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify Data Network is Separate from Management Network 


ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.25.96.0
ifcfg-re0:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
ifcfg-re1:NETWORK=100.66.132.0

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify Data Network is Separate from Management Network 


ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.25.96.0
ifcfg-re0:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
ifcfg-re1:NETWORK=100.66.132.0

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify Data Network is Separate from Management Network 


ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.25.96.0
ifcfg-re0:NETWORK=100.66.132.0

    ifcfg-re1:NETWORK=100.66.132.0

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify Data Network is Separate from Management Network 


ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.25.96.0
ifcfg-re0:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
ifcfg-re1:NETWORK=100.66.132.0

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify RDS Protocol is used for interprocess communication [Grid Home]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The RDS protocol provides superior performance because it avoids additional memory buffering operations when moving data from process memory to the network interface for IO operations. This includes both IO operations between the Oracle instance and the storage servers, as well as instance to instance block transfers via Cache Fusion.

    There is minimal impact to verify that the RDS protocol is in use. Implementing the RDS protocol requires an outage to relink the Oracle software.

    Risk:

    If the RDS protocol  is not used, IO operations will be sub-optimal.

    Action / Repair:

    To validate an ORACLE_HOME:
    As the owner userid of the ORACLE_HOME, set the ORACLE_HOME and LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables properly and execute the following command:

    $ORACLE_HOME/bin/skgxpinfo

    The output should be:

    rds

    To validate a CRS_HOME:
    As the owner userid of the CRS_HOME, set the CRS_HOME and LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables properly and execute the following command:

    $CRS_HOME/bin/skgxpinfo

    The output should be:

    rds

    If the RDS protocol is not being used, the appropriate binaries must be relinked.

        NOTE: In all cases, do not use the "relink all" command due to various issues. Use the make commands provided. 

    To relink an ORACLE_HOME:
    As the owner userid of the ORACLE_HOME execute the following steps with all necessary variables properly set:

        Shutdown any processes using the ORACLE_HOME
        "cd $ORACLE_HOME/rdbms/lib"
        "make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_rds ioracle"
        Restart any processes using the ORACLE_HOME 

    To relink a CRS_HOME:

        NOTE: The following instructions are for Oracle stack versions 12.2 or higher:

    As the owner userid of the CRS_HOME (and the "root" userid for some steps) execute the following steps with all necessary variables properly set:

        As the "root" userid, stop the clusterware runnning out of the CRS_HOME
        As the "root" userid, execute "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.sh -unlock"
        "cd $CRS_HOME/rdbms/lib"
        "make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_rds ioracle"
        As the "root" userid, execute "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.sh -lock"
        As the "root" userid, start the clusterware runnning out of the CRS_HOME
        After a few minutes, as the "root" userid verify all expected resources are executing with "$CRS_HOME/bin/crsctl stat res -t" 

        NOTE: The following instructions are for Oracle stack versions 12.1 or lower (including 11.2.x):

    As the owner userid of the CRS_HOME (and the "root" userid for some steps) execute the following steps with all necessary variables properly set:

        As the "root" userid, stop the clusterware runnning out of the CRS_HOME
        As the "root" userid, execute "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.pl -unlock"
        "cd $CRS_HOME/rdbms/lib"
        "make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_rds ioracle"
        As the "root" userid, "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.pl -patch"
        After a few minutes, as the "root" userid verify all expected resources are executing with "$CRS_HOME/bin/crsctl stat res -t"
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Oracle ASM is using RDS protocol for inter process communication
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY RDS PROTOCOL IS USED FOR INTERPROCESS COMMUNICATION [GRID HOME] 



rds
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Oracle ASM is using RDS protocol for inter process communication
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY RDS PROTOCOL IS USED FOR INTERPROCESS COMMUNICATION [GRID HOME] 



rds
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Oracle ASM is using RDS protocol for inter process communication
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY RDS PROTOCOL IS USED FOR INTERPROCESS COMMUNICATION [GRID HOME] 



rds
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter pre_page_sga
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Setting PRE_PAGE_SGA to TRUE improves database startup time.


    Risk:

    If PRE_PAGE_SGA is not set to TRUE, database startup may be delayed up to several minutes depending upon SGA size.

    Action / Repair:

    If PRE_PAGE_SGA is not set to "TRUE", correct the parameter setting.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:

    whexa3p31.pre_page_sga = TRUE
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter PRE_PAGE_SGA is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p33.pre_page_sga = TRUE
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter PRE_PAGE_SGA is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p32.pre_page_sga = TRUE
    


    Hide
    


    ORA_CRS_HOME env variable for Grid infrastructure owner
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Unset Oracle related environment variables especially ORA_CRS_HOME before starting OUI or before executing any root script for both root and grid user.

    This requirement is documented in Oracle Grid Infrastructure Installation Guide 11g Release 2 (11.2) .

    "Unset Oracle environment variables. If you have set ORA_CRS_HOME as an environment variable, then unset it before starting an installation or upgrade. You should never use ORA_CRS_HOME as an environment variable.

    If you have had an existing installation on your system, and you are using the same user account to install this installation, then unset the following environment variables: ORA_CRS_HOME; ORACLE_HOME; ORA_NLS10; TNS_ADMIN"

    Risk:

    Setting this variable can cause problems for various Oracle components, and it is never necessary for CRS programs because they all have wrapper scripts.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1502996.1 - Environment Variable ORA_CRS_HOME MUST be UNSET in 11gR2
    2.  Note: 952925.1 - 	 NETCA & ASMCA Fail during Upgrade of CRS/ASM to Grid Infrastructure 11gR2
    3.  Unset Oracle Environment Variables 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => ORA_CRS_HOME environment variable is not set for Grid infrastructure owner
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - ORA_CRS_HOME ENV VARIABLE FOR GRID INFRASTRUCTURE OWNER 




ORA_CRS_HOME environment variable not set
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => ORA_CRS_HOME environment variable is not set for Grid infrastructure owner
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - ORA_CRS_HOME ENV VARIABLE FOR GRID INFRASTRUCTURE OWNER 




ORA_CRS_HOME environment variable not set
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => ORA_CRS_HOME environment variable is not set for Grid infrastructure owner
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - ORA_CRS_HOME ENV VARIABLE FOR GRID INFRASTRUCTURE OWNER 




ORA_CRS_HOME environment variable not set
    


    Hide
    


    Verify that persistent memory (PMEM) is properly configured [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    For those Exadata platforms and release versions that support persistent memory (PMEM), properly configuring PMEM provides the greatest overall performance and high availability benefits.

        The currently recommended configuration for persistent memory is:

        Persistent Memory Cache Mode = WriteThrough
        Persistent Memory Cache Status = normal
        Persistent Memory Log Status = normal

    Risk:

    If the PMEM is not properly configured, the best combination of performance and high availability cannot be achieved. 

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that persistent memory (PMEM) is properly configured, as the root userid execute the following command set on each storage server that supports PMEM:

    PMEM_IN_USE=$(cellcli -e list physicaldisk | grep -ic PMEM)
    PMEMCACHEMODE=$(cellcli -e list cell attributes pmemcachemode | tr -cd [:alnum:])
    PMEMCACHE_STATUS=$(cellcli -e list pmemcache attributes status | tr -cd [:alnum:])
    PMEMLOG_STATUS=$(cellcli -e list pmemlog attributes status | tr -cd [:alnum:])
    if [ "$PMEM_IN_USE" -gt 0 ]
    then
      OVERALL_RESULT=0
      if [[ $PMEMCACHEMODE = "WriteThrough" ]]
      then
      PASS_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\nPASS: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: $PMEMCACHEMODE")
      else
      OVERALL_RESULT=1
      FAIL_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\nFAIL: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: $PMEMCACHEMODE")
      fi
      if [[ $PMEMCACHE_STATUS = "normal" ]]
      then
      PASS_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\nPASS: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: $PMEMCACHE_STATUS")
      else
      OVERALL_RESULT=1
      FAIL_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\nFAIL: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: $PMEMCACHE_STATUS")
      fi
      if [[ $PMEMLOG_STATUS = "normal" ]]
      then
      PASS_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\nPASS: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: $PMEMLOG_STATUS")
      else
      OVERALL_RESULT=1
      FAIL_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\nFAIL: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: $PMEMLOG_STATUS")
      fi
      if [[ $OVERALL_RESULT -eq 0 ]]
      then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: persistent memory is properly configured.  Details:\n${PASS_ARRAY[@]}"
      else
      echo -e "FAILURE: persistent memory is not properly configured.  Details:\n${FAIL_ARRAY[@]}\n${PASS_ARRAY[@]}"
      fi
    else
      echo -e "INFO: PMEM does not appear to be installed. Number of physicaldisks on PMEM: $PMEM_IN_USE"
    fi;

    The expected result is:

    SUCCESS: persistent memory is properly configured.  Details:

    PASS: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: WriteThrough
    PASS: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: normal
    PASS: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: normal

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE: persistent memory is not properly configured.  Details:

    FAIL: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: degraded

    PASS: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: WriteThrough
    PASS: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: normal

        NOTE: If a "FAILURE" result is returned, following the recommended procedures in the version specific documentation to change the PMEM configuration.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => All storage servers have persistent memory properly configured
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify that persistent memory (PMEM) is properly configured [Storage Server] 



PASS: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: WriteThrough
PASS: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: normal
PASS: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: normal

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify that persistent memory (PMEM) is properly configured [Storage Server] 



PASS: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: WriteThrough
PASS: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: normal
PASS: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: normal

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify that persistent memory (PMEM) is properly configured [Storage Server] 



    
PASS: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: WriteThrough
PASS: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: normal
PASS: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: normal

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify that persistent memory (PMEM) is properly configured [Storage Server] 



PASS: Persistent memory cache mode expected: WriteThrough Found: WriteThrough
PASS: Persistent memory cache status expected: normal Found: normal
PASS: Persistent memory log status expected: normal Found: normal

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Oracle Clusterware files are placed appropriately
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Oracle Clusterware files should always be placed in a high redundancy diskgroup with the exception of voting files for the following cases.

    i) For environments with less than 5 storage cells and running any Exadata software release prior to 12.1.2.3.0, the voting files need to be placed in a normal redundancy diskgroup.

    ii) For environments with less than 5 storage cells , running any Exadata software release 12.1.2.3.0 or above and running any Oracle Grid Infrastructure version prior to 12.1.0.2.160119, the voting files need to be placed in a normal redundancy diskgroup.

    Risk:

    Oracle Clusterware files placed on a normal redundancy diskgroup are exposed to the risk of of being lost in the event of diskgroup failures due to a double partner storage failure. Having the clusterware files on a high redundancy diskgroup mitigates this risk. The voting files are the only Clusterware files that are mandated to be stored in a normal redundancy diskgroup under the 2 conditions mentioned above. However, even if we lose the voting files due to a double partner storage failure under the above 2 conditions, they can be easily recreated unlike all other Clusterware files which require restore from backups.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify Oracle Clusterware files are placed appropriately, run Exachk and review the provided report.

    The expected output in the Exachk report should be as follows:

    In the "Findings Passed" summary section of the report, the overall result should be "PASS":

    PASS   OS Check   Oracle Clusterware files are placed appropriately   All Database Servers   View

    In the "View" detail section of the report for each individual database server:

    Status on random01client01:
    PASS => Oracle Clusterware files are placed appropriately

    DATA FROM RANDOM01CLIENT01 - VERIFY ORACLE CLUSTERWARE FILES ARE PLACED APPROPRIATELY

    Clusterware files placement check passed

    The Diskgroups found are 
    ============================
     Name Type Voting_files
    ACFSC1 HIGH N
    DATAC1 HIGH N
    DBFSC1 HIGH Y
    RECOC1 HIGH N

    OCR is stored in : DBFSC1

    Voting Files are stored in : DBFSC1

    ASM spfile is stored in : DBFSC1

    ASM password file is stored in : DBFSC1

    A "FAIL" example (view detail only):
    Status on random01client01:
    FAIL => Oracle Clusterware files are not placed appropriately

    DATA FROM RANDOM01CLIENT01 - VERIFY ORACLE CLUSTERWARE FILES ARE PLACED APPROPRIATELY

    Clusterware files placement check failed. 
    The clusterware files are not all placed in a high redundancy diskgroup.

    The Diskgroups found are 
    =========================
     Name Type Voting_files
    DATAC1 HIGH N
    DATAC2 HIGH N
    RECOC1 NORMAL N
    RECOC2 NORMAL Y

    OCR is stored in : DATAC2

    Voting Files are stored in : RECOC2

    ASM spfile is stored in : DATAC2

    ASM password file is stored in : DATAC2

    Please relocate the Voting Files to a high redundancy diskgroup using /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/bin/crsctl as described in the link below.
    For environments with less than 5 cells consider using Quorum devices which will enable storing the voting files in a high redundancy diskgroup.
    Minimum software versions that support Quorum devices are : Oracle Grid Infrastructure 12.1.0.2.160119 and Oracle Exadata release 12.1.2.3.0.

    https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/cwadd/managing-oracle-cluster-registry-and-voting-files.html#GUID-044D58CA-6392-40A1-AB31-C84A2A5A5CE6

        NOTE: If any "FAIL" results are returned, follow the guidance provided in the message.

        NOTE: If after corrective actions are completed you wish to run just this check without a full Exachk run, execute the following:

        ./exachk -check A096611C3310AC86E053D598EB0A3C1B
    

    Links
    1.  Adding, Deleting, or Migrating Voting Files 
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    UNDETERMINED => Oracle Clusterware files are not placed appropriately
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY ORACLE CLUSTERWARE FILES ARE PLACED APPROPRIATELY 




Clusterware files placement check failed. 
The clusterware files are not all placed in a high redundancy diskgroup.

The Diskgroups found are 
============================
 Name Type Voting_files
DATA_EXA3 NORMAL Y
RECO_EXA3 NORMAL N

OCR is stored in : DATA_EXA3

Voting Files are stored in : DATA_EXA3

ASM spfile is stored in : DATA_EXA3

    
ASM password file is stored in : DATA_EXA3

Please relocate the ASM spfile to a high redundancy diskgroup using '/u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/bin/asmcmd spcopy -u' as described in the link below.
After relocating the spfile, if possible restart the Grid Infrastructure in a rolling manner.
If a rolling grid infrastructure restart is not permitted, repeat the steps for relocating the spfile to the high redundancy diskgroup every time an initialization parameter modification to the ASM spfile is required until the Grid Infrastructure is restarted in a rolling manner.
    Click for more data
      
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    UNDETERMINED => Oracle Clusterware files are not placed appropriately
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY ORACLE CLUSTERWARE FILES ARE PLACED APPROPRIATELY 




Clusterware files placement check failed. 
The clusterware files are not all placed in a high redundancy diskgroup.

The Diskgroups found are 
============================
 Name Type Voting_files
DATA_EXA3 NORMAL Y
RECO_EXA3 NORMAL N

OCR is stored in : DATA_EXA3

Voting Files are stored in : DATA_EXA3

ASM spfile is stored in : DATA_EXA3

    
ASM password file is stored in : DATA_EXA3

Please relocate the ASM spfile to a high redundancy diskgroup using '/u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/bin/asmcmd spcopy -u' as described in the link below.
After relocating the spfile, if possible restart the Grid Infrastructure in a rolling manner.
If a rolling grid infrastructure restart is not permitted, repeat the steps for relocating the spfile to the high redundancy diskgroup every time an initialization parameter modification to the ASM spfile is required until the Grid Infrastructure is restarted in a rolling manner.
    Click for more data
      
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    UNDETERMINED => Oracle Clusterware files are not placed appropriately
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY ORACLE CLUSTERWARE FILES ARE PLACED APPROPRIATELY 




Clusterware files placement check failed. 
The clusterware files are not all placed in a high redundancy diskgroup.

The Diskgroups found are 
============================
 Name Type Voting_files
DATA_EXA3 NORMAL Y
RECO_EXA3 NORMAL N

OCR is stored in : DATA_EXA3

Voting Files are stored in : DATA_EXA3

ASM spfile is stored in : DATA_EXA3

    
ASM password file is stored in : DATA_EXA3

Please relocate the ASM spfile to a high redundancy diskgroup using '/u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/bin/asmcmd spcopy -u' as described in the link below.
After relocating the spfile, if possible restart the Grid Infrastructure in a rolling manner.
If a rolling grid infrastructure restart is not permitted, repeat the steps for relocating the spfile to the high redundancy diskgroup every time an initialization parameter modification to the ASM spfile is required until the Grid Infrastructure is restarted in a rolling manner.
    Click for more data
      
    


    Hide
    


    Verify that critical database files reside on high redundancy diskgroups
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The use of high redundancy ASM disk groups provides the ultimate protection against downtime and data loss caused by partner storage failures and corruptions. High redundancy not only protects against the less likely case of a double partner disk failure, but more importantly protects from all of the other combinations of issues that can occur with partner Exadata storage. The most important case is when the Exadata storage software is updated in a rolling manner. During a rolling update of the Exadata storage servers, redundancy is temporarily reduced during the time an Exadata storage server is updated and gracefully restarted. If a partner disk on the Exadata storage server being restarted fails during the restart process, all ASM disk groups with normal redundancy will dismount and all I/O operations to that disk group will fail. If this disk group contains critical files, the database and Oracle clusterware will crash and can not be restarted until the disk group is once again available.

    Critical files such as datafiles, online and standby log files, control files, archivelog files, spfiles, and clusterware OCR and voting files should always reside on high redundancy disk groups.

    NOTE: To ensure better data protection, Oracle strongly recommends databases to be configured with ASM High Redundancy on 5+ year old Exadata systems. See MOS Document 2075007.1 for details.

    NOTE: For reference, the following file types are considered "critical": CONTROLFILE, DATAFILE, ONLINELOG, CHANGETRACKING, ARCHIVELOG, FLASHBACK, PARAMETERFILE

    NOTE: Clusterware has it's own best practice recommendations for the placement of critical files. Please reference:
        Verify Oracle Clusterware files are placed appropriately

    Our general recommendation is that the two key disk groups supplied at Exadata deployment time for a cluster, ex: DATAC1 and RECOC1, are high redundancy. 

    Risk:

    Not using high redundancy diskgroups increases the risk of downtime and data loss caused by partner storage failures and corruptions, especially those encountered during cell planned maintenance.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that critical files reside on high redundancy ASM disk groups, as the home owner userid with the environment configured to access a given database, connnect to a given database and execute the following code:

    RAW_FILE_DATA=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set newpage none heading off lines 32000 feedback off timing off serveroutput on
    select (name||':DATAFILE') from v\$datafile;
    select (name||':CONTROLFILE') from v\$controlfile;
    select (member||':ONLINELOG') from v\$logfile;
    select (name||':ARCHIVELOG') from v\$archived_log where name is not null;
    select (value||':SPFILE') from v\$parameter where name = 'spfile';
    select (name||':FLASHBACK') from v\$flashback_database_logfile;
    select (filename||':CHANGETRACKING') from v\$block_change_tracking;
    exit
    EOF
    )
    # restrict file data to local files:
    RAW_FILE_DATA=$(echo "$RAW_FILE_DATA" | egrep "^\+")
    #get the diskgroup data:
    DISKGROUP_DATA=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set newpage none heading off lines 32000 feedback off timing off serveroutput on
    select name,type from v\$asm_diskgroup_stat;
    exit
    EOF
    )
    #trim the diskgoup data:
    DISKGROUP_DATA=$(echo "$DISKGROUP_DATA" | awk '$1=$1')
    #create an array of disk groups in use from the raw file data
    DG_IN_USE_ARRAY=$(echo -e "$RAW_FILE_DATA"| awk -F/ -v pattern="^+" '$0~pattern && /[[:alnum:]]/ {sub(/^\+/, "",$1); if ($1 != " " && !seen[$1]++) print $1;}')
    # trim the DG_IN_USE_ARRAY
    DG_IN_USE_ARRAY=$(echo "$DG_IN_USE_ARRAY" | sort -u)
    #for each dg in use, find type and build output_array
    RESULT=0
    for INDIVIDUAL_DG in $DG_IN_USE_ARRAY
    do
      DG_TYPE=$(echo "$DISKGROUP_DATA" | grep $INDIVIDUAL_DG | cut -d " " -f2)
      if [[ $DG_TYPE = "HIGH" ]]
      then
        FILE_TYPE=$(echo "$RAW_FILE_DATA" | grep $INDIVIDUAL_DG | cut -d ":" -f2 | sort -u |  sed -e ':a;N;s/\\n/ /;ba')
        PASS_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\ndisk group name: $INDIVIDUAL_DG\nredundancy: $DG_TYPE\nfile type(s): $FILE_TYPE")
      else
        FILE_TYPE=$(echo "$RAW_FILE_DATA" | grep $INDIVIDUAL_DG | cut -d ":" -f2 | sort -u |  sed -e ':a;N;s/\\n/ /;ba')
        FAIL_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\ndisk group name: $INDIVIDUAL_DG\nredundancy: $DG_TYPE\nfile type(s): $FILE_TYPE")
        RESULT=1
      fi
    done
    if [[ $RESULT -eq 0 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS:  all disk groups which contain critical files use high redundancy.\nDetails:\n${PASS_ARRAY[@]}"
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE:  one or more disk groups which contain critical files do not use high redundancy.\
    \n\nFAIL details:\n${FAIL_ARRAY[@]}\n\nPASS details:\n${PASS_ARRAY[@]}"
    fi

    The expected result is:

    SUCCESS:  all disk groups which contain critical files use high redundancy.
    Details:

    disk group name: DATAC1
    redundancy: HIGH
    file type(s): CHANGETRACKING CONTROLFILE DATAFILE ONLINELOG SPFILE
    disk group name: RECOC1
    redundancy: HIGH
    file type(s): ARCHIVELOG FLASHBACK

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE:  one or more disk groups which contain critical files do not use high redundancy.

    FAIL details:

    disk group name: RECOC1
    redundancy: NORMAL
    file type(s): ARCHIVELOG DATAFILE

    PASS details:

    disk group name: DATAC1
    redundancy: HIGH
    file type(s): CONTROLFILE DATAFILE ONLINELOG SPFILE
    disk group name: DATAC2
    redundancy: HIGH
    file type(s): ARCHIVELOG

        NOTE: If a "FAILURE" result is returned, follow the recommended procedures in the version specific documentation to change the disk group redundancy to high or to relocate the critical file(s).
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    FAIL => One or more disk groups which contain critical files do not use high redundancy
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify that critical database files reside on high redundancy diskgroups

    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify that critical database files reside on high redundancy diskgroups

disk group name: DATA_EXA3
redundancy: NORMAL
file type(s): CHANGETRACKING

    ONLINELOG
