    Hide
    


    Verify the Alternate Archive Destination is Configured to Prevent Database Hangs
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Without an alternate archive destination configured, if the local archive destination (typically the Fast Recovery Area) becomes unusable, the database will hang when it cannot archive a log. A properly configured alternate archive destination prevents a database hang and provides time for the local archive destination to be made healthy, at which time Oracle will automatically resume archiving to the local archive destination.

    The current recommended redo log archive log destination and alternate configuration is:
    DESTINATION 	ATTRIBUTE 	VALUE 	ALERT LEVEL
    log_archive_dest_1 	ALTERNATE 	a separately configured log archive destination,
    log_archive_dest_n 	FAIL
    log_archive_dest_1 	MAX_FAILURE 	1 	FAIL
    log_archive_dest_1 	STATUS 	VALID 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_1 	DB_UNIQUE_NAME 	equal to the DB_UNIQUE_NAME of the database 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_1 	REOPEN_SECS 	5 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_1 	VALID_TYPE 	ALL_LOGFILES 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_1 	VALID_ROLE 	ALL_ROLES 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_1 	DESTINATION 	USE_DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_n (ALTERNATE) 	STATUS 	ALTERNATE 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_n (ALTERNATE) 	ALTERNATE 	LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_n (ALTERNATE) 	DB_UNIQUE_NAME 	equal to the DB_UNIQUE_NAME of the database 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_n (ALTERNATE) 	VALID_TYPE 	ALL_LOGFILES 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_n (ALTERNATE) 	VALID_ROLE 	ALL_ROLES 	WARN
    log_archive_dest_n (ALTERNATE) 	DESTINATION 	%DATA% diskgroup 	WARN 

    The impact of moving critical database files out of ACFS disk groups varies by the type of file involved, and cannot be estimated here.

    NOTE: For more information on ACFS use cases and recommended disk group attributes on Exadata, please see below link: Oracle ACFS Support on Oracle Exadata Database Machine (Linux only) (Doc ID 1929629.1) 

    Risk:

    The database will eventually halt if the online redo logs cannot be archived. 

    Action / Repair:

    To Verify the log archive destination and alternate log archive destination configuration, run Exachk and examine the MAA Scorecard Section of the provided report.

    The expected output in the Exachk report should be as follows:

    In the "Findings Passed" summary section of the report, the overall result should be "PASS":

    PASS   OS Check    All log archive destination and alternate log archive destination settings are as recommended random01adm01:rac12c   View

    In the "View" detail section of the report for each individual database server:

    Status on random01adm01:rac12c:
    PASS => All log archive destination and alternate log archive destination settings are as recommended
    DATA FROM RANDOMADM01 - RAC12C DATABASE - VERIFY THE ALTERNATE ARCHIVE DESTINATION IS CONFIGURED TO PREVENT DATABASE HANGS

    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute ALTERNATE expected value: other than "NONE" found value: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_2
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute MAX_FAILURE expected value: 1 found value: 1
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute REOPEN expected value: 5 found value: 5
    PASS: ALTERNATE local archive destination attribute LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_STATE_n expected value: ALTERNATE found value: ALTERNATE
    PASS: ALTERNATE local archive destination attribute ALTERNATE expected value: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 found value: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1
    PASS: ALTERNATE local archive destination attribute DB_UNIQUE_NAME expected value: RAC12C found value: RAC12C
    PASS: ALTERNATE local archive destination attribute VALID_TYPE expected value: ALL_LOGFILES found value: ALL_LOGFILES
    PASS: ALTERNATE local archive destination attribute VALID_ROLE expected value: ALL_ROLES found value: ALL_ROLES
    PASS: ALTERNATE local archive destination attribute LOCATION expected value: %DATA% found value: +DATAC1
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute STATUS expected value: VALID found value: VALID
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute DB_UNIQUE_NAME expected value: RAC12C found value: RAC12C
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute VALID_TYPE expected value: ALL_LOGFILES found value: ALL_LOGFILES
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute VALID_ROLE expected value: ALL_ROLES found value: ALL_ROLES
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute DESTINATION expected value: USE_DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST found value: USE_DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST

    Example of a "CRITICAL" result:
    In the "View" detail section of the report:

    CRITICAL => One or more log archive destination and alternate log archive destination settings are not as recommended
    DATA FROM RANDOMADM01 - SING12C DATABASE- VERIFY THE ALTERNATE ARCHIVE DESTINATION IS CONFIGURED TO PREVENT DATABASE HANGS

    FAIL: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute ALTERNATE expected value: other than "NONE" found value: NONE
    FAIL: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute MAX_FAILURE expected value: 1 found value: 0
    WARN: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute DB_UNIQUE_NAME expected value: SING12C found value: NONE
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute STATUS expected value: VALID found value: VALID
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute VALID_TYPE expected value: ALL_LOGFILES found value: ALL_LOGFILES
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute VALID_ROLE expected value: ALL_ROLES found value: ALL_ROLES
    PASS: LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1 attribute DESTINATION expected value: USE_DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST found value: USE_DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST

        NOTE: For any incorrect settings, change following the appropriate version specific Oracle documentation instructions.

        Example parameter definitions:

        log_archive_dest_1='LOCATION=USE_DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST valid_for=(ALL_LOGFILES,ALL_ROLES) MAX_FAILURE=1 REOPEN=5 DB_UNIQUE_NAME=<db_unique_name> ALTERNATE=LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_10'
        log_archive_dest_10='location=+DATAC1 valid_for=(ALL_LOGFILES,ALL_ROLES) DB_UNIQUE_NAME=<db_unique_name> ALTERNATE=LOG_ARCHIVE_DEST_1'

        NOTE: If after corrective actions are completed you wish to run just this check without a full Exachk run, execute the following:

        ./exachk -check 9FABDE1F9D6D8C4FE053D298EB0A0F82
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:

    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify the Alternate Archive Destination is Configured to Prevent Database Hangs

    Verify Hardware and Firmware on Database and Storage Servers (CheckHWnFWProfile) [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The Oracle Exadata Database Machine is tightly integrated, and verifying the hardware and firmware before the Oracle Exadata Database Machine is placed into or returned to production status can avoid problems related to the hardware or firmware modifications.

    The impact for these verification steps is minimal.



    Risk:

    If the hardware and firmware are not validated, inconsistencies between database and storage servers can lead to problems and outages.



    Action / Repair:

    Verify the hardware and firmware configuration by executing the /opt/oracle.cellos/CheckHWnFWProfile script as the root userid as shown below:

    # /opt/oracle.cellos/CheckHWnFWProfile
    [SUCCESS] The hardware and firmware profile matches one of the supported profile

    If any result other than "SUCCESS" is returned, investigate and correct the condition.

        NOTE: CheckHWnFWProfile is also executed at each boot of the storage and database servers. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Hardware and firmware profile check is successful. [Database Server]
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY HARDWARE AND FIRMWARE ON DATABASE AND STORAGE SERVERS (CHECKHWNFWPROFILE) [DATABASE SERVER]



[SUCCESS] The hardware and firmware matches supported profile for server=ORACLE_SERVER_X8-2
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Hardware and firmware profile check is successful. [Database Server]
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY HARDWARE AND FIRMWARE ON DATABASE AND STORAGE SERVERS (CHECKHWNFWPROFILE) [DATABASE SERVER]



[SUCCESS] The hardware and firmware matches supported profile for server=ORACLE_SERVER_X8-2
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Hardware and firmware profile check is successful. [Database Server]
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY HARDWARE AND FIRMWARE ON DATABASE AND STORAGE SERVERS (CHECKHWNFWPROFILE) [DATABASE SERVER]



[SUCCESS] The hardware and firmware matches supported profile for server=ORACLE_SERVER_X8-2
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Hardware and Firmware on Database and Storage Servers (CheckHWnFWProfile) [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The Oracle Exadata Database Machine is tightly integrated, and verifying the hardware and firmware before the Oracle Exadata Database Machine is placed into or returned to production status can avoid problems related to the hardware or firmware modifications.

    The impact for these verification steps is minimal.



    Risk:

    If the hardware and firmware are not validated, inconsistencies between database and storage servers can lead to problems and outages.



    Action / Repair:

    Verify the hardware and firmware configuration by executing the /opt/oracle.cellos/CheckHWnFWProfile script as the root userid as shown below:

    # /opt/oracle.cellos/CheckHWnFWProfile
    [SUCCESS] The hardware and firmware profile matches one of the supported profile

    If any result other than "SUCCESS" is returned, investigate and correct the condition.

        NOTE: CheckHWnFWProfile is also executed at each boot of the storage and database servers. 
    

    Needs attention onexa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm02, exa3celadm04:
    FAIL => Hardware and firmware profile check is not successful on one or more storage servers.
    DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify Hardware and Firmware on Database and Storage Servers (CheckHWnFWProfile) [Storage Server] 


[40;1;33m[WARNING][0m The hardware and firmware does not match with the profile. See details below

<Check_Result Server_Model="ORACLE_SERVER_X8-2L">
  <Check_Result_for_HardDisk>
    <Combination_Check>
      <Supported_Groups>
        <Group VALUE="1">
          <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T"/>
          <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A524ORA014T"/>
        </Group>
        <Group VALUE="2">
          <HardDisk SIGNATURE="H7210A520SUN010T"/>
          <HardDisk SIGNATURE="H7210A524SUN010T"/>
        </Group>
      </Supported_Groups>
      <Found_Combination>

            <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:11"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:10"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214C520ORA014T" SLOT="252:9"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:8"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:7"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:6"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:5"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:4"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:3"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:2"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:1"/>
        <HardDisk SIGNATURE="W7214A520ORA014T" SLOT="252:0"/>
      </Found_Combination>
    </Combination_Check>
  </Check_Result_for_HardDisk>
</Check_Result>

[40;1;33m[WARNING][0m The hardware and firmware does not match with the profile. See details above

    </FlashCardCount>

      <Found VALUE="4,6,10"/>
    </PCISlotCombination>
  </Check_Result_for_Flash>

    Hide
    


    Verify all voting disks are online
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Voting disks help ensure a stable cluster. The impact of verifying all voting disks are online is minimal. The impact of bringing a given voting disk back online depends upon the reason why it went offline, and cannot be estimated here.



    Risk:

    Not having all expected voting disks online increases the risk of node eviction or cluster crash.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify all voting disks are online, as the grid home owner userid, and with CRS_HOME and SID set to access the ASM instance, execute the following code on one database server in the cluster:

    VOTEDISK_OUTPUT=$($CRS_HOME/bin/crsctl query css votedisk)
    LOCATED_COUNT=$(echo "$VOTEDISK_OUTPUT" | egrep "^Located" | cut -d" " -f2)
    ONLINE_COUNT=$(echo "$VOTEDISK_OUTPUT" | egrep -c ONLINE)
    if [ "$LOCATED_COUNT" -eq "$ONLINE_COUNT" ]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: all voting disks are online."
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: not all voting disks are online.\nDETAILS:\n$VOTEDISK_OUTPUT"
    fi

    The expected output should be:

    SUCCESS: all voting disks are online.

    Example of a "FAILURE" case:

    FAILURE: not all voting disks are online.
    DETAILS:
    ##  STATE    File Universal Id                File Name Disk group
    --  -----    -----------------                --------- ---------
     1. ONLINE   a07c741f08194f71bf7f4d14c7d67a15 (/dev/exadata_quorum/QD_DATAC1_RANDOM05ADM05) [DATAC1]
     2. ONLINE   d1327820402f4f2fbffca97cbdef72d7 (/dev/exadata_quorum/QD_DATAC1_RANDOM05ADM06) [DATAC1]
     3. ONLINE   748b53cfb1a64f6cbff0f71de2de89b3 (o/192.168.22.171;192.168.22.172/DATAC1_FD_05_random05celadm07) [DATAC1]
     4. ONLINE   5fbc672724094f82bfcd4ea220ab824a (o/192.168.22.173;192.168.22.174/DATAC1_FD_05_random05celadm08) [DATAC1]
     5. OFFLINE   e9efd3be40ad4f64bfd034233f3e37d3 (o/192.168.22.175;192.168.22.176/DATAC1_FD_05_random05celadm09) [DATAC1]

    If a "FAILURE" result is returned, investigate to determine root cause and take appropriate corrective action. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => All voting disks are online
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY ALL VOTING DISKS ARE ONLINE 



SUCCESS: all voting disks are online.
    


    Hide
    


    Non-autoextensible data and temp files
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The benefit of having "AUTOEXTEND" on is that applications may avoid out of space errors.
    The impact of verifying that the "AUTOEXTEND" attribute is "ON" is minimal. The impact of setting "AUTOEXTEND" to "ON" varies depending upon if it is done during database creation, file addition to a tablespace, or added to an existing file.



    Risk:

    The risk of running out of space in either the tablespace or diskgroup varies by application and cannot be quantified here. A tablespace that runs out of space will interfere with an application, and a diskgroup running out of space could impact the entire database as well as ASM operations (e.g., rebalance operations).



    Action / Repair:

    To obtain a list of tablespaces that are not set to "AUTOEXTEND", enter the following sqlplus command logged into the database as sysdba:
    select file_id, file_name, tablespace_name from dba_data_files where autoextensible <>'YES'
    union
    select file_id, file_name, tablespace_name from dba_temp_files where autoextensible <> 'YES'; 
    The output should be:
    no rows selected
    If any rows are returned, investigate and correct the condition.
    NOTE: Configuring "AUTOEXTEND" to "ON" requires comparing space utilization growth projections at the tablespace level to space available in the diskgroups to permit the expected projected growth while retaining sufficient storage space in reserve to account for ASM rebalance operations that occur either as a result of planned operations or component failure. The resulting growth targets are implemented with the "MAXSIZE" attribute that should always be used in conjunction with the "AUTOEXTEND" attribute. The "MAXSIZE" settings should allow for projected growth while minimizing the prospect of depleting a disk group. The "MAXSIZE" settings will vary by customer and a blanket recommendation cannot be given here.

    NOTE: When configuring a file for "AUTOEXTEND" to "ON", the size specified for the "NEXT" attribute should cover all disks in the diskgroup to optimize balance. For example, with a 4MB AU size and 168 disks, the size of the "NEXT" attribute should be a multiple of 672M (4*168).

    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check 9ECBA2152E92F6B1E040E50A1EC00DFB".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair 9ECBA2152E92F6B1E040E50A1EC00DFB".
    

    Needs attention onwhexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Some data or temp files are not autoextensible
    FILE_NAME                                           
--------------------------------------------------- 
+DATA_EXA3/WHEXA3P3/DATAFILE/undots1.419.1074016483
+DATA_EXA3/WHEXA3P3/DATAFILE/undots2.420.1074016485
+DATA_EXA3/WHEXA3P3/DATAFILE/undots3.421.1074016495

    


    Hide
    


    Non-routable network for interconnect
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Secure and efficient interconnect performance.

    Risk:

    Interconnect security and latency issues.

    Action / Repair:

    The cluster interconnect should be a completely private/isolated (layer 2 packet processing), non-routable network (the only nodes connected to it are the cluster members themselves).

    The 10.x.x.x, 172.x.x.x and 192.x.x.x networks are defined as non-routable networks by standard.  Customers who use other networks for the interconnect should ensure that they are not being routed, in which case this finding can be ignored.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Interconnect is configured on non-routable network addresses
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - NON-ROUTABLE NETWORK FOR INTERCONNECT 



bondeth0.2191  10.2.160.0  global  public
re0  100.66.132.0  global  cluster_interconnect,asm
re1  100.66.132.0  global  cluster_interconnect,asm
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Interconnect is configured on non-routable network addresses
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - NON-ROUTABLE NETWORK FOR INTERCONNECT 



bondeth0.2191  10.2.160.0  global  public
re0  100.66.132.0  global  cluster_interconnect,asm
re1  100.66.132.0  global  cluster_interconnect,asm
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Interconnect is configured on non-routable network addresses
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - NON-ROUTABLE NETWORK FOR INTERCONNECT 



bondeth0.2191  10.2.160.0  global  public
re0  100.66.132.0  global  cluster_interconnect,asm
re1  100.66.132.0  global  cluster_interconnect,asm
    


    Hide
    


    IDGEN$ sequence cache size
    


    

    Recommendation
    Sequence contention (SQ enqueue) can occur if SYS.IDGEN1$ sequence is not cached to 1000.  This condition can lead to performance issues in RAC.  1000 is the default starting in version 11.2.0.1.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYS.IDGEN1$ sequence cache size >= 1,000
    'IDGEN1$.CACHE_SIZE='||CACHE_SIZE 
--------------------------------- 
idgen1$.cache_size = 1000

    


    Hide
    


    GC block lost
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Optimal global cache performance 



    Risk:

    The RDBMS reports global cache lost block statistics ("gc cr block lost" and/or "gc current block lost") which could indicate a negative impact on interconnect performance and global cache processing.



    Action / Repair:

    The vast majority of escalations attributed to RDBMS global cache lost blocks can be directly related to faulty or misconfigured interconnects. GC lost blocks diagnostics guide serves as a starting point for evaluating common (and sometimes obvious) causes.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 563566.1 - gc lost blocks diagnostics
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => GC blocks lost is not occurring
    TOTAL_BLOCKS_LOST                        
---------------------------------------- 
No of GC lost block in last 24 hours = 0

    


    Hide
    


    AUDSES$ sequence cache size
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Application scalability



    Risk:

    Problems have been reported with AUDSES$, ORA_TQ_BASE$ and IDGEN1$, which are all internal sequences, if the cache size is too small (e.g., login storms or very high concurrency) and can manifest as waits in "rowcache" for "dc_sequences" which is a rowcache type for sequences.



    Action / Repair:

    Increase AUDSES$ and ORA_TQ_BASE$ to 10,000
    Increase IDGEN1$ to a value of 1000

    See referenced Notes.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 268476.1 - LOB Performance Guideline
    2.  Note: 432508.1 - High SQ Enqueue Contention with LOBs or Advanced Replication
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYS.AUDSES$ sequence cache size >= 10,000
    'AUDSES$.CACHE_SIZE='||CACHE_SIZE 
--------------------------------- 
audses$.cache_size = 10000

    


    Hide
    


    SELinux status
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    In Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Government and National Security regions, SELinux is required to be configured in "enforcing" mode. For OCI Commercial regions and Exadata on-premises, SELinux is recommended in "permissive" mode. The system administrator must be aware of the SELinux status and take action depending on the system type and / or Cloud region. Additionally, if Access Vector Cache (AVC) denials were triggered by SELinux, corresponding actions must be taken to prevent unexpected system behavior.

    Note: More information related to SELinux capabilities and importance for system security can be found in the following documentation: Oracle Linux Administering SELinux (https://docs.oracle.com/en/operating-systems/oracle-linux/8/).



    Risk:

    If SELinux is disabled, unauthorized access events are not recorded and the system administrator cannot use them for maintenance and security operations. On the other hand, if SELinux is enabled and the system policy is not updated and properly maintained, SELinux could block critical access to system processes and trigger unexpected system behavior. Additionally, in Exadata systems where SELinux is required in enforcing mode, not having SELinux properly configured would mean the system failing to comply with legally required functionality.



    Action / Repair:

    In Exadata database nodes and storage servers, depending on the system type and legal requirements, SELinux must be configured in "permissive" or "enforcing" mode. Additionally, all the system AVC denials generated by SELinux must be reviewed and attended.

    If SELinux is disabled, execute the following command (use appropriate mode, depending on system type and requirements):
        /opt/oracle.cellos/host_access_control selinux < --permissive | --enforcing >

    Note: Before using the "--enforcing" option, it is recommended to test the system performance and access event blocking with the "--permissive" option.


    For all the system executables flagged, execute the following command to understand why the denial was triggered, what the executable is requiring and how it can be fixed:
        ausearch -i -m avc -x </path/to/system/executable> | audit2allow [options]

    Note: Verify the SELinux system policy is updated not to block access for necessary system functionality.


    The AVC denials are persistent audit entries. A 7-day period of denials is collected for analysis, if corresponding fixes have been applied ignore related findings.

    Use the following command to collect denials from past dates:
        ausearch -i -m avc --start [start date] [start time]

    Use the following command to collect all AVC denials present in /var/log/audit/audit.log:
        ausearch -i -m avc



    Note: More information related to SELinux usage in Exadata systems can be found in section 2.1 (Using Security-Enhanced Linux) of the "Security Guide for Oracle Exadata".


    Note: Once the issue has been resolved, if you wish to validate this Exachk check individually, you may run the following command as "root" user:

        # exachk -showpass -check 9EC7304AE678DC2DE040E50A1EC07772
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => SELinux configuration is as expected
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR SELINUX STATUS



SUCCESS: SELinux is enabled and no AVC denials were found.

Details:

SELinux configuration status: .
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => SELinux configuration is as expected
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR SELINUX STATUS



SUCCESS: SELinux is enabled and no AVC denials were found.

Details:

SELinux configuration status: .
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => SELinux configuration is as expected
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR SELINUX STATUS



SUCCESS: SELinux is enabled and no AVC denials were found.

Details:

SELinux configuration status: .
    


    Hide
    


    VIP NIC bonding config.
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Public network interface (VIP) redundancy, increased application availability



    Risk:

    Lack of NIC bonding for the public network interface can result in a single point of failure for VIPs thereby causing the potential for application availability issues.



    Action / Repair:

    Oracle highly recommends to configure redundant network for VIPs using NIC BONDING.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    GI shell limits hard stack
    


    

    Recommendation
    The hard stack shell limit for the Oracle Grid Infrastructure software install owner as defined in /etc/security/limits.conf should be >= 10240.

    What's being checked here is the /etc/security/limits.conf file as documented in 11gR2 Grid Infrastructure Installation Guide, section 2.15.3 Setting Resource Limits for the Oracle Software Installation Users.  

    If the /etc/security/limits.conf file is not configured as described in the documentation then to check the hard stack configuration while logged into the software owner account (e.g., grid).

    $ ulimit -Hs
    10240

    As long as the hard stack limit is 10240 or above then the configuration should be OK.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    Oracle database software owner hard stack shell limits
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Documented value is the /etc/security/limits.conf file as documented in 11gR2 Grid Infrastructure  Installation Guide, section 2.15.3 Setting Resource Limits for the Oracle Software Installation Users.  

    If the /etc/security/limits.conf file is not configured as described in the documentation then log in to the system as the database software owner (e.g., oracle) and check the hard stack configuration as described below.

    Risk:

    The hard stack shell limit for the Oracle DB software install owner as defined in /etc/security/limits.conf should be >= 10240.  As long as the hard stack limit is 10240 or above then the configuration should be OK.



    Action / Repair:

    Change DB software install owner hard stack shell limit

    $ ulimit -Hs
    10240

    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

oracle    hard     memlock     unlimited
    


    Hide

    Verify Data Network is Separate from Management Network
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    It is a requirement that the management network be on a different non-overlapping sub-net than the RDMA Network Fabric network and the client access network. This is necessary for better network security, better client access bandwidths, and for Auto Service Request (ASR) to work correctly.
    The management network is comprised of the eth0 network interface in the database and storage servers, the ILOM network interfaces of the database and storage servers, and the Ethernet management interfaces of the RDMA Network Fabric switches and PDUs.


    Risk:

    Having the management network on the same subnet as the client access network will reduce network security, potentially restrict the client access bandwidth to/from the Database Machine to a single 1GbE link, and will prevent ASR from working correctly.


    Action / Repair:

    To verify that the management network interface (eth0) is on a separate network from other network interfaces, execute the following command as the "root" userid on both storage and database servers:
    grep -i network /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg* | cut -f5 -d"/" | grep -v "#"
     
    The output will be similar to:
    ifcfg-bondeth0:NETWORK=10.204.77.0
    ifcfg-bondib0:NETWORK=192.168.76.0
    ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.204.78.0
    ifcfg-lo:NETWORK=127.0.0.0
    The expected result is that the network values are different. If they are not, investigate and correct the condition.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Management network is separate from data network
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY DATA NETWORK IS SEPARATE FROM MANAGEMENT NETWORK



ifcfg-bondeth0.2191:NETWORK=10.2.160.0
ifcfg-bondeth1.2193:NETWORK=10.21.96.0
ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.25.96.0
ifcfg-re0:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
ifcfg-re1:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Management network is separate from data network
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY DATA NETWORK IS SEPARATE FROM MANAGEMENT NETWORK



ifcfg-bondeth0.2191:NETWORK=10.2.160.0
ifcfg-bondeth1.2193:NETWORK=10.21.96.0
ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.25.96.0
ifcfg-re0:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
ifcfg-re1:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Management network is separate from data network
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY DATA NETWORK IS SEPARATE FROM MANAGEMENT NETWORK



ifcfg-bondeth0.2191:NETWORK=10.2.160.0
ifcfg-bondeth1.2193:NETWORK=10.21.96.0
ifcfg-eth0:NETWORK=10.25.96.0
ifcfg-re0:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
ifcfg-re1:NETWORK=100.66.132.0
    


    Hide
    


    Manage ASM Audit File Directory Growth with cron
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The audit file destination directories for an ASM instance can grow to contain a very large number of files if they are not regularly maintained. Use the Linux cron(8) utility and the find(1) command to manage the number of files in the audit file destination directories.

    The impact of using cron(8) and find(1) to manage the number of files in the audit file destination directories is minimal.



    Risk:

    Having a very large number of files can cause the file system to run out of free disk space or inodes, or can cause Oracle to run very slowly due to file system directory scaling limits, which can have the appearance that the ASM instance is hanging on startup.



    Action / Repair:

    Refer to the referenced MOS Note
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1298957.1 - Manage Audit File Directory Growth with cron
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => ASM Audit file destination file count <= 100,000
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - MANAGE ASM AUDIT FILE DIRECTORY GROWTH WITH CRON 



Number of audit files at /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/rdbms/audit = 30
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => ASM Audit file destination file count <= 100,000
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - MANAGE ASM AUDIT FILE DIRECTORY GROWTH WITH CRON 



Number of audit files at /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/rdbms/audit = 12
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:+ASM2:
    PASS => ASM Audit file destination file count <= 100,000
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - MANAGE ASM AUDIT FILE DIRECTORY GROWTH WITH CRON 



Number of audit files at /u01/app/19.0.0.0/grid/rdbms/audit = 14
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue DB44
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 30655657, corruption may occur due to lost writes when files are stored in an ACFS file system that contains ACFS snapshots (read-only(RO) or read-write(RW)).

    This issue causes database corruption when database files (data files, archived log files) are stored in ACFS. This issue does not affect database control files or redo log files stored in ACFS.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue DB44 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue DB44
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE DB44 



ACFS Mount point
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue DB44
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE DB44 



ACFS Mount point
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue DB44
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE DB44 



ACFS Mount point
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX58
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 30391350, after database server reboot, databases open slowly due to excessive LGWR waits caused by slow RDS connection formation.  Excessive LGWR waits may cause slowness on instances in other nodes in the cluster.  
    Slowness lasting up to 20 minutes has been observed on Exadata quarter rack systems experiencing this issue.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX58 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX58

    Exadata Critical Issue EX57
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to unpublished bug 30388717, heavy RDMA traffic on the interconnect network (on either RoCE-based or RDMA Network Fabric-based systems) may cause a database server or storage server kernel to crash.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX57 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues

    Exadata Critical Issue DB43
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 30363621, a kernel panic may occur on a database server running
    Grid Infrastructure 19c when ACFS file systems are used.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    2.  Note: 2608246.1 - (DB43) Database server crash when using 19c ACFS file systems (Doc ID 2608246.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue DB43
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE DB43

    Free space in root file system
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Best Practice, Proactive problem avoidance



    Risk:

    root filesystem has 20% or less free space remaining.  Action should be taken to free up space in order to avoid potential problems from lack of space in the root filesystem.



    Action / Repair:

    Free up space in the root filesystem
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    Hide
    


    Verify RDS Protocol is used for interprocess communication [Database Home]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The RDS protocol provides superior performance because it avoids additional memory buffering operations when moving data from process memory to the network interface for IO operations. This includes both IO operations between the Oracle instance and the storage servers, as well as instance to instance block transfers via Cache Fusion.

    There is minimal impact to verify that the RDS protocol is in use. Implementing the RDS protocol requires an outage to relink the Oracle software.

    Risk:

    If the RDS protocol is not used, IO operations will be sub-optimal.


    Action / Repair:

    To validate an ORACLE_HOME:
    As the owner userid of the ORACLE_HOME, set the ORACLE_HOME and LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables properly and execute the following command:

    $ORACLE_HOME/bin/skgxpinfo

    The output should be:

    rds

    To validate a CRS_HOME:
    As the owner userid of the CRS_HOME, set the CRS_HOME and LD_LIBRARY_PATH variables properly and execute the following command:

    $CRS_HOME/bin/skgxpinfo

    The output should be:

    rds

    If the RDS protocol is not being used, the appropriate binaries must be relinked.

        NOTE: In all cases, do not use the "relink all" command due to various issues. Use the make commands provided. 

    To relink an ORACLE_HOME:
    As the owner userid of the ORACLE_HOME execute the following steps with all necessary variables properly set:

        Shutdown any processes using the ORACLE_HOME
        "cd $ORACLE_HOME/rdbms/lib"
        "make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_rds ioracle"
        Restart any processes using the ORACLE_HOME 

    To relink a CRS_HOME:

        NOTE: The following instructions are for Oracle stack versions 12.2 or higher:

    As the owner userid of the CRS_HOME (and the "root" userid for some steps) execute the following steps with all necessary variables properly set:

        As the "root" userid, stop the clusterware runnning out of the CRS_HOME
        As the "root" userid, execute "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.sh -unlock"
        "cd $CRS_HOME/rdbms/lib"
        "make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_rds ioracle"
        As the "root" userid, execute "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.sh -lock"
        As the "root" userid, start the clusterware runnning out of the CRS_HOME
        After a few minutes, as the "root" userid verify all expected resources are executing with "$CRS_HOME/bin/crsctl stat res -t" 

        NOTE: The following instructions are for Oracle stack versions 12.1 or lower (including 11.2.x):

    As the owner userid of the CRS_HOME (and the "root" userid for some steps) execute the following steps with all necessary variables properly set:

        As the "root" userid, stop the clusterware runnning out of the CRS_HOME
        As the "root" userid, execute "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.pl -unlock"
        "cd $CRS_HOME/rdbms/lib"
        "make -f ins_rdbms.mk ipc_rds ioracle"
        As the "root" userid, "$CRS_HOME/crs/install/rootcrs.pl -patch"
        After a few minutes, as the "root" userid verify all expected resources are executing with "$CRS_HOME/bin/crsctl stat res -t" 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm03:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm02:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => Oracle database(s) are using RDS protocol for inter process communication
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify RDS Protocol is used for interprocess communication [Database Home] 



rds
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => Oracle database(s) are using RDS protocol for inter process communication
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify RDS Protocol is used for interprocess communication [Database Home] 



rds
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => Oracle database(s) are using RDS protocol for inter process communication
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify RDS Protocol is used for interprocess communication [Database Home] 



rds
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter filesystemio_options
    


    

    Recommendation
    Ensures both async and direct IO are used when accessing filesystems. This improves performance for filesystem I/O (ex: data loads). This does not affect database IO for Exadata because the database is stored in ASM.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1274318.1 - Oracle Sun Database Machine X2-2 Setup/Configuration Best Practices (Doc ID 1274318.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => filesystemio_options is set to recommended value
    whexa3p31.filesystemio_options = setall
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => filesystemio_options is set to recommended value
    whexa3p33.filesystemio_options = setall
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => filesystemio_options is set to recommended value
    whexa3p32.filesystemio_options = setall
    


    Hide

    RDBMS Version
    


    

    Recommendation
    The RBMS version for X2-2 is expected to be 11.2.0.2 or higher.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3

    RDBMS_VERSION              
--------------------------

    Hide
    


    ASM Version
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The components in the I/O stack are tightly integrated in Exadata. You must use the proper versions of software both on the storage servers and the database servers.
    There is minimal impact to verify the ASM version.



    Risk:

    If the ASM version is not correct, the database(s) will not be able to communicate with the storage servers via ASM.



    Action / Repair:

    Verify the Oracle ASM software is version 11.2.0.2 or higher
    If it is not, correct the condition.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => ASM Version is 11.2.0.2 or higher as expected
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - ASM VERSION 



version = 19.0.0.0.0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => ASM Version is 11.2.0.2 or higher as expected
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - ASM VERSION 



version = 19.0.0.0.0
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:+ASM2:
    PASS => ASM Version is 11.2.0.2 or higher as expected
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - ASM VERSION 



version = 19.0.0.0.0
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Cluster Synchronization Services (CSS) misscount value
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Cluster Synchronization Services (CSS) misscount affects the impact and timing of a clusterware node eviction. Please see the table below for recommendations and comments.

        NOTE: Exadata has a feature called Instant Failure Detection (or Fast Node Death Detection) which does not rely on CSS misscount. The node evictions referenced in this section are only the more rare types that cannot use this feature. 

    CSS Misscount Value Table

    VALUE 	ALERT LEVEL 	NOTES
    15 	SUCCESS 	This value is only for Autonomous Database Cloud environments which are specifically designed to optimize availability using a lower CSS misscount
    30 	SUCCESS 	Recommended to minimize application service level impact during node evictions
    less than 30 	CRITICAL 	Increases the risk of a false postive node eviction
    (except the value of 15 for Autonomous Database Cloud environments)
    greater than 60 	FAILURE 	Delays a node eviction longer than necessary, and can impact many application service levels
    31 to 60 	WARNING 	Delays a node eviction, and can impact some application service levels

        NOTE: In grid version 11.2.x 60 is the default and recommended value. If you are still running 11.2.x grid, a value of "60" will return "SUCCESS". Customers are urged to upgrade to more recent grid versions that support a CSS misscount value of 30.



    Risk:

    The risk of setting CSS misscount too low is hitting false positive node evictions. The risk of setting CSS misscount too high is delaying node evictions which can impact application service levels.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify Cluster Synchronization Services (CSS) misscount value, run Exachk and review the provided report.

    The expected output in the Exachk report should be as follows:

    In the "Findings Passed" summary section of the report, the overall result should be "PASS":

    PASS   OS Check   Cluster Synchronization Services (CSS) misscount value is set as recommended   All Database Servers   
    View

    In the "View" detail section of the report for each individual database server:

    Status on random01client01:
    PASS => Cluster Synchronization Services (CSS) misscount value is set as recommended

    DATA FROM RANDOM01CLIENT01 - VERIFY CLUSTER SYNCHRONIZATION SERVICES (CSS) MISSCOUNT VALUE 
    SUCCESS: recommended value: 30  Value found: 30

    Examples of other "SUCCESS" details:

    SUCCESS: ADB only recommended value: 15  Value found: 15

    -- OR --

    SUCCESS: 11.2 only recommended value: 60  Value found: 60

    Example of a "CRITICAL" result:

    CRITICAL: recommended value: 30  Value found: 25

    -- OR --

    CRITICAL: ADB only recommended value: 15  Value found: 30

    -- OR --

    CRITICAL: 11.2 only recommended value: 60  Value found: 90

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE: recommended value: 30  Value found: 65

    Example of a "WARNING" result:

    WARNING: recommended value: 30  Value found: 45

    To set the recommended CSS misscount value, as the owner userid of the grid home and with the environment properly set, execute the following code on a database server (takes effect on all nodes in a cluster without an Oracle Clusterware restart):

    $<GI_HOME>/bin/crsctl set css misscount 30

    The output will be similar to:

    CRS-4684: Successful set of parameter misscount to 30 for Cluster Synchronization Services

        NOTE: If after corrective actions are completed, you wish to run just this review manually without a full Exachk run, as the "root" userid execute the following Exachk command:

        exachk -check 9AD3948CEED6219DE040E50A1EC030AA
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1274322.1 - Oracle Sun Database Machine X2-2/X2-8 , X3-2/X3-8 and X4-2 High Availability Best Practices
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Cluster Synchronization Services (CSS) misscount value is set as recommended
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY CLUSTER SYNCHRONIZATION SERVICES (CSS) MISSCOUNT VALUE 



SUCCESS: recommended value: 30  Value found: 30
    


    Hide
    


    Verify DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM database parameter
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized.
    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal.
    The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.



    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM = FULL aids in block corruption detection. Enable for primary and standby databases
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1302539.1 - Best Practices for Corruption Detection, Prevention, and Automatic Repair - in a Data Guard Configuration
    2.  Protect Against Data Corruption 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM database parameter 



db_block_checksum value = FULL
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM database parameter 



db_block_checksum value = FULL
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM is set to recommended value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify DB_BLOCK_CHECKSUM database parameter 



db_block_checksum value = FULL
    


    Hide
    


    ASM disk group compatible.asm attribute
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The components in the I/O stack are tightly integrated in Exadata. You must use the proper versions of software both on the storage servers and the database servers. Setting compatible attributes defines available functionality. Setting CELL.SMART_SCAN_CAPABLE enables the offloading of certain query work to the storage servers. Setting AU_SIZE maximizes available disk technology and throughput by reading 4MB of data before performing a disk seek to a new sector location.

    There is minimal impact to verify and configure these settings.



    Risk:

    If these attributes are not set as directed, performance will be sub-optimal.



    Action / Repair:

    For the ASM disk group containing Oracle Exadata Storage Server grid disks, verify the attribute settings as follows: 

         * COMPATIBLE.ASM attribute is set to the Oracle ASM version in use.
         * COMPATIBLE.RDBMS attribute is set to the minimum Oracle database software version in use. 
         * CELL.SMART_SCAN_CAPABLE attribute is TRUE. 
         * AU_SIZE attribute is 4M. 

    If compatible.rdbms is not set properly, then the rdbms software version and database must be upgraded or the diskgroup must be recreated. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => All disk groups have compatible.asm attribute set to recommended values
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - ASM DISK GROUP COMPATIBLE.ASM ATTRIBUTE 



Oracle Clusterware active version on the cluster is [19.0.0.0.0]

ASM DATA_EXA3.compatible.asm = 19.0.0.0.0
ASM RECO_EXA3.compatible.asm = 19.0.0.0.0
    


    Hide
    


    ASM Cell smart scan
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The components in the I/O stack are tightly integrated in Exadata. You must use the proper versions of software both on the storage servers and the database servers. Setting compatible attributes defines available functionality. Setting CELL.SMART_SCAN_CAPABLE enables the offloading of certain query work to the storage servers. Setting AU_SIZE maximizes available disk technology and throughput by reading 4MB of data before performing a disk seek to a new sector location.
    There is minimal impact to verify and configure these settings.


    Risk:

    If these attributes are not set as directed, performance will be sub-optimal.



    Action / Repair:

    For the ASM disk group containing Oracle Exadata Storage Server grid disks, verify the attribute settings as follows:
    COMPATIBLE.ASM attribute is set to the Oracle ASM software version in use.
    COMPATIBLE.RDBMS attribute is set to the Oracle database software version in use.
    CELL.SMART_SCAN_CAPABLE attribute is TRUE.
    AU_SIZE attribute is 4M.
    If these attributes are not set properly, correct the condition.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => All disk groups have CELL.SMART_SCAN_CAPABLE parameter set to true
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - ASM CELL SMART SCAN 



ASM DATA_EXA3.cell.smart_scan_capable = TRUE
ASM RECO_EXA3.cell.smart_scan_capable = TRUE
    


    Hide
    


    ASM disk group compatible.rdbms attribute
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and MAA testing has shown that certain diskgroup attributes should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these diskgroup attributes as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The attributes are specific to ASM diskgroups. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal. 


    Risk:

    If the diskgroup attributes are not set as recommended, performance and or availability issues can be encountered. 



    Action / Repair:

    It is recommended that compatible.rdbms be set to the lowest RDBMS version that will ever be used in this Cluster.

    NOTE: Reducing "compatible.rdbms" to an lower version from a higher version requires the diskgroup to be rebuilt. Therefore, the value of "compatible.rdbms" should be carefully analyzed and set according to customer requirements and business plans.

    NOTE: For new Exadata deployments, the "compatible.rdbms" disk group attribute is set to the lowest database version supported that contains the features described in this best practice.  For example, with GI 23ai, the lowest database supported is RDBMS 19c, and thus all GI 23ai disk groups will have the compatible.rdbms attribute set to 19.0.

    NOTE: important features for Exadata that are enabled via compatible.rdbms are listed below. For the complete set, see the ASM documentation.

        Appliance mode and fixed partnering with compatible.asm=12.1.0.2
        Disk resync checkpointing with compatible.rdbms=12.1.0.2
        Sparse disk group with with compatible.rdbms=12.1.0.2
        Extended and Flex disk groups with compatible.rdbms=12.2.0.1
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => All disk groups have compatible.rdbms attribute set to recommended values
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - ASM DISK GROUP COMPATIBLE.RDBMS ATTRIBUTE 



Lowest supported Oracle database version = 11.2.0.4. We highly recommend attribute compatible.rdbms to be higher or equal to such version. 
 
 The following disk groups have compatible.rdbms attribute set to recommended values:  
 ASM DATA_EXA3.compatible.rdbms = 12.1.0.2  
 ASM RECO_EXA3.compatible.rdbms = 12.1.0.2
    


    Hide
    


    ASM allocation unit size for all disk groups
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    In order to achieve fast disk scan rates with today's disk technology, it is important that segments be laid out on disk with at least 4MB of contiguous disk space. This allows disk scans to read 4MB of data from disk before having to perform a seek to another location on disk and therefore ensures that most of the time during a scan is spent transferring data from disk.



    Risk:

    Time could be spent seeking between disk locations for data. 



    Action / Repair:

    To ensure that segments are laid out with 4MB of contiguous data on disk, you will need to set the ASM allocation unit (AU) size to 4MB and ensure that data file extents are at least 4MB in size. The ASM allocation unit can be specified when a disk group is created. For Exadata, we recommend setting the AU size to 4MB. The ASM allocation unit size (AU_SIZE) can be set at disk group creation time as can be seen in the following example:

    CREATE diskgroup data normal redundancy 
    DISK 'o/*/DATA*'
    ATTRIBUTE 
              'AU_SIZE' = '4M',
              'cell.smart_scan_capable'='TRUE',
              'compatible.rdbms'='11.2.0.0', 
              'compatible.asm'='11.2.0.0';
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => All disk groups have allocation unit size set to 4MB
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - ASM ALLOCATION UNIT SIZE FOR ALL DISK GROUPS 



ASM DATA_EXA3.au_size = 4194304
ASM RECO_EXA3.au_size = 4194304
    


    Hide
    


    Verify the currently active image status [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The currently active image status for either a database or storage server should always be "success". The impact of verification is minimal. The impact of correcting a status other than "success" depends upon the root cause of the deviation, and cannot be estimated here.

    Risk:

    If the currently active image status is not "success" unpredictable behavior such as crashing, failure to boot, poor performance, etc.. is likely.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify the currently active image status execute the following command set as the root userid on all database and storage servers:

    FULL_DETAILS=$(imageinfo)
    if [[ $(echo "$FULL_DETAILS" | egrep "^Image status:|^Active image status:" | egrep -iwc "success") -eq 1 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: the currently active image status is \"success\"."
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: the currently active image status is not \"success\".  Details:\n$FULL_DETAILS"
    fi

    The expected output should be

    SUCCESS: the currently active image status is "success".

    Example of a database server "FAILURE:" result:

    FAILURE: the currently active image status is not "success".  Details:

    Kernel version: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.el7uek.x86_64 #2 SMP Fri Aug 23 20:48:29 GMT 2019 x86_64
    Image kernel version: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.el7uek
    Image version: 19.3.0.0.0.190909
    Image activated: 2019-09-09 12:03:36 -0700
    Image status: failure
    Node type: KVMHOST
    System partition on device: /dev/mapper/VGExaDb-LVDbSys1

    Example of a storage server "FAILURE:" result:

    FAILURE: the currently active image status is not "success".  Details:

    Kernel version: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.2.el7uek.x86_64 #2 SMP Sat Sep 14 19:30:38 GMT 2019 x86_64
    Cell version: OSS_MAIN_LINUX.X64_190919
    Cell rpm version: cell-19.4.0.0.0_LINUX.X64_190919-1.x86_64

    Active node type: STORAGE

    Rollback to the inactive partitions: Possible

    If the output is not "SUCCESS:", investigate root cause and implement corrective action.

    Verify Exafusion Memory Lock Configuration
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Having memlock set correctly is required for a successful upgrade to releases 12.2 and higher, and also to prevent ORA- errors associated with IPC context initialization. The impact of verifying the Exafusion memory lock configuration is minimal. Following any modifications to the limits.conf settings, a logout/login is required for the OS user to ensure the changes take effect.

        NOTE: The memlock settings should be correct according to recommendations regardless of whether Exafusion is actually being used or not (it is enabled by default in 12.2).

    Risk:

    Instance startup will fail, and/or clients will fail to connect if memlock settings are insufficient. 

    Action / Repair:

    To verify Exafusion memory lock configuration, run Exachk and review the provided report.

    In the "Findings Passed" summary section of the report, the overall result should be "PASS":

    PASS   OS Check   Memlock settings meet the Oracle best practice recommendations      All Database Servers   View

    In the "View" detail section of the report for this check the expected output should be similar to:

    Status on randomadm05vm01:
    PASS => Memlock settings meet the Oracle best practice recommendations

    DATA FROM RANDOMADM05VM01 - VERIFY EXAFUSION MEMORY LOCK CONFIGURATION 

    SUCCESS: Memlock settings meet the Oracle best practices

    In the "View" detail section of the report for this check a "FAILURE" example will be similar to:

    Status on random01client01:/u01/app/ora11g/product/11.2.0.4/dbhome_1:
    FAIL => Memlock settings do not meet the Oracle best practice recommendations

    DATA FROM random01client01 - /u01/app/ora11g/product/11.2.0.4/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify Exafusion Memory Lock Configuration 




    FAILURE: the following required memlock settings are missing in ()
    ------
    oradb11g hard memlock unlimited
    oradb11g soft memlock unlimited
    ------
     FAILURE: oradb11g must have an unlimited setting (oradb11g hard memlock 237284280 file:/opt/vw_30657605/.exachk_120720_180218/.exachk_120720_180218/limits_copy.conf)
     FAILURE: oradb11g must have an unlimited setting (oradb11g soft memlock 237284280 file:/opt/vw_30657605/.exachk_120720_180218/.exachk_120720_180218/limits_copy.conf)

    If a "FAILURE" or "WARNING" message appears, make the necessary edits to "/etc/security/limits.conf" and files under "/etc/security/limits.d/" as directed.

        NOTE: If after corrective actions are completed, you wish to run just this review manually without a full Exachk run, as the "root" userid in the directory in which Exachk was installed, execute the following:

        ./exachk -check 935C913EDAB919C3E053D198EB0A3995
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm03:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm02:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => Memlock settings meet the Oracle best practice recommendations
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify Exafusion Memory Lock Configuration

*    soft     memlock  32768

    Exadata Critical Issue EX54
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 29645783, shortly after software upgrade hard disks may fail on High Capacity storage servers with 8 TB or 10 TB disk drives. If this issue occurs on partner disk drives on multiple storage servers when performing non-rolling upgrade, then one or more ASM disk groups may be forcibly dismounted and lost, requiring restore from backup.

    NOTE - This system is at risk of hitting issue EX54 ONLY during software update.  Operations outside of a software update window are unaffected.  
    Before performing the next software update it is imperative to review the details of issue EX54 in below MOS Document 1270094.1.

    Action / Repair:

    See  Exadata Critical Issue EX54 in below Exadata Critical Issue MOS Note
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX54
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX54 


Exadata Image Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX54 


Exadata Image Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX54 


Exadata Image Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX54

    Exadata Critical Issue EX56
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability. 

    Risk:

    Due to unpublished bug 29797007, database servers (non-OVM, domU, or dom0) running an Exadata release with kernel version 4.1.12-124.26.12 (i.e. Exadata 18.1.16, 18.1.17, 18.1.18, 19.2.2, 19.2.3, and 19.2.4) will incorrectly detect corruption and fail to mount an ext4 file system that has the meta_bg feature set. 

    Action / Repair:

    See  Exadata Critical Issue EX56in below Exadata Critical Issue MOS Note
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-

    Verify available ksplice fixes are installed [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    On Exadata systems some Oracle Linux operating system updates are delivered via ksplice. All available ksplice updates should be installed to ensure issues fixed in the installed Exadata release are not encountered.

    Risk:

    Not having all available ksplice updates installed can lead to unexpected behavior caused by encountering issues that are expected to be fixed in the installed Exadata release. The risk of checking that all available ksplice updates are installed is minimal.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify all available ksplice updates are installed run the following command set as the root user on each database and storage server:

    if rpm -qa|grep -q uptrack-updates-$(uname -r)
    then
      RAW_UPTRACK_SHOW=$(uptrack-show --available 2>&1)
      availUpdates=$(echo "$RAW_UPTRACK_SHOW" | grep -A1 'Available updates:' | tail -1)
      if [[ "$availUpdates" == 'None' ]]
      then
        echo 'SUCCESS: All available ksplice updates are installed.'
      else
        echo -e "FAIL: All available ksplice updates are not installed. Run 'uptrack-install --all -y' as the root user.  Details:\n$RAW_UPTRACK_SHOW"
      fi
    else
      echo 'SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.'
    fi

    The expected output is the following:

    SUCCESS: All available ksplice updates are installed.

    -- OR --

    SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.

    Example of a FAIL result:

    FAIL: All available ksplice updates are not installed. Run 'uptrack-install --all -y' as the root user.  Details:
    Available updates:
    [8x4eqo27] Improved fix to CVE-2018-3620, CVE-2018-3646: Information leak in Intel CPUs under terminal fault.

    Effective kernel version is 4.1.12-94.8.6.el6uek

    If there are available ksplice updates not installed then run uptrack-install as the root user, as follows:

    # uptrack-install --all -y
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => All available ksplice fixes are installed, or ksplice not in use
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY AVAILABLE KSPLICE FIXES ARE INSTALLED [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => All available ksplice fixes are installed, or ksplice not in use
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY AVAILABLE KSPLICE FIXES ARE INSTALLED [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => All available ksplice fixes are installed, or ksplice not in use
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY AVAILABLE KSPLICE FIXES ARE INSTALLED [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.
    


    Hide
    


    Verify available ksplice fixes are installed [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    On Exadata systems some Oracle Linux operating system updates are delivered via ksplice. All available ksplice updates should be installed to ensure issues fixed in the installed Exadata release are not encountered.

    Risk:

    Not having all available ksplice updates installed can lead to unexpected behavior caused by encountering issues that are expected to be fixed in the installed Exadata release. The risk of checking that all available ksplice updates are installed is minimal.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify all available ksplice updates are installed run the following command set as the root user on each database and storage server:

    if rpm -qa|grep -q uptrack-updates-$(uname -r)
    then
      RAW_UPTRACK_SHOW=$(uptrack-show --available 2>&1)
      availUpdates=$(echo "$RAW_UPTRACK_SHOW" | grep -A1 'Available updates:' | tail -1)
      if [[ "$availUpdates" == 'None' ]]
      then
        echo 'SUCCESS: All available ksplice updates are installed.'
      else
        echo -e "FAIL: All available ksplice updates are not installed. Run 'uptrack-install --all -y' as the root user.  Details:\n$RAW_UPTRACK_SHOW"
      fi
    else
      echo 'SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.'
    fi

    The expected output is the following:

    SUCCESS: All available ksplice updates are installed.

    -- OR --

    SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.

    Example of a FAIL result:

    FAIL: All available ksplice updates are not installed. Run 'uptrack-install --all -y' as the root user.  Details:
    Available updates:
    [8x4eqo27] Improved fix to CVE-2018-3620, CVE-2018-3646: Information leak in Intel CPUs under terminal fault.

    Effective kernel version is 4.1.12-94.8.6.el6uek

    If there are available ksplice updates not installed then run uptrack-install as the root user, as follows:

    # uptrack-install --all -y
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => All available ksplice fixes are installed, or ksplice not in use
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify available ksplice fixes are installed [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify available ksplice fixes are installed [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify available ksplice fixes are installed [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify available ksplice fixes are installed [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS: ksplice updates are not used on this system.
