    Evaluate database parameter processes for versions 12 and higher
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The values presented here are based upon internal testing and provide maximum reliability with generally acceptable performance.

    The minimum recommended values  for database servers with five or less active instances are based on socket counts:

    2 socket servers - minimum of 1024
    8 socket servers - minimum of 2048


    Risk:

    Not properly testing and setting the processes parameter can lead to problems.

    Action / Repair:

    Customers should always perform due diligence testing based upon traditional application / system tuning, coupled with analysis of application uptime requirements, to determine the appropriate setting for their application environment. For larger numbers of deployed databases, during the testing please also refer to Consolidation Parameters Reference Table.

    Once the appropriate testing has been done, customers may change this parameter as needed to meet their requirements and ignore this basic guidance. 

    Please refer to the version specific Oracle documentation for guidance on adjusting this parameter.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1465230.1 - Resizing Grid Disks in Exadata: Example of Recreating RECO Grid Disks in a Rolling Manner
    2.  Note: 1551288.1 - Understanding ASM Capacity and Reservation of Free Space in Exadata
    3.  Note: 757552.1 - Oracle Exadata Best Practices
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    INFO => Please refer to data and guidance provided for database parameter processes
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Evaluate database parameter processes for versions 12 and higher 



INFO: processes parameter value (2048) meets or exceeds recommended minimum: 2048
Please refer to guidance provided in Action / Repair concerning appropriate testing.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    INFO => Please refer to data and guidance provided for database parameter processes
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Evaluate database parameter processes for versions 12 and higher 



INFO: processes parameter value (2048) meets or exceeds recommended minimum: 2048
Please refer to guidance provided in Action / Repair concerning appropriate testing.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    INFO => Please refer to data and guidance provided for database parameter processes
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Evaluate database parameter processes for versions 12 and higher 



INFO: processes parameter value (2048) meets or exceeds recommended minimum: 2048
Please refer to guidance provided in Action / Repair concerning appropriate testing.
    


    Hide
    


    Verify the Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) configuration
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    By default, Exadata uses NSCD to cache the most common name service requests (e.g. passwords, hosts and groups). Nevertheless, SSSD (System Security Services Daemon) can also be configured to provide cache for system services, such as Name Service Switch (NSS) and Pluggable Authentication Modules (PAM). NSCD default configuration, used by Exadata, conflicts with SSSD cache operations. Hence, the NSCD configuration must be verified to prevent cache conflicts between services and unexpected system behavior.

    Risk:

    If NCSD and SSSD are both configured to cache the same system resources, OS processes may use the incorrect cache service. Typical problems include CRS start failure due to an invalid password and new connections to the database failing due to invalid password error (ORA-1031, ORA-1017).

    Action / Repair:

    In Exadata database nodes and storage servers, the NSCD service must be active and enabled (to start upon system reboots and upgrades). At the same time, the configuration present in /etc/nscd.conf must match the memory-loaded configuration used by NSCD service.  Additionally, if the SSSD service is active and configured, the NSCD configuration must be customized to comply with the SSSD cache operations.

        Use the following command to check the NSCD service status in Oracle Linux 6:

        $ service nscd status

        Use the following command to check the NSCD service status in Oracle Linux 7 and later versions:

        $ systemctl status nscd.service

        Use the following command to check the SSSD service status in Oracle Linux 7 and later versions:

        $ systemctl status sssd.service

        If needed, use the following commands to stop and disaled the SSSD service in Oracle Linux 7 and later versions:

        $ systemctl stop sssd.service
        $ systemctl disable --now sssd.service

        If the NSCD service unit is not enabled, execute the following command:

        systemctl enable --now nscd.service

        If the SSSD service is active and configured, modify the NSCD configuration file and restart the NSCD service. Perform the following steps:

        NOTE: Detailed example and technical justifications may be found in "LDAP configuration example in Exadata compute nodes and storage servers using SSSD (Doc ID 3020122.1)".

            In the /etc/nscd.conf file, enter the following content:

            enable-cache            passwd          no
            enable-cache            group           no
            enable-cache            hosts           yes
            enable-cache            services        no
            enable-cache            netgroup        no

            Restart the NSCD service:

            systemctl restart nscd.service
                    

        If the SSSD service it not configured or is not active, use the default NSCD configuration provided by Exadata. Perform the following steps:
            In the /etc/nscd.conf file, enter the following content:

            enable-cache            passwd          yes
            enable-cache            group           yes
            enable-cache            hosts           yes
            enable-cache            services        yes
            enable-cache            netgroup        no

            Restart the NSCD service:

            systemctl restart nscd.service
              

        If the configuration present in /etc/nscd.conf does not match the memory-loaded configuration used by NSCD, restart the NSCD service. Use the following command:

        systemctl restart nscd.service
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    UNDETERMINED => The Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) configuration is not correct
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY THE NAME SERVICE CACHE DAEMON (NSCD) CONFIGURATION



UNDETERMINED: Unable to collect SSSD service data. Check the service status for any errors or misconfigurations.
      
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    UNDETERMINED => The Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) configuration is not correct
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY THE NAME SERVICE CACHE DAEMON (NSCD) CONFIGURATION



UNDETERMINED: Unable to collect SSSD service data. Check the service status for any errors or misconfigurations.
      
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    UNDETERMINED => The Name Service Cache Daemon (NSCD) configuration is not correct
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY THE NAME SERVICE CACHE DAEMON (NSCD) CONFIGURATION



UNDETERMINED: Unable to collect SSSD service data. Check the service status for any errors or misconfigurations.
      
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX55
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to 
    performance or availability. 

    Risk:

    Due to bug 29871722, a daily cron job scheduled for approximately 3am on 
    database servers that runs the /opt/oracle.cellos/genCellRoute.sh script 
    causes RDS connection reset to storage servers. RDS connection reset can 
    cause diskmon split-brain with regard to storage server connectivity, which 
    can lead to database server eviction and reboot to resolve the diskmon 
    split-brain condition. 

    Action / Repair:

    Run the following Exachk command to repair this issue on this system:
    Note: This Exachk repair command must be run as the root user.

    ./exachk -repaircheck all -check 8DC65FF147E791FEE053D198EB0AE642

    Actions taken by this Exachk repair:

    1. On each database server
    # touch /etc/exadata/DISABLE_RDS_RESET_FOR_DUP_HWADDR 

    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check 8DC65FF147E791FEE053D198EB0AE642".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair 8DC65FF147E791FEE053D198EB0AE642".
    

    Links
    1.  Doc ID 2560543.1 - (EX55) RDS connection reset by genCellRoute.sh to one or more storage servers may cause database server node eviction 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX55
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX55



Image Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX55
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX55



Image Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX55
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX55



Image Version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808
    


    Hide
    


    Oracle database software owner soft nproc shell limit
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The soft nproc shell limit for the Oracle DB software install owner as defined in /etc/security/limits.conf should be >= 2047.

    Risk:

    The soft nproc shell limit for the Oracle DB software install owner as defined in /etc/security/limits.conf should be >= 2047.  As long as the soft nproc limit is 2047 or above then the configuration should be OK.



    Action / Repair:

    Change DB software install owner soft nproc shell limit

    $ ulimit -Su
    2047

    

    Links
    1.  Note: 169706.1 - Oracle Database OS Installation and Configuration Requirements Quick Reference
    2.  Note: 788480.1 - Resource Limits Using /etc/security/limits.conf and /etc/profile
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Oracle database software owner soft nproc shell limit  is configured according to recommendation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - ORACLE DATABASE SOFTWARE OWNER SOFT NPROC SHELL LIMIT 




oracle user's soft nproc shell limit = 400000
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Oracle database software owner soft nproc shell limit  is configured according to recommendation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - ORACLE DATABASE SOFTWARE OWNER SOFT NPROC SHELL LIMIT 




oracle user's soft nproc shell limit = 400000
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Oracle database software owner soft nproc shell limit  is configured according to recommendation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - ORACLE DATABASE SOFTWARE OWNER SOFT NPROC SHELL LIMIT 




oracle user's soft nproc shell limit = 400000
    


    Hide
    


    Oracle database software owner hard nofile shell limits
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The hard nofile shell limit for the Oracle database software install owner as defined in /etc/security/limits.conf should be >= 65536.

    Risk:

    Resource starvation (file descriptors) leading to node instability
    

    Links
    1.  Setting Resource Limits for the Oracle Software Installation Users 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX51
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability

    Risk:

    When I/O Resource Management (IORM) is configured to manage flash cache on storage servers running Exadata 18.1.10, 18.1.11, or 18.1.12, the cellsrv process may crash with error ORA-600 [FCGroupDesc::decLocalCnt_underflow].  

    If the cellsrv process crashes on multiple partner storage servers at the same time, then one or more ASM disk groups may dismount causing database or clusterware shutdown. 

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX51 in below document 1270094.1 for additional details
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX51
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX51 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX51 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX51 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX51 


Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX50
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability

    Risk:

    Kernel service systemd-tmpfiles-clean.service may remove required socket 
    files in /var/tmp/.oracle, which may cause database startup or connections to 
    fail, or clusterware connection to fail on Exadata database servers running 
    Oracle Linux 7 (i.e. Exadata 19.1). 

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX50 in below document 1270094.1 for additional details

    Or you can use Exachk's repair functionality to repair this check on all nodes in cluster  using ./exachk -repair all -check 811C6F7E69AB3871E053D498EB0A8EE0 -dbnone -showpass

    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check 811C6F7E69AB3871E053D498EB0A8EE0".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair 811C6F7E69AB3871E053D498EB0A8EE0".
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX50
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR EXADATA CRITICAL ISSUE EX50



Exadata Software version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808
Contents of /usr/lib/tmpfiles.d/tmp.conf:-


v /tmp 1777 root root 10d
v /var/tmp 1777 root root 30d

x /tmp/systemd-private-%b-*
X /tmp/systemd-private-%b-*/tmp
x /var/tmp/systemd-private-%b-*
X /var/tmp/systemd-private-%b-*/tmp

x /var/tmp/systemd-private-%b-*
X /var/tmp/systemd-private-%b-*/tmp

    Verify database parameter AUDIT_TRAIL
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Setting the database parameter AUDIT_TRAIL to either "db" or "db, extended" is a recommended security optimization.

    Risk:

    Lack of database activity audit records.

    Action / Repair:

    If AUDIT_TRAIL is not set as recommended, correct the setting.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3

    Hide
    


    Verify RAID disk controller CacheVault capacitor condition [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The CacheVault capacitor loses its ability to support cache over time. Verifying the CacheVault capacitor condition helps to reasonably time proactive replacement.

    The impact of verifying the CacheVault capacitor condition is minimal. Replacing the CacheVault will require downtime for the impacted server. 

    Risk:

    A failed CacheVault capacitor will put the RAID controller into WriteThrough mode which significantly impacts write I/O performance. 

    Action / Repair:

    NOTE: This check is not applicable to Extreme Flash Oracle Exadata Storage Servers nor X7-8 Oracle Exadata Database Servers as they contain no conventional disk drives!

    Execute the following command as the "root" userid on all storage and database servers:

    RAW_OUTPUT=$(/opt/MegaRAID/storcli/storcli64 /c0/cv show all)
    if [[ $(echo "$RAW_OUTPUT" | egrep -i "^state" | egrep -ic optimal)  -eq 1 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: raid controller CacheVault condition is optimal."
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: raid controller CacheVault condition is not optimal.  Details:\n\n$RAW_OUTPUT"
    fi

    The expected output should be:

    SUCCESS: raid controller CacheVault condition is optimal.

    If the output is a "FAILURE" message, upload the detailed information provided into a hardware service request for component replacement. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => The RAID disk controller CacheVault capacitor condition is "Optimal"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY RAID DISK CONTROLLER CACHEVAULT CAPACITOR CONDITION [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: raid controller CacheVault condition is optimal.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => The RAID disk controller CacheVault capacitor condition is "Optimal"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY RAID DISK CONTROLLER CACHEVAULT CAPACITOR CONDITION [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: raid controller CacheVault condition is optimal.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => The RAID disk controller CacheVault capacitor condition is "Optimal"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY RAID DISK CONTROLLER CACHEVAULT CAPACITOR CONDITION [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: raid controller CacheVault condition is optimal.
    


    Hide
    


    Verify RAID disk controller CacheVault capacitor condition [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The CacheVault capacitor loses its ability to support cache over time. Verifying the CacheVault capacitor condition helps to reasonably time proactive replacement.

    The impact of verifying the CacheVault capacitor condition is minimal. Replacing the CacheVault will require downtime for the impacted server. 

    Risk:

    A failed CacheVault capacitor will put the RAID controller into WriteThrough mode which significantly impacts write I/O performance. 

    Action / Repair:

    NOTE: This check is not applicable to Extreme Flash Oracle Exadata Storage Servers nor X7-8 Oracle Exadata Database Servers as they contain no conventional disk drives!

    Execute the following command as the "root" userid on all storage and database servers:

    RAW_OUTPUT=$(/opt/MegaRAID/storcli/storcli64 /c0/cv show all)
    if [[ $(echo "$RAW_OUTPUT" | egrep -i "^state" | egrep -ic optimal)  -eq 1 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: raid controller CacheVault condition is optimal."
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: raid controller CacheVault condition is not optimal.  Details:\n\n$RAW_OUTPUT"
    fi

    The expected output should be:

    SUCCESS: raid controller CacheVault condition is optimal.

    If the output is a "FAILURE" message, upload the detailed information provided into a hardware service request for component replacement.
    

    Needs attention on-

    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX47
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability

    Risk:

    Storage servers with hard disks using IORM objective auto, low_latency, or balanced, and running one of the following versions: 12.1.2.3.7, or 12.2.1.1.3 through 12.2.1.1.6, or 18.1.0 through 18.1.4 - IORM incorrectly calculates hard disk utilization, causing IOs to queue and limiting the number of IOs issued to hard disks, which can lead to poor database performance or voting disk write timeouts

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX47 in below document 1270094.1 for additional details
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02

    Exadata Critical Issue EX45
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to performance or availability. 

    Risk:

    Applies to Storage servers running Exadata version between 12.1.2.1.0 and 12.1.2.3.3, inclusive - When a flash disk fails a flash cache read miss does not result in populating the flash cache, causing reads to continually be satisfied by hard disk instead of flash cache. As a result, database 
    performance read performance may suffer significantly

    Action / Repair:

    See EX45 below MOS not for action/repair
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02

    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX45 


Exadata Version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX45 


Exadata Version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX45 


Exadata Version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX45 


Exadata Version = 20.1.1.0.0.200808

    


    Hide
    


    Verify proper ACFS drivers are installed for Spectre v2 mitigation
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    On Exadata database servers that have an Exadata version installed that provides mitigation for Spectre v2 vulnerability, proper ACFS drivers or other customer-installed kernel drivers must be installed in order for the proper Spectre v2 mitigation to be used.

    Installing proper ACFS drivers requires server (or VM) reboot. The impact of installing proper customer-installed kernel drivers cannot be estimated here.

    Risk:

    Not using the proper ACFS drivers or other customer-installed kernel drivers can prevent the desired Spectre v2 mitigation, which can lead to severely degraded performance for all database workloads, even if ACFS is not being used.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify proper ACFS drivers are installed for Spectre v2 mitigation, execute the following command set as the "root" userid on all database servers:

    #!/bin/bash
    # CPU model numbers (/proc/cpuinfo)
    # V2:26 X2-2:44 X2-8:46 X2-8M2:47 X3:45 X4:62 X5:63 X6:79 X7:85
    modelsUseRetpoline='26|44|46|47|45|62|63|79'
    thisModel=$(egrep "^model[[:space:]]*:" /proc/cpuinfo | sort -u | awk '{print $NF}')
    # kernels without spectrev2 mitigation will not have this file
    if [[ ! -e /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spectre_v2 ]]; then
     echo "WARNING: System is not capable of Spectre v2 mitigation. See minimum version requirements in MOS document 2356385.1."
    else
     v2mitigation=$(</sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spectre_v2)
     # dom0 should use retpoline for all hardware
     # X6 and older should use retpoline
     wantRetpoline=no
      if (  [[ -d /proc/xen/capabilities ]] && grep -q 'control_d' /proc/xen/capabilities ) || echo "$thisModel" | egrep -q "$modelsUseRetpoline"; then
      wantRetpoline=yes
     fi
     if [[ $wantRetpoline == yes ]]; then
      if ! echo $v2mitigation | grep -qi retpoline; then
       echo "FAIL: Spectre v2 mitigation is expected to be retpoline, but is not."
       if dmesg | grep -q 'Disabling Spectre v2 mitigation retpoline'; then
        echo "Spectre v2 mitigation retpoline was disabled after system boot."
        # look for modules not compiled with retpoline
        badmodules=$(dmesg | grep 'loading module not compiled with retpoline compiler' | awk -F '[]:]' '{print $2}' | tr '\012' ' ')
        echo "Modules loaded not compiled with retpoline compiler: $badmodules. These modules must be updated."
        if [[ $badmodules =~ oracleoks ]]; then
         echo "oracleoks module will be updated by installing updated ACFS drivers. See MOS document 2356385.1."
        fi
       fi
      else
       echo "SUCCESS: Spectre v2 mitigation is using $v2mitigation"
      fi
     else
      echo "SUCCESS: Spectre v2 mitigation is using $v2mitigation"
     fi
    fi

    The expected output is:

    SUCCESS: Spectre v2 mitigation is using Mitigation: Full generic retpoline, IBRS_FW, IBPB

    -OR-

    SUCCESS: Spectre v2 mitigation is using Mitigation: IBRS, IBRS_FW, IBPB

    Example of a "WARNING" result:

    WARNING: System is not capable of Spectre v2 mitigation.  See minimum version requirements in MOS document 2356385.1.

    In the above "WARNING" example, the system should be upgraded per the MOS note.

    Example of a "FAIL" result:

    FAIL: Spectre v2 mitigation is expected to be retpoline, but is not.  Spectre v2 mitigation retpoline was disabled after system boot.  Modules loaded not compiled with retpoline compiler: oracleoks. These modules must be updated.  oracleoks module will be updated by installing updated ACFS drivers.  See: MOS document 2356385.1.

    In the above FAIL, the system was expected to be using retpoline mitigation for Spectre v2, but was not. The system initially booted with retpoline mitigation, but it was disabled when an improper kernel module was loaded that caused retpoline mitigation to be disabled. 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1633603.1 - How to Setup Diagnostic Directory Group Permissions for Platinum Automated Diagnostic Upload
    2.  Note: 2356385.1 - Oracle Exadata Database Machine Patch Availability Document for CVE-2017-5715, CVE-2017-5753, and CVE-2017-5754
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => All database servers are using the expected Spectre v2 mitigation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY PROPER ACFS DRIVERS ARE INSTALLED FOR SPECTRE V2 MITIGATION



SUCCESS: Spectre v2 mitigation is using Mitigation: Enhanced IBRS, IBPB: conditional
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => All database servers are using the expected Spectre v2 mitigation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY PROPER ACFS DRIVERS ARE INSTALLED FOR SPECTRE V2 MITIGATION



SUCCESS: Spectre v2 mitigation is using Mitigation: Enhanced IBRS, IBPB: conditional
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => All database servers are using the expected Spectre v2 mitigation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY PROPER ACFS DRIVERS ARE INSTALLED FOR SPECTRE V2 MITIGATION



SUCCESS: Spectre v2 mitigation is using Mitigation: Enhanced IBRS, IBPB: conditional
    


    Hide
    


    Evaluate Automated Maintenance Tasks configuration
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Some automated maintenance tasks are enabled by default with default settings at database creation time. It is recommended that these automated tasks be allowed to run, but that they are reviewed and adjusted if necessary to provide the most benefit for a given environment's workload. Benefits are provided by improving the overall efficiency of an environment, and also from not having the automated maintenance tasks themselves negatively impact the environment's specific workload.

    Risk:

    Leaving automated maintenance tasks at their default values, or disabling them completely may significantly impact a given environment's specific workload performance.

    Action / Repair:

    To see basic information on automated maintenance tasks, as the owner of the oracle home for a given database and with the environment set to access that database, execute the following command set:

    FORMATTED_OUTPUT=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set newpage none head off lines 80 feedback off timing off serveroutput on
    select client_name,status from DBA_AUTOTASK_CLIENT;
    exit
    EOF
    )
    LINE_COUNT=$(echo "$FORMATTED_OUTPUT" | wc -l)
    ENABLED_COUNT=$(echo "$FORMATTED_OUTPUT" | egrep -ic enabled)
    if [ $LINE_COUNT -eq $ENABLED_COUNT ]
    then 
      echo -e "INFO: all automated maintenance tasks are enabled."
      echo -e "Please review configuration appropriateness for this environment."
    else 
      echo -e "WARNING: one or more automated maintenance tasks are not enabled."
      echo -e "Please enable all and review configuration appropriateness for this environment.\nDetails:\n$FORMATTED_OUTPUT" 
    fi;

    The expected output should be similar to:

    INFO: all automated maintenance tasks are enabled.
    Please review configuration appropriateness for this environment.

    Example of a "WARNING" result:

    WARNING: one or more automated maintenance tasks are not enabled.
    Please enable all and review configuration appropriateness for this environment.
    Details:
    sql tuning advisor                                               ENABLED
    auto optimizer stats collection                                  ENABLED
    auto space advisor                                               DISABLED

        NOTE:
        Oracle recommends that Oracle supplied automated maintenance tasks be utilized and tuned for each individual database and it's associated workload.
        For more information, please see:
        Database Administrator's Guide, 11g Release 2, Managing Automated Database Maintenance Tasks
        Database Administrator's Guide, 12c Release 1, Managing Automated Database Maintenance Tasks
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1465230.1 - Resizing Grid Disks in Exadata: Example of Recreating RECO Grid Disks in a Rolling Manner
    2.  Note: 1551288.1 - Understanding ASM Capacity and Reservation of Free Space in Exadata
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => All automated maintenance tasks are enabled
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Evaluate Automated Maintenance Tasks configuration 



INFO: all automated maintenance tasks are enabled.
Please review configuration appropriateness for this environment.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => All automated maintenance tasks are enabled
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Evaluate Automated Maintenance Tasks configuration 



INFO: all automated maintenance tasks are enabled.
Please review configuration appropriateness for this environment.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => All automated maintenance tasks are enabled
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Evaluate Automated Maintenance Tasks configuration 



INFO: all automated maintenance tasks are enabled.
Please review configuration appropriateness for this environment.
    


    Hide
    


    Verify sys and system users default tablespace is system
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    It's recommended to Keep the Default Tablespace for SYS and SYSTEM Schema mapped to the Default SYSTEM. All Standard Dictionary objects as well as all the added option will be located in the same place with no risk to record Dictionary data in other Datafiles.



    Risk:

    If Default tablespace for SYS and SYSTEM is not set to SYSTEM, Data dictionary Object can be created in other locations and cannot be controlled during maintenance activities of the database. Due to this, there's a potential risk to run into severe Data Dictionary Corruption that may implicate time consuming Recovery Steps.

    Action / Repair:

    If SYS or SYSTEM schema have a Default Tablespace different than SYSTEM, it's recommended to follow instruction given into Note ID : 1111111.2

    SQL> SELECT username, default_tablespace
         FROM dba_users
         WHERE username in ('SYS','SYSTEM');

    If  DEFAULT_TABLESPACE is anything other than SYSTEM tablespace, modify the default tablespace to SYSTEM by using the below command.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => The SYS and SYSTEM user ids have a default tablespace of SYSTEM
    DEFAULT_TABLESPACE 
------------------ 
SYSTEM
SYSTEM

    


    Hide
    


    Verify fast recovery area allocation totals are not greater than the total space of the DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST disk group
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The space committed in DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST_SIZE for all database combined should not be larger than the total usable space in the DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST disk group. This ensures room for archive log creation and proper automatic space management. 

    Risk:

    Database operation can be hampered by running out of space in the Fast Recovery Area (FRA). 

    Action / Repair:

     To verify that the space committed by diskgroup to Fast Recovery Area is less than the space available, run Exachk and review the provided report.

    The expected output in the Exachk report should be as follows:

    PASS   ASM Check   Fast recovery area allocation totals are not greater than the total space of the DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST disk group   All ASM Instances   
    View

    If more space is committed to Fast Recovery Area than is actually available and usable in the diskgroup the Exachk report will return something similar to the following:

    [FAILURE] Disk group RECO over-committed on db_recovery_file_dest : space committed = 768012 MB, space available = 275754 MB

    If the total space requested for the Fast Recovery Area by diskgroup for the databases is greater than the space defined for the diskgroup, analyze your database Fast Recovery Area requirements and adjust the DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST_SIZE setting in one of more databases to reduce the space committed. To determine the space committed by database, connect to one database instance for each database and run the following:

    col "FRA Diskgroup" format a30
    select fra_name.value as "FRA Diskgroup", round(fra_space.value/1048576)||' mb' as "FRA Space Committed"
    from v$parameter fra_name, v$parameter fra_space
    where fra_name.name = 'db_recovery_file_dest' and
    fra_space.name = 'db_recovery_file_dest_size';

    The output should be similar to the following:

    FRA Diskgroup                  FRA Space Committed
    ------------------------------ -------------------------------------------
    +RECO                          1048576 mb

    To alter the amount of space committed to the Fast Recovery Area by a database run a command similar to the following with an appropriate value for the size.

    SQL> alter system set db_file_recovery_dest_size=250g scope=both;

    If after corrective actions are completed, you wish to run this one check without a full Exachk run execute the following command as the "root" userid in the directory in which Exachk was installed:

    ./exachk -check 9AD94FEDF63F8296E040E50A1EC06A28,655C2F41EBD4D8D2E053D398EB0A46B7,656199B11AE12339E053D198EB0AD957
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => Fast recovery area allocation totals are not greater than the total space of the DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST disk group
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY FAST RECOVERY AREA ALLOCATION TOTALS ARE NOT GREATER THAN THE TOTAL SPACE OF THE DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST DISK GROUP 



    


    Hide
    


    Verify there is enough disk group free space for a rebalance operation
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Having enough disk group free space available to accomodate a rebalance operation helps to prevent an outage or loss of data.

    It is important to know if there is sufficient disk group free space to allow for ASM rebalance to complete after disk failure so that full redundancy is restored.  This is critical to avoid data loss or complete outage if a subsequent partner disk failure occurs in the future. 

    The impact of verifying that there is enough disk group free space available for a rebalance operation is minimal. The impact of correcting a lack of free space will vary depending upon the reason for the lack of free space, and cannot be estimated here. 

    The following table displays the required free space percentage for a complete rebalance operation after one disk failure with various combinations of Exadata configurations.

    The percentages listed should be multiplied by the total raw disk group size (ie., v$asm_diskgroup.total_mb) to compute the amount of space to keep free in the diskgroup.

    Applicable to Exadata X9 and Earlier High Capacity or Extreme Flash, or Exadata X10 High Capacity:


    Grid Infrastructure Version     Number of Failgroups     Required % free
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    12.1.0                             any                    15%
    greater than or equal to 12.2     less than 5             15%
    greater than or equal to 12.2     5 or more                9% 

    Note: Eighth Rack systems require 20% free space regardless of version.


    Applicable to Exadata X10 Extreme Flash Only with Grid Infrastructure version 19.x or higher:

    Number of Failgroups       Redundancy        Required % free
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~       ~~~~~~~~~~        ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    < 5                        NORMAL               15%
    < 5                        HIGH                 29%
    >= 5                       NORMAL                9%
    >= 5                       HIGH                 11%

    NOTE: In X10-EF systems for GI versions prior to 19.17, or 21.x, please apply patch 34281503 so the above percentages are applicable.

    Please refer to MOS note "Understanding ASM Capacity and Reservation of Free Space in Exadata (Doc ID 1551288.1)" for more information.

    Risk:

    If there is not enough diskgroup free space available for a rebalance operation, there is an increased risk of an outage or loss of data with an additional disk failure.

    Action / Repair:

    If a diskgroup does not have sufficient free space, you should do one of the following:

        - evaluate the space usage within the diskgroup and free up space by removing tablespaces that are no longer needed
        - move datafiles to another diskgroup that has enough space (datafile moves can be done on-line as of Oracle 12.1 )
        - increase the size of the diskgroup, assuming that some other diskgroup can be shrunk or, there is unallocated freespace on celldisks 
        - add additional capacity


    Examples of the output returned by the script:

    ( NOTE: we are removing the code sample and instead will rely only on the Exachk code to compute the values )

    SUCCESS: Diskgroup DATAC5 has 94.9% free space which is enough to complete a rebalance operation if a disk fails
    	 Diskgroup DATAC5 HIGH Redundancy, Required Minimum Percent Free = 15%, Required Minimum Free MB = 18872524.8
    	 Diskgroup DATAC5 has Total MB = 125816832, Free MB = 119405532, Usable MB = 33511002.4

    SUCCESS: Diskgroup RECOC5 has 98.6% free space which is enough to complete a rebalance operation if a disk fails
    	 Diskgroup RECOC5 HIGH Redundancy, Required Minimum Percent Free = 15%, Required Minimum Free MB = 2119996.8
    	 Diskgroup RECOC5 has Total MB = 14133312, Free MB = 13934628, Usable MB = 3938210.4

    FAILURE: Diskgroup TESTC5 has 14% free space which is lower than the 15% free space threshold. A rebalance may fail with ORA-15041
    	 Diskgroup TESTC5 HIGH Redundancy, Required Minimum Percent Free = 15%, Required Minimum Free MB = 7396185.6
    	 Diskgroup TESTC5 has Total MB = 49307904, Free MB = 6901548, Usable MB = -164879.2

    If a diskgroup does not have sufficient free space, you should do one or more of the following:

        Evaluate the space usage within the diskgroup and free up space by removing tablespaces that are no longer needed
        Increase the size of the disk group, assuming that some other diskgroup can be shrunk or, there is already unallocated free space on celldisks that can be used


    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1351036.1 - Validate and Fix Proper ASM Failure Group Configuration on Oracle Exadata Database Machine
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    FAIL => There is not enough disk group free space for a rebalance operation
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY THERE IS ENOUGH DISK GROUP FREE SPACE FOR A REBALANCE OPERATION 



FAILURE: Disk group DATA_EXA3 has 4% free space which is lower than the 15% free space threshold. A rebalance may fail with ORA-15041
	 Disk group DATA_EXA3 NORMAL Redundancy, Required Minimum Percent Free = 15%, Required Minimum Free MB = 34499750
	 Disk group DATA_EXA3 has Total MB = 229998336, Free MB = 9218916, Usable MB = -12640417
	 Number of failgroups = 4

SUCCESS: Disk group RECO_EXA3 has 25.2% free space which is enough to complete a rebalance operation if a disk fails
	 Disk group RECO_EXA3 NORMAL Redundancy, Required Minimum Percent Free = 15%, Required Minimum Free MB = 59673254
	 Disk group RECO_EXA3 has Total MB = 397821696, Free MB = 100105964, Usable MB = 20216354
	 Number of failgroups = 4

Model       : Oracle Corporation ORACLE SERVER X8-2L High Capacity
Eighth Rack : FALSE
    


    Hide
    


    Invalid sys/system objects
    


    

    Recommendation
    If the dbupgdiag.sql script reports any invalid objects, run $ORACLE_HOME/rdbms/admin/utlrp.sql (multiple times) to validate the invalid objects in the database until there is no change in the number of invalid objects.

    $ cd $ORACLE_HOME/rdbms/admin
    $ sqlplus "/ as sysdba"
    SQL> @utlrp.sql

    After validating the invalid objects, re-run dbupgdiag.sql in the database once again and make sure that everything is fine.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 837570.1 - Complete Checklist for Manual Upgrades to 11gR2
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => No SYS or SYSTEM objects were found to be INVALID
    Query returned no rows which is expected when the SQL check passes.

    


    Hide
    


    Verify initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    cluster_database_instances should not be changed from the default value for performance and stability. The impact of verifying initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value is minimal. The impact of removing a set value should include a database restart to make sure the change survives database shutdown and startup.

    Risk:

    If cluster_database_instances is modified from the default, dynamic remastering can be impacted potentially causing poor performance or stability.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify cluster_database_instances is at the default value, as the owner of the oracle home for a given database and with the environment set to access that database, execute the following command set:

    unset ISDEFAULT_VALUE
    ISDEFAULT_VALUE=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set head off lines 80 feedback off timing off serveroutput on
    select upper(isdefault) from v\$parameter where name ='cluster_database_instances';
    exit
    EOF
    )
    if [ $ISDEFAULT_VALUE = "TRUE" ]
    then 
         echo -e "SUCCESS: cluster_database_instances is at the default value"
    else 
         echo -e "FAILURE: cluster_database_instances should be at the default value: \"isdefault\" column value = "$ISDEFAULT_VALUE"" 
    fi;

    The expected output should be:

    SUCCESS: cluster_database_instances is at the default value

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE: cluster_database_instances should be at the default value: "isdefault" column value = FALSE

    To correct a failure condition, with the environment properly set to access the target database, unset cluster_database_instances database parameter using

    SQL> alter system reset cluster_database_instances scope=spfile sid='*';

    Restart the instance and verify the change survives startup and shutdown.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => The initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value 



SUCCESS: cluster_database_instances is at the default value
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => The initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value 



SUCCESS: cluster_database_instances is at the default value
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => The initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify initialization parameter cluster_database_instances is at the default value 



SUCCESS: cluster_database_instances is at the default value
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX39
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Significant increase in system "load average" as shown by the "top" command (Top.ExaWatcher collection).
    Significant increase in "%sys" and "%iostat" for a subset of CPUs as shown by the "mpstat -P ALL" command (Mpstat.ExaWatcher collection).
    These symptoms are also evident in the Host CPU table in the Report Summary section of an AWR report.

    Risk:

    Automatic NUMA memory balancing feature in UEK4 may cause the system to experience continuously high load or reduced performance

    Action / Repair:

    See  Exadata Critical Issue EX39 in below Exadata Critical Issue MOS Note

    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check 5CE421E72521A884E053D598EB0A906C".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair 5CE421E72521A884E053D598EB0A906C".
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03

    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX39

    Verify there are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Under certain rare circumstances, and only under the direction of Oracle Support, a file may be placed in specified locations which will impact the firmware update process in a specific way. Under normal operation, these files should not exist. Verifying there are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures helps to avoid unexpected firmware versions or firmware version mismatches across the system components. The impact of verification is minimal. The impact of correction can range from simply removing the undesired file(s) to updating or downgrading a firmware version.

    Risk:

    The risk varies depending upon which file is found. Please refer to the entries in this table:

    Firmware Update Behavior Modification File Table

    Filename: /opt/oracle.cellos/DISABLE_FIRMWARE_HARDWARE_CHECK
    Function: Disables automatic firmware verification and/or correction.
    Risk:     Risk is incorrect firmware version introduced during operations like component replacement, Exadata Software image upgrade or downgrade, and server reboots.

    Filename: /.updfrm_exact
    Function: Overrides a manual firmware operation.
    Risk:     Risk is that a desired manual firmware operation may be rolled back upon server reboot

    Action / Repair:

    To verify there are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures, execute the following command set as the "root" userid on each database server and storage server:

    INPUT_FILENAME_ARRAY="/.updfrm_exact /opt/oracle.cellos/DISABLE_FIRMWARE_HARDWARE_CHECK"
    RETURN_RESULT=0
    unset OUTPUT_ARRAY
    for INDIVIDUAL_FILENAME in $INPUT_FILENAME_ARRAY
    do
      if [ -f $INDIVIDUAL_FILENAME ]
      then
        RETURN_RESULT=$(expr $RETURN_RESULT + 1)
        OUTPUT_ARRAY+="$INDIVIDUAL_FILENAME\n"
      fi
    done
    if [ $RETURN_RESULT -eq 0 ]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS:  There were no files found that impact normal firmware update procedures."
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE:  One or more files were found that impact normal firmware update procedures:\n${OUTPUT_ARRAY[@]}"
    fi

    The output should be:

    SUCCESS:  There were no files found that impact normal firmware update procedures.

    Example of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE:  One or more files were found that impact normal firmware update procedures:
    /.updfrm_exact
    /opt/oracle.cellos/DISABLE_FIRMWARE_HARDWARE_CHECK

    If the output is a "FAILURE" result, investigate and take corrective action. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => There are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify there are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS:  There were no files found that impact normal firmware update procedures.

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify there are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS:  There were no files found that impact normal firmware update procedures.

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify there are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS:  There were no files found that impact normal firmware update procedures.

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify there are no files present that impact normal firmware update procedures [Storage Server] 


SUCCESS:  There were no files found that impact normal firmware update procedures.

    


    Hide
    


    Verify "asm_power_limit" is greater than zero
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Setting "asm_power_limit=0" disables rebalance operations. Verifying that "asm_power_limit" is greater than zero confirms that rebalance operations are enabled. The impact of verifying that "asm_power_limit" is greater than zero is minimal, as is the impact of setting it to a value greater than zero.

        NOTE: Changing the default value via the initialization parameter "asm_power_limit" is not the same as changing the power for an actively running rebalance operation. 

    Risk:

    "asm_power_limit=0" disables rebalance operations, which can lead to data loss in the event of multiple hardware failures over time. 

    Action / Repair:

    To verify "asm_power_limit" is greater than zero, as the grid home owner userid, execute the following command set once for each ASM instance with the environment properly configured to access that given instance:

        NOTE: This code will not execute properly if executed on a database server in a flex ASM environment where an ASM instance is not running. 

    ASMPL_PARAM_DATA=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set newpage none heading off lines 80 feedback off timing off serveroutput on
    select value from v\$parameter where name = 'asm_power_limit';
    exit
    EOF
    )
    ASMPL_QUEUE_DATA=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set newpage none heading off lines 80 feedback off timing off serveroutput on
    select count(*) from gv\$asm_operation where power=0 or actual=0;
    exit
    EOF
    )
    if [[ $ASMPL_PARAM_DATA -gt 0 && $ASMPL_QUEUE_DATA -eq 0 ]]
    then 
      echo -e "SUCCESS: \"asm_power_limit\" is set to $ASMPL_PARAM_DATA and there are no rebalance operations in gv\$asm_operation with the attribute POWER or ACTUAL = 0"
    else 
      echo -e "FAILURE:"
      if [ $ASMPL_PARAM_DATA -eq 0 ]
      then
        echo -e "The intitialization parameter \"asm_power_limit\" is set to zero"
      fi
      if [ $ASMPL_QUEUE_DATA -gt 0 ]
      then
        echo -e "There are rebalance operation(s) in gv\$asm_operation with the attribute POWER or ACTUAL = 0"
      fi
    fi;

    The output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: "asm_power_limit" is set to 32 and there are no rebalance operations in gv$asm_operation with the attribute POWER or ACTUAL = 0

    Examples of "FAILURE" results:

    FAILURE:
    The intitialization parameter "asm_power_limit" is set to zero
    There are rebalance operation(s) in gv$asm_operation with the attribute POWER or ACTUAL = 0

    FAILURE:
    The intitialization parameter "asm_power_limit" is set to zero

    FAILURE:
    There are rebalance operation(s) in gv$asm_operation with the attribute POWER or ACTUAL = 0

    If the output is a "FAILURE" result, investigate and take corrective action. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => "asm_power_limit" is greater than zero and there are no rebalance operations in the queue with the attribute POWER or ACTUAL = 0
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY "ASM_POWER_LIMIT" IS GREATER THAN ZERO 



SUCCESS: asm_power_limit is set to 32 and there are no rebalance operations in the queue with the attribute POWER or ACTUAL = 0
    


    Hide
    


    Verify the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS and TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Configuring the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, and TEMP tablespaces to be of type bigfile simplifies maintenance and operations which involve these tablespaces. The impact of verifying the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, and TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile is minimal.

    Risk:

    If the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, and TEMP tablespaces are not of type bigfile, maintenance operations are more complicated and a tablespace running out of free space is more possible.

    Action / Repair:

     To verify the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, and TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile, as the ORACLE_HOME owner userid on one database server in the cluster, execute the following command set once for each database running out of a given ORACLE_HOME, with the environment properly configured to access each given database:

    BIGFILE_DATA=$($ORACLE_HOME/bin/sqlplus -s "/ as sysdba" <<EOF
    set newpage none lines 80 feedback off timing off serveroutput on
    SELECT tablespace_name, bigfile FROM dba_tablespaces
    WHERE tablespace_name in ('SYSTEM', 'SYSAUX', 'USERS', 'TEMP');
    exit
    EOF
    )
    if [ `echo "$BIGFILE_DATA" | grep -ic "NO"` -gt 0 ]
    then 
         echo -e "FAILURE: One or more of SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are not of type bigfile:\n\n$BIGFILE_DATA"
    else 
         echo -e "SUCCESS: SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile:\n\n$BIGFILE_DATA" 
    fi

    The output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, and TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile:

    TABLESPACE_NAME                BIG
    ------------------------------ ---
    SYSTEM                         YES
    SYSAUX                         YES
    TEMP                           YES
    USERS                          YES

    Examples of a "FAILURE" result:

    FAILURE: One or more of SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are not of type bigfile:

    TABLESPACE_NAME                BIG
    ------------------------------ ---
    SYSTEM                         NO
    SYSAUX                         NO
    TEMP                           NO
    USERS                          NO

    If the output is a "FAILURE" result, investigate and take corrective action. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS and TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile 



SUCCESS: SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile:

TABLESPACE_NAME 	       BIG
------------------------------ ---
SYSTEM			       YES
SYSAUX			       YES
TEMP			       YES
USERS			       YES
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS and TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile 



SUCCESS: SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile:

TABLESPACE_NAME 	       BIG
------------------------------ ---
SYSTEM			       YES
SYSAUX			       YES
TEMP			       YES
USERS			       YES
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify the SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS and TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile 



SUCCESS: SYSTEM, SYSAUX, USERS, TEMP tablespaces are of type bigfile:

TABLESPACE_NAME 	       BIG
------------------------------ ---
SYSTEM			       YES
SYSAUX			       YES
TEMP			       YES
USERS			       YES
    


    Hide
    


    Verify the vm.min_free_kbytes configuration
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Maintaining vm.min_free_kbytes as recommended helps a Linux system to reclaim memory more efficiently.

    The impact of verifying the vm.min_free_kbytes configuration is minimal.

    The impact of adjusting vm.min_free_kbytes should include a reboot to verify the configuration is correctly configured and retained during the boot cycle.

        NOTE: It is possible, but NOT recommended, especially for a system already under memory pressure, to modify the setting interactively in active kernel memory.

    The recommended values are shown in the following table:

    vm.min_free_kbytes value (Kb)
    MAX(1GB * number_numa_nodes, 0.5% * total_memory) 

    Risk:

    Exposure to unexpected node eviction and reboot.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify the vm.min_free_kbytes configuration, as the "root" userid on each database server, execute the following command set:
    MIN_FREE_KBYTES_SYSCTL=$(egrep ^vm.min_free_kbytes <([ -e /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf ] && cat /etc/sysctl.d/* || cat /etc/sysctl.conf) | awk -F'=' '{print $2}' | tr -d ' ')
    MIN_FREE_KBYTES_MEMORY=$(cat /proc/sys/vm/min_free_kbytes)
    NUMA_NODE_COUNT=$(numactl --hardware | grep available: | awk '{print $2}')
    TOTAL_MEMORY_KBYTES=$(free -k | awk '/Mem:/ {print $2}')
    NUMA_BASED=$(( $NUMA_NODE_COUNT * 1048576 ))
    MEMORY_BASED=$(( $TOTAL_MEMORY_KBYTES / 200 ))
    if [[ $NUMA_BASED -ge $MEMORY_BASED ]]
    then
      RECOMMEND_VALUE=$NUMA_BASED
    else
      RECOMMEND_VALUE=$MEMORY_BASED
    fi
    OFFSET=$(echo $RECOMMEND_VALUE*.05 | bc | cut -d"." -f1)
    LOWER_BOUND=$(echo $RECOMMEND_VALUE-$OFFSET | bc)
    UPPER_BOUND=$(echo $RECOMMEND_VALUE+$OFFSET | bc)
    if [[ $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_SYSCTL -ge LOWER_BOUND && $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_SYSCTL -le UPPER_BOUND ]]
    then
      SYSCTL_IN_RANGE=YES
    else
      SYSCTL_IN_RANGE=NO
    fi
    #sysctl in range?
    if [[ $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_MEMORY -ge LOWER_BOUND && $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_MEMORY -le UPPER_BOUND ]]
    then
      MEMORY_IN_RANGE=YES
    else
      MEMORY_IN_RANGE=NO
    fi
    DETAIL=$(
    echo -e "Total Memory:       $TOTAL_MEMORY_KBYTES";
    echo -e "NUMA node count:    $NUMA_NODE_COUNT";
    echo -e "NUMA calculated:    $NUMA_BASED";
    echo -e "memory calculated:  $MEMORY_BASED";
    echo -e "recommended value:  $RECOMMEND_VALUE";
    echo -e "permitted range:    $LOWER_BOUND to $UPPER_BOUND";
    echo -e "at boot (sysctl):   $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_SYSCTL";
    echo -e "sysctl in range?:   $SYSCTL_IN_RANGE";
    echo -e "in active memory:   $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_MEMORY";
    echo -e "memory in range?:   $MEMORY_IN_RANGE";
    )
    if [[ $SYSCTL_IN_RANGE = YES && $MEMORY_IN_RANGE = YES ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: vm.min_free_kbytes is configured as recommended.  Details:\n\n$DETAIL"
    elif [[ $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_SYSCTL -lt $LOWER_BOUND || $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_MEMORY -lt $LOWER_BOUND ]]
    then
      echo -e "FAILURE: vm.min_free_kbytes is not configured as recommended.  Details:\n\n$DETAIL"
    elif  [[ $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_SYSCTL -gt $UPPER_BOUND && $MIN_FREE_KBYTES_MEMORY -gt $UPPER_BOUND ]]
    then
      echo -e "WARNING: vm.min_free_kbytes is not configured as recommended.  Details:\n\n$DETAIL"
    else
      echo -e "ERROR: Inconsistent results.  Details:\n\n$DETAILS"
    fi
    The output should be similar to:
    SUCCESS: vm.min_free_kbytes is configured as recommended.  Details:

    Total Memory:       790834860
    NUMA node count:    2
    NUMA calculated:    2097152
    memory calculated:  3954174
    recommended value:  3954174
    permitted range:    3756466 to 4151882
    at boot (sysctl):   3954174
    sysctl in range?:   YES
    in active memory:   3954174
    memory in range?:   YES
    Example of a "FAILURE" result:
    FAILURE: vm.min_free_kbytes is not configured as recommended.  Details:

    Total Memory:       263649268
    NUMA node count:    1
    NUMA calculated:    1048576
    memory calculated:  1318246
    recommended value:  1318246
    permitted range:    1252334 to 1384158
    at boot (sysctl):   524288
    sysctl in range?:   NO
    in active memory:   524288
    memory in range?:   NO
    NOTE: In the above "FAILURE" example, the setting at boot (sysctl) and active memory are both lower than the permitted range.
    Example of a "WARNING" result:
    WARNING: vm.min_free_kbytes is not configured as recommended.  Details:

    Total Memory:       263649268
    NUMA node count:    1
    NUMA calculated:    1048576
    memory calculated:  1318246
    recommended value:  1318246
    permitted range:    1252334 to 1384158
    at boot (sysctl):   1412346
    sysctl in range?:   NO
    in active memory:   1412346
    memory in range?:   NO
    NOTE: In the above "WARNING" example, the setting at boot (sysctl) and active memory are both higher than the permitted range.
    If the output is a "FAILURE" result, set the recommended vm.min_free_kbytes value for the given configuration at boot (sysctl) and reboot the database server.
    If numactl is unavailable, check uses lscpu.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => The vm.min_free_kbytes configuration is set as recommended
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY THE VM.MIN_FREE_KBYTES CONFIGURATION



SUCCESS: vm.min_free_kbytes is configured as recommended. Details:

Total Memory:      790844384
NUMA node count:   2
NUMA calculated:   2097152
memory calculated: 3954221
recommended value: 3954221
permitted range:   3756510 to 4151932
at boot (sysctl):  3954221
sysctl in range?:  YES
in active memory:  3954221
memory in range?:  YES
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => The vm.min_free_kbytes configuration is set as recommended
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY THE VM.MIN_FREE_KBYTES CONFIGURATION

    Status on exa3dbadm02:

    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY THE VM.MIN_FREE_KBYTES CONFIGURATION



SUCCESS: vm.min_free_kbytes is configured as recommended. Details:
