    Verify the currently active image status [Database Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The currently active image status for either a database or storage server should always be "success". The impact of verification is minimal. The impact of correcting a status other than "success" depends upon the root cause of the deviation, and cannot be estimated here.

    Risk:

    If the currently active image status is not "success" unpredictable behavior such as crashing, failure to boot, poor performance, etc.. is likely.

    Action / Repair:

     To verify the currently active image status execute the following command set as the root userid on all database and storage servers:

    FULL_DETAILS=$(imageinfo)
    if [[ $(echo "$FULL_DETAILS" | egrep "^Image status:|^Active image status:" | egrep -iwc "success") -eq 1 ]]
    then
      echo -e "SUCCESS: the currently active image status is \"success\"."
    else
      echo -e "FAILURE: the currently active image status is not \"success\".  Details:\n$FULL_DETAILS"
    fi

    The expected output should be

    SUCCESS: the currently active image status is "success".

    Example of a database server "FAILURE:" result:

    FAILURE: the currently active image status is not "success".  Details:

    Kernel version: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.el7uek.x86_64 #2 SMP Fri Aug 23 20:48:29 GMT 2019 x86_64
    Image kernel version: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.el7uek
    Image version: 19.3.0.0.0.190909
    Image activated: 2019-09-09 12:03:36 -0700
    Image status: failure
    Node type: KVMHOST
    System partition on device: /dev/mapper/VGExaDb-LVDbSys1

    Example of a storage server "FAILURE:" result:

    FAILURE: the currently active image status is not "success".  Details:

    Kernel version: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.2.el7uek.x86_64 #2 SMP Sat Sep 14 19:30:38 GMT 2019 x86_64
    Cell version: OSS_MAIN_LINUX.X64_190919
    Cell rpm version: cell-19.4.0.0.0_LINUX.X64_190919-1.x86_64

    Active image version: 19.4.0.0.0.190919
    Active image kernel version: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.2.el7uek
    Active image activated: 2019-09-26 03:48:20 -0700
    Active image status: failure
    Active node type: STORAGE
    Active system partition on device: /dev/md24p5
    Active software partition on device: /dev/md24p7

    Cell boot usb partition: /dev/md25p1
    Cell boot usb version: 19.4.0.0.0.190919

    Inactive image version: 19.4.0.0.0.190912
    Inactive image activated: 2019-09-19 03:48:13 -0700
    Inactive image status: success
    Inactive node type: STORAGE
    Inactive system partition on device: /dev/md24p6
    Inactive software partition on device: /dev/md24p8

    Inactive marker for the rollback: /boot/I_am_hd_boot.inactive
    Inactive grub config for the rollback: /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg.inactive
    Inactive usb grub config for the rollback: /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg.usb.inactive
    Inactive kernel version for the rollback: 4.14.35-1902.5.1.el7uek.x86_64
    Rollback to the inactive partitions: Possible

    If the output is not "SUCCESS:", investigate root cause and implement corrective action.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => The currently active image status is "success"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY THE CURRENTLY ACTIVE IMAGE STATUS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: the currently active image status is "success".
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => The currently active image status is "success"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY THE CURRENTLY ACTIVE IMAGE STATUS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: the currently active image status is "success".
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => The currently active image status is "success"
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY THE CURRENTLY ACTIVE IMAGE STATUS [DATABASE SERVER]



SUCCESS: the currently active image status is "success".
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter asm_power_limit
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Aligning with MAA best practice parameters for the ASM instance improves stability, security, and performance of ASM operations. Check the ASM documentation for instructions and impact of changing specfic parameters.

    Risk:

    The risk of not using MAA best practice parameters for the ASM instances is security vulnerability, performance issues, and possible data loss.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify important ASM instance parameters, run the following script with the environment configured for the ASM instance. Note this script cannot check for all best pracice parameters because some are customer specific. Please refer to the 12.1.0.2 ASM instance best practice parameter and attribute reference for a complete list as well as more details on why these parameters are best practices.

    for record in asm_power_limit,4 audit_syslog_level,local0.info audit_sys_operations,true
    do
    parameter_name=`echo $record | awk -F, '{print $1}'`
    pass_value=`echo $record | awk -F, '{print $2}'`
    current_value=`sqlplus -S  "/ as sysasm" << eof
    set head off
    select lower(value) from v\\$parameter where name='$parameter_name';
    exit
    eof`
    current_value=`echo $current_value | tr -d '\r'`
    if [ $current_value == $pass_value ]
    then
    ret_val=0
    echo -e "SUCCESS: $parameter_name current value $current_value matches best practice value $pass_value"
    else
    echo -e "FAILURE: $parameter_name current value $current_value does not match best practice value $pass_value"
    ret_val=1
    fi
    done


    The output should look like this:
    SUCCESS: asm_power_limit current value 4 matches best practice value 4
    SUCCESS: audit_syslog_level current value local0.info matches best practice value local0.info
    SUCCESS: audit_sys_operations current value true matches best practice value true
    If the output does not match please adjust any parameter listed with a FAILURE prefix
    

    Needs attention on+ASM3, +ASM1, +ASM2
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on +ASM1:
    WARN => ASM parameter ASM_POWER_LIMIT is not set to the default value.
    +ASM1.asm_power_limit = 32
    

    Status on +ASM3:
    WARN => ASM parameter ASM_POWER_LIMIT is not set to the default value.
    +ASM3.asm_power_limit = 32
    

    Status on +ASM2:
    WARN => ASM parameter ASM_POWER_LIMIT is not set to the default value.
    +ASM2.asm_power_limit = 32
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter open_cursors
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized.
    The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal.
    The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.

    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    OPEN_CURSORS >= 300.  Initial deployment database uses 1000
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter OPEN_CURSORS is set to recommended value
    whexa3p31.open_cursors = 1000
    


    Hide
    


    Check for parameter db_block_size
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The default and generally recommended DB_BLOCK_SIZE for Oracle databases is 8192(bytes). 

    A different block size may be specified at database creation if it is proven by thorough testing to be more efficient for a given database design and application set.


    Risk:

    Sub-optimal performance.

    Action / Repair:

    DB_BLOCK_SIZE cannot be modified after database creation.  If it is desired to change the DB_BLOCK_SIZE from it's current value, the database will have to be rebuilt.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p31, whexa3p33, whexa3p32
    

    


    Status on whexa3p31:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_SIZE is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p31.db_block_size = 8192
    

    Status on whexa3p33:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_SIZE is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p33.db_block_size = 8192
    

    Status on whexa3p32:
    PASS => Database parameter DB_BLOCK_SIZE is set to the recommended value
    whexa3p32.db_block_size = 8192
    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX87
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 36309367, queries on Database 19c using Exadata Smart Scan with Exadata version 23.1.0 through 23.1.11 may produce duplicate rows (wrong results) when the table contains chained rows.


    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX87 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX87
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Exadata Critical Issue EX87

    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX87

    Hide
    


    Verify no obsolete patches installed in Grid Infrastructure software home
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If a problem is discovered with an interim patch Oracle will withdraw the patch, mark it obsolete in My Oracle Support (MOS), and typically provide a replacement interim patch.
    The benefit of this check is to avoid potential problems caused by continuing to use a withdrawn, obsolete interim patch. An obsolete patch is also known as a regressed patch.
    This check identifies interim patches that have become obsolete (i.e., have been withdrawn) within the last 18 months that are installed in Database and Grid Infrastructure software homes that are running a Long Term Release that is under Premier or Extended Support (e.g., Release 19c).

    Risk:

    The risk of continuing to use an obsolete patch is dependent on the reason the patch was withdrawn, but, in general, can negatively affect system functionality, availability, and/or performance.
    Note that while an obsolete interim patch may continue to resolve the original issue for which it was installed, it is withdrawn because it may not cover all scenarios or it may introduce undesirable behavior in some circumstances.

    Action / Repair:

    Confirm the reported patch is installed using OPatch. For example, if Exachk/Orachk reports "Found obsolete Patch 35058893 (Unique Patch ID 25317040)", then run the following "opatch lsinventory" command to confirm the obsolete patch is installed:

    $ORACLE_HOME/OPatch/opatch lsinventory  | grep -A2 '^Patch *35058893'
        Patch 35058893     : applied on Thu Oct 05 06:51:19 UTC 2023
        Unique Patch ID: 25317040
        Patch description:  "PERFORMANCE DEGRADATION IN RMAN CATALOG COMMAND AFTER 19.16 PATCH"

    Login to My Oracle Support (MOS) and query the obsolete patch to identify and install the replacement patch.  If a replacement patch is not available, then contact Oracle Support. 

    To run the check again
    # exachk -check 142710BEFBB5CC62E0639812F50AFCD2
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => No obsolete patches found in Grid Infrastructure software home
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY NO OBSOLETE PATCHES INSTALLED IN GRID INFRASTRUCTURE SOFTWARE HOME 



No obsolete patches found in OPatch inventory
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => No obsolete patches found in Grid Infrastructure software home
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY NO OBSOLETE PATCHES INSTALLED IN GRID INFRASTRUCTURE SOFTWARE HOME 



No obsolete patches found in OPatch inventory
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => No obsolete patches found in Grid Infrastructure software home
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY NO OBSOLETE PATCHES INSTALLED IN GRID INFRASTRUCTURE SOFTWARE HOME 



No obsolete patches found in OPatch inventory
    


    Hide
    


    Verify no obsolete patches installed in Database software home
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    If a problem is discovered with an interim patch Oracle will withdraw the patch, mark it obsolete in My Oracle Support (MOS), and typically provide a replacement interim patch.
    The benefit of this check is to avoid potential problems caused by continuing to use a withdrawn, obsolete interim patch. An obsolete patch is also known as a regressed patch.
    This check identifies interim patches that have become obsolete (i.e., have been withdrawn) within the last 18 months that are installed in Database and Grid Infrastructure software homes that are running a Long Term Release that is under Premier or Extended Support (e.g., Release 19c).

    Risk:

    The risk of continuing to use an obsolete patch is dependent on the reason the patch was withdrawn, but, in general, can negatively affect system functionality, availability, and/or performance.
    Note that while an obsolete interim patch may continue to resolve the original issue for which it was installed, it is withdrawn because it may not cover all scenarios or it may introduce undesirable behavior in some circumstances.

    Action / Repair:

    Confirm the reported patch is installed using OPatch.  For example, if Exachk/Orachk reports "Found obsolete Patch 35058893 (Unique Patch ID 25317040)", then run the following "opatch lsinventory" command to confirm the obsolete patch is installed:

    $ORACLE_HOME/OPatch/opatch lsinventory  | grep -A2 '^Patch *35058893'
    Patch 35058893     : applied on Thu Oct 05 06:51:19 UTC 2023
    Unique Patch ID: 25317040
    Patch description:  "PERFORMANCE DEGRADATION IN RMAN CATALOG COMMAND AFTER 19.16 PATCH"

    Login to My Oracle Support (MOS) and query the obsolete patch to identify and install the replacement patch.  If a replacement patch is not available, then contact Oracle Support.

    To run the check again
    # exachk -check 142419924193CB5DE0639812F50A6ECD
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm03:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm02:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1, exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => No obsolete patches found in Database software home
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify no obsolete patches installed in Database software home 



No obsolete patches found in OPatch inventory
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => No obsolete patches found in Database software home
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify no obsolete patches installed in Database software home 



No obsolete patches found in OPatch inventory
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:/u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1:
    PASS => No obsolete patches found in Database software home
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - /u01/app/oracle/product/19.0.0.0/dbhome_1 DATABASE_HOME - Verify no obsolete patches installed in Database software home 



No obsolete patches found in OPatch inventory
    


    Hide
    


    Verify Hidden Database Initialization Parameter Usage
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Hidden database initialization parameters are typically set as a workaround to solve a specific problem, and should be removed once a system has been upgraded to a version level that contains the fix for the specific problem. Often they are not removed during the upgrade process to the version level that contains the correct fix. Verifying the hidden database initialization parameter usage helps avoid hidden parameters being used any longer than necessary.

    NOTES:

    1) For additional ZFS based backup configuration information, please see: Oracle ZFS Storage: FAQ: Exadata RMAN Backup with The Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance (Doc ID 1354980.1)

    2) This best practice check does not include any application specific hidden parameters. If an application in use requires hidden parameters that are failed by this best practice, refer to the proper documentation for the application version in use. If the extra hidden parameters are correct, then ignore the failures reported for those specific parameters.

    For Oracle E-Business Suite, please see: Database Initialization Parameters for Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12 (Doc ID 396009.1)
    For Siebel CRM Application, please see: Performance Tuning Guidelines for Siebel CRM Application on Oracle Database (Doc ID 2077227.2)

    Risk:

    Use of hidden ASM or database initialization parameters not recommended by Oracle development in an Exadata environment can cause instability, performance problems, corruptions, and crashes.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify the hidden database initialization parameter usage in each ASM and database instance, execute the following sqlplus command as the owner of the respective home with the environment properly set to access the instance:

    select name,value from v$parameter where substr(name,1,1)='_';

        NOTE: v$parameter only contains hidden parameters that have been changed from the default, which are the ones of interest here.

    The expected output should be a list of any hidden parameters in use that have been changed from the default value, similar to:

    _enable_NUMA_support  FALSE

    There should be no hidden parameters in use that are not shown in the "Generally Acceptable Hidden Parameters Table":

    Generally Acceptable Hidden Parameters Table
    Parameter
    Name 	Value 	Oracle
    Version 	Exadata
    Version 	Instance
    Type 	Notes
    _file_size_increase_increment 	2143289344 	<= 11.2.0.3 BP11 	ALL 	Database 	Enables more performant rman backup allocation sizes.
    _enable_NUMA_support 	Set _enable_NUMA_support=TRUE for all hardware generation 8-socket database servers (Note - applies to non-OVM only - OVM is not supported on 8-socket servers).

    Set _enable_NUMA_support=TRUE for X5 and later 2-socket database servers deployed as non-OVM.

    In all other cases do not explicitly set _enable_NUMA_support. 	<12.1.0.2.6 	ALL 	Database 	For any Exadata system using Database 12.1.0.2.6 or higher, do not explicitly set _enable_NUMA_support (includes all hardware generations, 2-socket, 8-socket, non-OVM, and OVM). _enable_NUMA_support setting is automatically configured by the database.

    For any Exadata system using Database 12.1.0.2.5 or lower, reference the recommended setting in the Value column of this row.
    _asm_resyncckpt 	0 	12.1.0.1 ONLY 	ALL 	ASM 	Turns off resync checkpointing
    _smm_auto_max_io_size 	1024 	

    12.1 and lower
    	ALL 	Database 	This permits 1MB IOs for hash joins that spill to disk, which can increase performance up to 40% due to increased throughput. These performance increases can prevent the need to move TEMP to flash.

    Internal only note: this will no longer be needed when bug 20925115 is fixed.
    _parallel_adaptive_max_users 	2 	12.1 and higher 	ALL 	Database 	Check to ensure not more than the recommended value. Setting this higher than this recommended value can deplete memory and impact performance.*

    Parameter PARALLEL_MAX_SERVERS is evaluated based on the below calculation method:
    parallel_threads_per_cpu*cpu_count*concurrent_parallel_users*5

    Parameter PARALLEL_SERVERS_TARGET is evaluated based on the below calculation method:
    parallel_threads_per_cpu*cpu_count*concurrent_parallel_users*2

    _PARALLEL_ADAPTIVE_MAX_USERS provides the value of concurrent_parallel_users in the calculation. The value of this parameter is set to 4 in most cases which would result in a higher than recommended maximum number of parallel servers, therefore the recommended value is 2.

    PARALLEL_MAX_SERVERS would be calculated as below assuming cpu_count is set to all available CPUs:
    X2-2: 1 * 24 * 2 * 5 = 240
    X6-2: 1 * 88 * 2 * 5 = 880
    X2-8: 1 * 128 * 2 * 5 = 1280
    X6-8: 1 * 288 * 2 * 5 = 2880
    _assm_segment_repair_bg 	FALSE 	12.2 and higher 	ALL 	Database 	work-around for bug 23734075
    _asm_max_connected_clients 	Dynamically changes 	12.2. and 18.1 ONLY 	ALL 	ASM 	Used internally; Removed in release 19c
    _backup_disk_bufcnt 	64 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1)
    _backup_disk_bufsz 	1048576 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1)
    _backup_file_bufcnt 	64 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1)
    _backup_file_bufsz 	1048576 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1) 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 2094946.1 - High Waits On 'block change tracking buffer space' - Checkpoint Contention With BLOCK CHANGE TRACKING
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    FAIL => Hidden database Initialization Parameter usage is not correct
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify Hidden Database Initialization Parameter Usage

    Verify Hidden ASM Initialization Parameter Usage
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Hidden database initialization parameters are typically set as a workaround to solve a specific problem, and should be removed once a system has been upgraded to a version level that contains the fix for the specific problem. Often they are not removed during the upgrade process to the version level that contains the correct fix. Verifying the hidden database initialization parameter usage helps avoid hidden parameters being used any longer than necessary.

    NOTES:

    1) For additional ZFS based backup configuration information, please see: Oracle ZFS Storage: FAQ: Exadata RMAN Backup with The Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance (Doc ID 1354980.1)

    2) This best practice check does not include any application specific hidden parameters. If an application in use requires hidden parameters that are failed by this best practice, refer to the proper documentation for the application version in use. If the extra hidden parameters are correct, then ignore the failures reported for those specific parameters.

    For Oracle E-Business Suite, please see: Database Initialization Parameters for Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12 (Doc ID 396009.1)

    For Siebel CRM Application, please see: Performance Tuning Guidelines for Siebel CRM Application on Oracle Database (Doc ID 2077227.2)

    Risk:

    Use of hidden ASM or database initialization parameters not recommended by Oracle development in an Exadata environment can cause instability, performance problems, corruptions, and crashes.

    Action / Repair:

     To verify the hidden database initialization parameter usage in each ASM and database instance, execute the following sqlplus command as the owner of the respective home with the environment properly set to access the instance:

    select name,value from v$parameter where substr(name,1,1)='_';

        NOTE: v$parameter only contains hidden parameters that have been changed from the default, which are the ones of interest here.

    The expected output should be a list of any hidden parameters in use that have been changed from the default value, similar to:

    _enable_NUMA_support  FALSE

    There should be no hidden parameters in use that are not shown in the "Generally Acceptable Hidden Parameters Table":

    Generally Acceptable Hidden Parameters Table
    Parameter
    Name 	Value 	Oracle
    Version 	Exadata
    Version 	Instance
    Type 	Notes
    _file_size_increase_increment 	2143289344 	<= 11.2.0.3 BP11 	ALL 	Database 	Enables more performant rman backup allocation sizes.
    _enable_NUMA_support 	Set _enable_NUMA_support=TRUE for all hardware generation 8-socket database servers (Note - applies to non-OVM only - OVM is not supported on 8-socket servers).

    Set _enable_NUMA_support=TRUE for X5 and later 2-socket database servers deployed as non-OVM.

    In all other cases do not explicitly set _enable_NUMA_support. 	<12.1.0.2.6 	ALL 	Database 	For any Exadata system using Database 12.1.0.2.6 or higher, do not explicitly set _enable_NUMA_support (includes all hardware generations, 2-socket, 8-socket, non-OVM, and OVM). _enable_NUMA_support setting is automatically configured by the database.

    For any Exadata system using Database 12.1.0.2.5 or lower, reference the recommended setting in the Value column of this row.
    _asm_resyncckpt 	0 	12.1.0.1 ONLY 	ALL 	ASM 	Turns off resync checkpointing
    _smm_auto_max_io_size 	1024 	

    12.1 and lower
    	ALL 	Database 	This permits 1MB IOs for hash joins that spill to disk, which can increase performance up to 40% due to increased throughput. These performance increases can prevent the need to move TEMP to flash.

    Internal only note: this will no longer be needed when bug 20925115 is fixed.
    _parallel_adaptive_max_users 	2 	12.1 and higher 	ALL 	Database 	Check to ensure not more than the recommended value. Setting this higher than this recommended value can deplete memory and impact performance.*

    Parameter PARALLEL_MAX_SERVERS is evaluated based on the below calculation method:
    parallel_threads_per_cpu*cpu_count*concurrent_parallel_users*5

    Parameter PARALLEL_SERVERS_TARGET is evaluated based on the below calculation method:
    parallel_threads_per_cpu*cpu_count*concurrent_parallel_users*2

    _PARALLEL_ADAPTIVE_MAX_USERS provides the value of concurrent_parallel_users in the calculation. The value of this parameter is set to 4 in most cases which would result in a higher than recommended maximum number of parallel servers, therefore the recommended value is 2.

    PARALLEL_MAX_SERVERS would be calculated as below assuming cpu_count is set to all available CPUs:
    X2-2: 1 * 24 * 2 * 5 = 240
    X6-2: 1 * 88 * 2 * 5 = 880
    X2-8: 1 * 128 * 2 * 5 = 1280
    X6-8: 1 * 288 * 2 * 5 = 2880
    _assm_segment_repair_bg 	FALSE 	12.2 and higher 	ALL 	Database 	work-around for bug 23734075
    _asm_max_connected_clients 	Dynamically changes 	12.2. and 18.1 ONLY 	ALL 	ASM 	Used internally; Removed in release 19c
    _backup_disk_bufcnt 	64 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1)
    _backup_disk_bufsz 	1048576 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1)
    _backup_file_bufcnt 	64 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1)
    _backup_file_bufsz 	1048576 	12.1 and lower 	ALL 	Database 	Only when ZFS based backups are in use (NOTE: 1) 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:+ASM2, exa3dbadm03:+ASM3, exa3dbadm01:+ASM1
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:+ASM1:
    PASS => Hidden ASM Initialization Parameter usage is correct
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 - VERIFY HIDDEN ASM INITIALIZATION PARAMETER USAGE 



The set underscore parameters meet expectations


For this version of ASM, 19.8.0.0.200714, the allowed underscore parameters along with their recommended values are :

_ksxp_allow_ksxr_rolling_migration TRUE

    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:+ASM3:
    PASS => Hidden ASM Initialization Parameter usage is correct
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 - VERIFY HIDDEN ASM INITIALIZATION PARAMETER USAGE 



The set underscore parameters meet expectations


For this version of ASM, 19.8.0.0.200714, the allowed underscore parameters along with their recommended values are :

_ksxp_allow_ksxr_rolling_migration TRUE

    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:+ASM2:
    PASS => Hidden ASM Initialization Parameter usage is correct
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 - VERIFY HIDDEN ASM INITIALIZATION PARAMETER USAGE 



The set underscore parameters meet expectations


For this version of ASM, 19.8.0.0.200714, the allowed underscore parameters along with their recommended values are :

_ksxp_allow_ksxr_rolling_migration TRUE

    Exadata Critical Issue EX85
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 36140446, flash disk(s) on Exadata X7 and X8/X8M storage servers running Exadata 23.1.10 or 23.1.11 are not properly configured after flash disk replacement or fresh imaging due to a timing issue between cell services and the multipathd service.

    Flash disks affected by this issue do not have a CELLDISK object configured, thus no flash cache, flash log, and/or grid disks are configured on the flash disk, resulting in the storage server missing or having smaller flash cache and flash log than expected, or missing grid disks.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX85 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX85
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX85 


This system is not exposed to critical issue EX85. Flash Cache PASSES verification.

Storage server makeModel                            : Oracle Corporation ORACLE SERVER X8-2L High Capacity

    Verify bundle patch version installed matches bundle patch version registered in database
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Crosschecking the software bundle patch version installed with the bundle patch registered in the database to make sure they match ensures software correctness and stability. If a bundle patch is being installed in a Data Guard configuration in a standby-first manner where the SQL portion of the bundle patch is not installed inside the database until the primary and all standby software homes have the same version installed, then this crosscheck is expected to fail until both the binary and SQL portion of the bundle patch application is fully installed.

    Risk:

    Incomplete bug fixes, software instability,unexpected behavior. For cloud environments, the dbaas tooling lifecycle management operations like patching, upgrade, Data Guard, etc. may fail.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that the bundle patch version installed matches bundle patch version registered in database, as the oracle home owner for the primary database, and with ORACLE_SID and ORACLE_HOME properly set, execute the following command:

    e.g:
    - Run opatch as below to get applied patch details  
      $ORACLE_HOME/OPatch/opatch lspatches 2>/dev/null|grep -iwv javavm|grep -wi database
            34133642;Database Release Update : 19.16.0.0.220719 (34133642)

    - Run database SQL below to verify patch information in database  
    select PATCH_ID,ACTION, STATUS from (select * from dba_registry_sqlpatch where PATCH_ID = <<OPactch Patchid>> order by action_time desc) where rownum=1 ; 

    PATCH_ID         ACTION         STATUS
    --------------------------------------------------------------------------
    34133642           APPLY         SUCCESS

    The output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: The bundle patch version installed matches the bundle patch version registered in the database 
    FAILURE:    The bundle patch version installed does not match the bundle patch version registered in the database

    If FAILURE is reported, then investigate and correct the discrepancy. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => The bundle patch version installed matches the bundle patch version registered in the database
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify bundle patch version installed matches bundle patch version registered in database 



Bundle patch installed in software home (OPatch): 31281355 19.8.0.0.200714
Bundle patch installed in database registry     : 31281355 19.8.0.0.200714
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => The bundle patch version installed matches the bundle patch version registered in the database
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify bundle patch version installed matches bundle patch version registered in database 



Bundle patch installed in software home (OPatch): 31281355 19.8.0.0.200714
Bundle patch installed in database registry     : 31281355 19.8.0.0.200714
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => The bundle patch version installed matches the bundle patch version registered in the database
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify bundle patch version installed matches bundle patch version registered in database 



Bundle patch installed in software home (OPatch): 31281355 19.8.0.0.200714
Bundle patch installed in database registry     : 31281355 19.8.0.0.200714
    


    Hide
    


    Verify data (non-system) disks on Exadata Storage Servers have no partitions
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Verifying that storage server data (non-system) disks have no partitions helps avoid an outage or data loss.

    The impact of verifying that storage server data (non-system) disks have no partitions is minimal. The impact of correcting storage server data (non-system) disks that have partitions varies according to the reason for the partitions and the state of the device, and cannot be estimated here. 

    Risk:

    During a storage server reboot, for storage server data (non-system) disks that have partitions, the partitions may become not visible to the operation system, and therefore unusable.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify that storage server data (non-system) disks have no partitions, as the "root" userid, execute the following command set on each storage server:

    unset report_command   
    OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME=/opt/oracle/cell/cellsrv/deploy/scripts      
    DISK_DEV="$OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME/unix/hwadapter/diskadp/get_disk_devices.pl"      
    SYS_DISKS=`cellcli -x -e "list lun attributes deviceName where isSystemLun = TRUE"`      
    SYS_DISK0=`echo $SYS_DISKS|cut -f1 -d' '`      
    SYS_DISK1=`echo $SYS_DISKS|cut -f2 -d' '`      
          
    if [ -z "$OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME" ]; then      
       report_command=$(echo "$report_command\nEnvironment variable OSS_SCRIPTS_HOME is not defined")      
       status=1      
    fi      
          
    if [ ! -f $DISK_DEV ]; then      
       report_command=$(echo "$report_command\nFile $DISK_DEV does not exists")      
       status=1      
    else      
        DATA_DISKS=`$DISK_DEV 2 |grep -v $SYS_DISK0 |grep -v $SYS_DISK1`      
          
        failDiskCount=0      
        for disk in $DATA_DISKS; do      
           size=${#disk}      
           if [ $size -eq 9 ]; then      
              disk="${disk%?}"      
           fi      
          
           parted -s $disk print 1>&2 >/dev/null      
          
           if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then      
              disks[$i]=$disk      
              failDiskCount=`expr $failDiskCount + 1`      
           fi      
        done      
          
        if [ $failDiskCount -eq 0 ]; then      
          report_command=$(echo "$report_command\nAll data disks have no partitions")      
          status=0      
        else      
          report_command=$(echo "$report_command\nThe following disks have partitions:")      
          report_command=$(echo "$report_command\n ${disks[@]}")      
          report_command=$(echo "$report_command\nAssociated griddisks needs to be removed from diskgroups")      
          report_command=$(echo "$report_command\nRebalance should complete before replacing/reformatting this device.")      
          status=1      
        fi      
    fi      
    echo -e "$report_command"

    The expected output should be:

    All data disks have no partitions

    If data disks with partitions are discovered, they will be echoed back. If the output is not as expected, investigate for root cause and take appropriate corrective action.

        NOTE: For additional information, please see: Exadata: Problems introduced when replacing a physical disk having a foreign partition table (Doc ID 1965314.1). 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1965314.1 - 	Problems introduced when replacing a physical disk having a foreign partition table
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => No data (non-system) disks contain partitions
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify data (non-system) disks on Exadata Storage Servers have no partitions 



All data disks have no partitions

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Verify data (non-system) disks on Exadata Storage Servers have no partitions 



All data disks have no partitions

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Verify data (non-system) disks on Exadata Storage Servers have no partitions 



All data disks have no partitions

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Verify data (non-system) disks on Exadata Storage Servers have no partitions 

    


All data disks have no partitions

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Verify SYS and SYSTEM accounts are using default profile
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The default installation of the Oracle Database requires SYS and SYSTEM accounts assigned with the DEFAULT profile.

    The DEFAULT profile contains unlimited server resources; SYS and SYSTEM accounts require unlimited server resources to perform database administration tasks such as gathering statistics, etc.

    Risk:

    Keeping the DEFAULT profile for the SYS and SYSTEM accounts unaltered helps to avoid operational issues such as errors while applying data patches, standby Data Guard replication errors, etc.

    Action / Repair:

    Make sure the DEFAULT profile is associated with the SYS and SYSTEM accounts.
    

    Links
    1.  SQL Language Reference - CREATE PROFILE 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYS and SYSTEM accounts are using default profile
    TO REVIEW COLLECTED DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify SYS and SYSTEM accounts are using default profile 

    USERNAME		  CURRENT PROFILE	    RECOMMENDED PROFILE
------------------------- ------------------------- -------------------------
SYS			  DEFAULT		    DEFAULT
SYSTEM			  DEFAULT		    DEFAULT

    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYS and SYSTEM accounts are using default profile
    TO REVIEW COLLECTED DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify SYS and SYSTEM accounts are using default profile 

    USERNAME		  CURRENT PROFILE	    RECOMMENDED PROFILE
------------------------- ------------------------- -------------------------
SYS			  DEFAULT		    DEFAULT
SYSTEM			  DEFAULT		    DEFAULT

    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => SYS and SYSTEM accounts are using default profile
    TO REVIEW COLLECTED DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Verify SYS and SYSTEM accounts are using default profile 

    USERNAME		  CURRENT PROFILE	    RECOMMENDED PROFILE
------------------------- ------------------------- -------------------------
SYS			  DEFAULT		    DEFAULT
SYSTEM			  DEFAULT		    DEFAULT

    


    Hide
    


    Verify execute privilege from the PUBLIC Role
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The default installation of the Oracle Database requires that certain privileges be granted to the PUBLIC role. Grants to the PUBLIC role are inherited by all database users.

    Risk:

    Exercise caution when revoking privileges from PUBLIC role. Oracle and third-party products explicitly require default grants to PUBLIC role for commonly used functions, objects, and in view definitions.

     For example, the EXECUTE statement on the SYSDATE function and the SELECT statement on the DUAL table are granted to the PUBLIC role.
    Also, if you revoke the EXECUTE statement on the DBMS_DATAPUMP package from the PUBLIC role, the Oracle Data Pump Export utility (expdp) ceases to work properly resulting in ORA-06550 and ORA-39126 errors. If you must revoke the EXECUTE privilege on package DBMS_DATAPUMP from the PUBLIC role, at least grant the EXECUTE privilege on the DBMS_DATAPUMP package to the DATAPUMP_EXP_FULL_DATABASE role instead.

    Action / Repair:

    Please check with the appropriate application security documentation (e.g., E-Business Suite, PeopleSoft, Siebel and/or owners of your application) to determine if revoking PUBLIC privileges from packages can be done without impacting application functionality.

    If there is a requirement to revoke the EXECUTE privilege from the PUBLIC role, follow these steps:
      1.    Check the object dependencies, for details refer to MOS Note 247093.1.
      2.    Grant the privilege to the required users:
            SQL> grant EXECUTE on <package> to <user1>,<user2>...<user n>;
      3.    Revoke the EXECUTE privilege from the PUBLIC role:
            SQL> revoke EXECUTE on <package> from PUBLIC;

    Also this misconfiguration can be repaired with repair functionality in AHF using "ahfctl compliance -repair -check 0E74E5CEDF3A3065E0639812F50A50AB".
To see the repair command, run "ahfctl compliance -showrepair 0E74E5CEDF3A3065E0639812F50A50AB".
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1165830.1 - Problems After Revoking Execute On DBMS_SQL, DBMS_JOB, DBMS_LOB, DBMS_RANDOM, and DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT From PUBLIC
    2.  Note: 1489111.1 - DataPump Export Or Import Fails With Error PLS-201 At SYS.DBMS_DATAPUMP (Doc ID 1489111.1)	To BottomTo Bottom	
    3.  Note: 1577002.1 - Invalid Components, Objects After Revoke Public Privileges (Doc ID 1577002.1)
    4.  Note: 247093.1 - Revoking Privileges From PUBLIC (Doc ID 247093.1)
    5.  Note: 797706.1 - Invalid Objects After Revoking EXECUTE Privilege From PUBLIC (Doc ID 797706.1)
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3

    Exadata Critical Issue EX84
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 36015805, on Exadata Database Service and on-premises Exadata systems, after storage servers are upgraded to Exadata version 22.1.15 through 22.1.17, or 23.1.0 through 23.1.8, the database may experience IO performance degradation when flash cache is under space pressure, which may cause significant database performance degradation.

    On some systems with primarily OLTP workloads, a change introduced in Exadata 22.1.15 and 23.1.0 may result in the flash cache being too slow to purge cold, unsynchronized data to hard disk, thus preventing new (hot) data from landing in the flash cache, causing OLTP performance degradation due to higher OLTP flash cache misses.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX84 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => System is not exposed to Exadata Critical Issue EX84
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX84 


Storage server Exadata version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm02 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX84 


Storage server Exadata version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm03 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX84 


Storage server Exadata version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

DATA FROM exa3celadm04 FOR Exadata Critical Issue EX84 


Storage server Exadata version: 20.1.1.0.0.200808

    


    Hide
    


    Exadata Critical Issue EX16
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Bug 19132065 - Oracle Linux semtimedop() wakeups by timeout are lagging causing offload operations to fail (which may degrade performance) and errors similar to one or more of the following: 
        ORA-700 [Offload issue job timed out] 
        ORA-700 [Offload group not open] 
        RS-700 [Celloflsrv hang detected. It will be terminated] 

    This issue is also present on Oracle Linux database servers, but the negative consequences are currently unknown. 

    Fix or Workaround: 
    Set operating system kernel parameter rcu_delay=1 on all storage servers and Oracle Linux database servers.  


    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue EX16 in MOS Note 12700094.1 for recent updates and additional details. 
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02

    Exadata Critical Issue DB52
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    A system exposed to a critical issue may experience system-wide impact to
    performance or availability.

    Risk:

    Due to bug 35784008, a database process stuck in an uninterruptible state (D state) when instance eviction and reconfiguration occurs can resume and issue database I/O after the instance is evicted, which can cause database corruption.  This issue only affects Exadata systems, including Exadata Database Service and Exadata running on-premises.

    Action / Repair:

    See Exadata Critical Issue DB52 in MOS note 1270094.1.
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 1270094.1 - Exadata Critical Issues
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:

    Hide
    


    Verify there are no griddisks configured on flash memory devices
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    The definition and maintenance of storage server griddisks is critical for optimal performance and outage avoidance.

    The impact of verifying the storage server griddisk configuration is minimal. Correcting any abnormalities is dependent upon the reason for the anomaly, so the impact cannot be estimated here.



    Risk:

    If the storage server griddisk configuration is not verified, poor performance or unexpected outages may occur.



    Action / Repair:

    To verify there are no storage server griddisks configured on flash memory devices, execute the following command as the "celladmin" user on each storage server:

    cellcli -e "list griddisk where disktype=flashdisk" | wc -l

    The output should be:0

    If the output is not as expected, investigate the condition and take corrective action based upon the root cause of the unexpected result.

    NOTE: 
    Experience has shown that the Oracle recommended Best Practice of using all available flash device space for Smart Flash Log and Smart Flash Cache provides the highest overall performance benefit with lowest maintenance overhead for an Oracle Exadata Database Machine. 

    In some very rare cases for certain highly write-intensive applications, there may be some performance benefit to configuring grid disks onto the flash devices for datafile writes only.  

    With the release of the Smart Flash Log feature in 11.2.2.4, redo logs should never be placed on flash grid disks. Smart Flash Log leverages both hard disks and flash devices with intelligent caching to achieve the fastest possible redo write performance, optimizations which are lost if redo logs are simply placed on flash grid disks. 

    The space available to Smart Flash Cache and Smart Flash Log is reduced by the amount of space allocated to the grid disks deployed on flash devices. The usable space in the flash grid disk group is either half or one-third of the space allocated for grid disks on flash devices, depending on whether the flash grid disks are configured with ASM normal or high redundancy.

    If after thorough performance and recovery testing, a customer chooses to deploy grid disks on flash devices, it would be a supported, but not Best Practice, configuration.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    PASS => There are no griddisks configured on flash memory devices
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Verify there are no griddisks configured on flash memory devices

    RAID controller version on storage servers
    


    

    Recommendation
    RAID controller version should match on all storage cells. use following command to find out the RAID controller version on storage cell.

    /opt/MegaRAID/MegaCli/MegaCli64 -AdpAllInfo -a0 -nolog  | grep 'FW Package Build' |awk -F: '{print $2}'
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02

    Click for more data
    


    Hide
    


    Ensure db_unique_name is unique across the enterprise [primary]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    db_unique_name is used extensively in many Clusterware, RDBMS, and Exadata code layers. db_unique_name is enforced to be unique within clusters but not across clusters. Ensuring db_unique_name is unique across clusters, especially those that are sharing the same Exadata storage, ensures that all code layers that use it work properly.

    Risk:

    Having databases with the same db_unique_name across different Real Application Clusters that share the same Exadata storage causes unexpected behavior such as database isolation, crashes, or failures to start.

    Action / Repair:

    To see whether db_unique_name is at the default value, as the owner of the oracle home for a given database and with the environment set to access that database, execute the following SQL command:
    By default db_unique_name would be same as db_name parameter.

      col DB_NAME format a30
      col DB_UNIQUE_NAME format a30 
      select sys_context ('USERENV','db_name') DB_NAME, sys_context ('USERENV','db_unique_name') DB_UNIQUE_NAME from dual ;

    Alternatively one can also use show parameter as below to verify:
      show parameter db_name
      show parameter db_unique_name

    NOTE:
    Oracle recommends that db_unique_name is unique across a customer's Oracle enterprise. This recommendation assumes that an output prefixed with "SUCCESS" means specific care has been taken to ensure a given db_unique_name is unique across the customer's Oracle enterprise. An output prefixed with "FAILURE" is assumed to imply that enterprise a given db_unique_name may not have been validated to be unique across the customer's Oracle enterprise.

    The corrective action is to ensure all databases have a unique name across the customer's Oracle enterprise, especially those accessing the same Exadata storage.

    If it is known that all database names are unique across the Oracle enterprise, it is not necessary to take an outage just to change the value of db_unique_name. The change to db_unique_name required in order to make this recommendation pass can be done at the next scheduled maintenance period.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onwhexa3p3
    

    


    Status on whexa3p3:
    PASS => DB_UNIQUE_NAME on primary has not been modified from the default, confirm that database name is unique across your Oracle enterprise
    'DATABASENAME:'||(SELECTVALUEFROMV$PARAMETERWHEREUPPER(NAME)IN('DB_NAME'))||CHR(10)||'DATABASEUNIQUENAME:'||(SELECTVALUEFROMV$PARAMETERWHEREUPPER(NAME)IN('DB_UNIQUE_NAME')) 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
Database Name       : whexa3p3
Database Unique Name: whexa3p3

    


    Hide
    


    Validate network configuration files in RDBMS homes
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    This check validates tnsnames.ora and sqlnet.ora for syntax issues in Oracle Database Home. Please review any identified issues and address them.

    Risk:

    Incorrect configuration could cause database connectivity issues.
    

    Needs attention on-

    Hide
    


    Check alerthistory for stateful alerts not cleared [Storage Server]
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    There are two types of alerts maintained in the alerthistory of a storage or database server, stateful and stateless.

    A stateful alert is usually associated with a transient condition, often hardware related, and it will clear itself after that transient condition is corrected. These alerts age out of the alerthistory after 7 days (default time) once they are set to clear.

    The benefit of checking for stateful alerts that have not been cleared is faster problem resolution. The impact of correcting any stateful alert that has not been cleared depends upon each individual alert. 


    Risk:

    Failure to investigate a stateful alert that has not been cleared may result in significant impact, which varies by the particular alert.

    Action / Repair:

    To verify there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared, as the root userid on each storage and database server execute the following commands:

    unset IMAGE_VERSION
    unset NODE_TYPE
    unset COMMAND_NAME
    unset NAME_ARRAY
    unset INDIVIDUAL_NAME
    unset SID
    unset SEVERITY
    unset MESSAGE
    unset ACTION
    unset OUTPUT_ARRAY
    if [ $(egrep -i node.type /opt/oracle.cellos/cell.conf | grep -i db | wc -l) -eq 1 ]
      then NODE_TYPE=db
    else
      NODE_TYPE=cell
    fi
    IMAGE_VERSION=$(imageinfo -version |tr -d '.'|cut -c1-6)
    if [ $NODE_TYPE = "cell" ]
    then
      COMMAND_NAME=cellcli
    else
      if [ $IMAGE_VERSION -ge 121211 ]
        then COMMAND_NAME=dbmcli
      fi;
    fi;
    if [ -n "$COMMAND_NAME" ]
    then
      NAME_ARRAY=$($COMMAND_NAME -e "list alerthistory attributes name where alerttype=stateful and endtime=null" | sed -e 's/^[ \t]*//');
      if [ -z "$NAME_ARRAY" ]
      then
        echo -e "SUCCESS: there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared."
      else
        for INDIVIDUAL_NAME in $NAME_ARRAY
        do
          NAME_RECORD=$($COMMAND_NAME -e "list alerthistory attributes alertsequenceid,severity,alertMessage,alertAction where name=$INDIVIDUAL_NAME" | tr -s "\t")
          SID=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f2 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          SEVERITY=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f3 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          MESSAGE=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f4 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          ACTION=$(echo "$NAME_RECORD" | cut -f5 | tr -s " " | sed -e 's/^[[:space:]]*//')
          OUTPUT_ARRAY+=$(echo -e "\n";echo -e "SID:\t\t$SID";echo -e "NAME:\t\t$INDIVIDUAL_NAME";echo -e "SEVERITY:\t$SEVERITY";echo -e "MESSAGE:\t$MESSAGE";echo -e "ACTION:\t\t$ACTION")
        done
        echo -e -n "FAILURE: there are one or more stateful alerts that have not been cleared. Details:"
        echo -e "${OUTPUT_ARRAY[@]}"
      fi
    else
      echo "alerthistory is not available on database servers at image versions below 12.1.2.1.1: $NODE_TYPE $IMAGE_VERSION"
    fi

    The output should be similar to:

    SUCCESS: there are no stateful alerts that have not been cleared.

    - OR -

    alerthistory is not available on database servers at image versions below 12.1.2.1.1: db 112322

    Example of a FAILURE result:

    FAILURE: there are one or more stateful alerts that have not been cleared. Details:

    SID:            1
    NAME:           1_2
    SEVERITY:       critical
    MESSAGE:        A IO subsystem component is suspected of causing a fault with a 100% certainty. Component Name : /SYS/MB/RISER3/PCIE3 Fault class : fault.io.intel.iio.pcie-downstream-devices Fault message : http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-QH
    ACTION:         For additional information, please refer to http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-QH This alert occurred while the Management Server was not available and is being sent out on restart of the Management Server. Note the event time may reflect the time when the alert was detected by the Management Server, not the time when the fault occurred. Diagnostic package is attached. It is also accessible at /opt/oracle/dbserver/dbms/deploy/log/scam07adm07_2014_08_11T17_40_33_1_2.tar.bz2

    SID:            2
    NAME:           2_1
    SEVERITY:       critical
    MESSAGE:        A processor component is suspected of causing a fault with a 100% certainty. Component Name : /SYS/MB/P0 Fault class : fault.cpu.intel.thermtrip Fault message : http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-K5
    ACTION:         For additional information, please refer to http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8003-K5 This alert occurred while the Management Server was not available and is being sent out on restart of the Management Server. Note the event time may reflect the time when the alert was detected by the Management Server, not the time when the fault occurred.

    If the output is not as expected, examine the full details for each alert that has not been cleared and follow the recommendations. 
    

    Needs attention onexa3celadm01, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04, exa3celadm02
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3celadm01, exa3celadm02, exa3celadm03, exa3celadm04:
    CRITICAL => One or more storage servers have stateful alerts that have not been cleared.
    DATA FROM exa3celadm01 FOR Check alerthistory for stateful alerts not cleared [Storage Server]

It will be retained on the storage server for 28 days, after which it may be automatically purged by MS during accelerated space reclamation.

    Diagnostic packages for critical alerts can be downloaded and/or re-created at https://exa3celadm01.prod.d002.loc/diagpack"


SID:		3
NAME:		3_1
SEVERITY:	critical
MESSAGE:	"A SQL PLAN quarantine has been added. As a result, Smart Scan is disabled for SQL statements with the quarantined SQL plan. 
 Quarantine id     : 66 
 Quarantine type   : SQL PLAN 
 Quarantine reason : Crash 
 Quarantine Plan   : SYSTEM 
 Quarantine Mode   : FULL_Quarantine 
  DB Unique Name : WHEXA3P3 
 Incident id       : 1 
 SQLID             : 9pyr2t6xvwmdp 
 SQL Plan details  : {SQL_PLAN_HASH_VALUE=42854979, PLAN_LINE_ID=7} 
 In addition, the following disk region has been quarantined, and Smart Scan will be disabled for this region: 
 Disk Region : {Grid Disk Name=DATA_EXA3_CD_07_exa3celadm01, offset=3292269641728, size=1M} 
"
ACTION:		"A SQL statement caused the Cell Server (CELLSRV) service on the cell to crash. A SQL PLAN quarantine has been created to prevent the same SQL statement from causing the same cell to crash. When possible, disable offload for the SQL statement or apply the RDBMS patch that fixes the crash, then remove the quarantine with the following CellCLI command: 
 CellCLI> drop quarantine 66 
All quarantines are automatically removed when a cell is patched or upgraded. For information about how to disable offload for the SQL statement, refer to the section about 'SQL Processing Offload' in Oracle Exadata Storage Server User's Guide.
 Diagnostic package is attached. It is also accessible at https://exa3celadm01.prod.d002.loc/diagpack/download?name=exa3celadm01_2022_01_14T19_51_14_3_1.tar.bz2
It will be retained on the storage server for 28 days, after which it may be automatically purged by MS during accelerated space reclamation.
Diagnostic packages for critical alerts can be downloaded and/or re-created at https://exa3celadm01.prod.d002.loc/diagpack"

"
ACTION:		"A SQL statement caused the Cell Server (CELLSRV) service on the cell to crash. A SQL PLAN quarantine has been created to prevent the same SQL statement from causing the same cell to crash. When possible, disable offload for the SQL statement or apply the RDBMS patch that fixes the crash, then remove the quarantine with the following CellCLI command: 
 CellCLI> drop quarantine 70 
All quarantines are automatically removed when a cell is patched or upgraded. For information about how to disable offload for the SQL statement, refer to the section about 'SQL Processing Offload' in Oracle Exadata Storage Server User's Guide.
 Diagnostic package is attached. It is also accessible at https://exa3celadm04.prod.d002.loc/diagpack/download?name=exa3celadm04_2024_06_14T14_12_16_29_1.tar.bz2
It will be retained on the storage server for 28 days, after which it may be automatically purged by MS during accelerated space reclamation.
Diagnostic packages for critical alerts can be downloaded and/or re-created at https://exa3celadm04.prod.d002.loc/diagpack"


SID:		44
NAME:		44_1
SEVERITY:	critical
MESSAGE:	"Flash disk entered poor performance status. The LUN 5_0 changed status to warning - poor performance. CellDisk changed status to proactive failure.
Status                      : WARNING - POOR PERFORMANCE 
Manufacturer                : Oracle 
Model Number                : Flash Accelerator F640 PCIe Card v2 
Size                        : 2981GB 
Serial Number               : PHLN008200XU6P4EGN-2 
Firmware                    : VDV1RZ06 
Slot Number                 : PCI Slot: 5; FDOM: 2 
Cell Disk                   : FD_02_exa3celadm04 
Grid Disk                   : Not configured 
Flash Cache                 : Present 
Flash Log                   : Present 
Reason for poor performance : No I/Os completed even after a timeout period has expired"
ACTION:		"The flash disk has entered poor performance status. A white cell locator LED has been lit to help locate the affected cell.
If the flash disk is used for flash cache, then flash cache will be disabled on this disk thus reducing the effective flash cache size. If flash cache is in write back mode, dirty data on this flash disk will be automatically flushed to the corresponding grid disks. If the flash disk is used for flash log, then flash log will be disabled on this disk thus reducing the effective flash log size. If the flash disk is used for grid disks, then the data from the flash disk will be automatically rebalanced by Oracle ASM to other flash disks. Another alert will be sent when all data has been rebalanced and flushed from this flash disk. Please wait until rebalance and flush have completed before replacing the flash disk.
Detailed information on this problem can be found at https://support.oracle.com/CSP/main/article?cmd=show&type=NOT&id=2285528.1 

 Diagnostic package is attached. It is also accessible at https://exa3celadm04.prod.d002.loc/diagpack/download?name=exa3celadm04_2025_07_08T03_19_37_44_1.tar.bz2
It will be retained on the storage server for 28 days, after which it may be automatically purged by MS during accelerated space reclamation.
Diagnostic packages for critical alerts can be downloaded and/or re-created at https://exa3celadm04.prod.d002.loc/diagpack"

    Verify DSA authentication is not supported for SSH equivalency
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    DSA (Digital Signature Algorithm) is considered insecure and should not be used as an authentication mechanism, hence DSA keys must not exist for any operating system user. Additionally, the operating system crypto policy must not contain options and/or configuration allowing DSA key-based authentication for inbound or outbound connectivity. 

    Risk:

    Beginning with Exadata 23.1 (Oracle Linux 8), by default, all inbound and outbound connections attempting DSA authentication are blocked at the operating system level. Under these circumstances, utilities and services requiring key-based authentication will be negatively impacted if they solely rely on DSA support. Using DSA authentication may cause automation tasks failures, increase the attack surface of a system and/or facilitate unauthorized access.

    Action / Repair:

    In Exadata database nodes and storage servers, system users must not own a DSA key-pair, nor allow inbound SSH connectivity authenticated via DSA keys. Additionally, the system crypto policy must not contain any DSA cipher that may be used by system processes or services.

        If any system user owns a DSA key-pair, perform the following steps:
            Remove the public component of the key

            rm -f </path/key.pub>

            Remove the private component of the key

            rm -f </path/key.pub>


            Create a new RSA key-pair
            NOTE: Detailed steps on how to identify DSA keys and generate RSA keys (recommended for key-based authentication) may be found in "How to setup RSA SSH equivalence on Oracle Exadata nodes (Doc ID 2923095.1)".

        If DSA authentication is allowed for inbound SSH connectivity, perform the following steps on every authorization file flagged:
            Open the authorization file
            Remove all entries beginning with "ssh-dss"
            Save the changes and close the authorization file.
        If DSA support is enabled in the system crypto policy, perform one of the following strategies:
            Use the Oracle Linux 8 default crypto policy
                Execute the following command

                update-crypto-policies --set DEFAULT

                Restart the system to apply changes

                reboot

            Enable FIPS mode
                Execute the following command

                /opt/oracle.cellos/host_access_control fips-mode --enable

                Restart the system to apply changes

                reboot


    Note: Once the issue has been resolved, if you wish to validate this Exachk check individually, you may run the following command as "root" user:

        exachk -showpass -check 037DBC37B8C06095E0639712F50A4FF6
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    FAIL => DSA authentication is found for inbound and/or outbound SSH connectivity
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY DSA AUTHENTICATION IS NOT SUPPORTED FOR SSH EQUIVALENCY

Details:

- 	 /home/oracle/.ssh/id_dsa.pub

 	 - /home/dbmadmin/.ssh/id_dsa
 	 - /home/dbmadmin/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
 	 - 	 /home/oracle/.ssh/id_dsa
 - 	 /root/.ssh/id_dsa

Authorization files containing remote DSA keys:
	 - .ssh/authorized_keys contains 2 remote DSA keys

 	 - /home/dbmadmin/.ssh/id_dsa
 	 - /home/dbmadmin/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
 	 - /root/.ssh/id_dsa
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    FAIL => DSA authentication is found for inbound and/or outbound SSH connectivity
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY DSA AUTHENTICATION IS NOT SUPPORTED FOR SSH EQUIVALENCY

Details:

DSA keys found in the system:
	 - /home/dbmadmin/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
 	 - /home/oracle/.ssh/id_dsa
 	 - /home/oracle/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
 	 - /home/dbmadmin/.ssh/id_dsa

    Dedicated Tablespace for Unified Audit Trail
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Moving the database audit trail objects out of the SYSAUX tablespace improves overall database performance by reducing the load on the SYSAUX tablespace.

    Risk:

    SYSAUX tablespace usage for auditing can lead to potential database performance problems.


    Action / Repair:

    If the default tablespace for audit object is under SYSAUX tablespace, then it is recommended to create a new custom tablespace and move the existing audit objects/data to the new tablespace to avoid any Performance overhead. Always Maintain sufficient space to avoid database unplanned outages and configure tablespace monitoring also partition the auditing table. This is to avoid performance during data purging. Schedule audit data purging jobs as per your organization policies
    It is applicable only for customers who are using unified audit by default. Database has both unified and traditional audit. This is not for audit if audit trail is set to OS

    This can be done following the below commands as an example:

    Create a new tablespace AUDIT_TBS and make sure that its size is large enough for the tables that will be moved.

    Move the audit trail tables using procedure DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_LOCATION.

    Always Maintain sufficient space to avoid database unplanned outages and configure tablespace monitoring also partition the auditing table. This is to avoid performance during data purging. Schedule audit data purging jobs as per your organization policies
    For Unified Audit Trail:

    create tablespace AUDIT_TBS datafile '<PATH>/auditts.dbf' size 100M autoextend on;

    BEGIN
    DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.set_audit_trail_location(
    audit_trail_type => DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.AUDIT_TRAIL_UNIFIED,--this moves table Unified Audit
    audit_trail_location_value => 'AUDIT_TBS');
    END;
    /
    

    Links
    1.  How To Move The DB Audit Trails To A New Tablespace Using DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT? (Doc ID 1328239.1) 
    2.  PL/SQL Packages and Types Reference - DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Tablespace used by audit objects is as recommended
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Dedicated Tablespace for Unified Audit Trail 




PARAMETER_NAME		  PARAMETER_VALUE	    AUDIT_TRAIL
------------------------- ------------------------- ----------------------------
DB AUDIT TABLESPACE	  TS_DB_AUDIT		    UNIFIED AUDIT TRAIL
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Tablespace used by audit objects is as recommended
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Dedicated Tablespace for Unified Audit Trail 




PARAMETER_NAME		  PARAMETER_VALUE	    AUDIT_TRAIL
------------------------- ------------------------- ----------------------------
DB AUDIT TABLESPACE	  TS_DB_AUDIT		    UNIFIED AUDIT TRAIL
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Tablespace used by audit objects is as recommended
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Dedicated Tablespace for Unified Audit Trail 




PARAMETER_NAME		  PARAMETER_VALUE	    AUDIT_TRAIL
------------------------- ------------------------- ----------------------------
DB AUDIT TABLESPACE	  TS_DB_AUDIT		    UNIFIED AUDIT TRAIL

    Verify Oracle High Availability Services Automatic Startup Configuration
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    This check checks if Oracle High Availability Services autostart is enabled.


    Risk:

    For Oracle Exadata Database Service, quarterly infrastructure maintenance will fail if Oracle High Availability Services autostart is disabled.

    For on-premise Exadata systems, the cluster will not start automatically in case of a restart of a database server if Oracle High Availability Services autostart is disabled.

    Action / Repair:

    Run the command "crsctl enable crs" to enable Oracle High Availability Services autostart.
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm01, exa3dbadm02, exa3dbadm03
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:
    PASS => Oracle High Availability Services autostart is enabled
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM01 FOR VERIFY ORACLE HIGH AVAILABILITY SERVICES AUTOMATIC STARTUP CONFIGURATION



SUCCESS: Oracle High Availability Services autostart is enabled.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:
    PASS => Oracle High Availability Services autostart is enabled
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM03 FOR VERIFY ORACLE HIGH AVAILABILITY SERVICES AUTOMATIC STARTUP CONFIGURATION



SUCCESS: Oracle High Availability Services autostart is enabled.
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:
    PASS => Oracle High Availability Services autostart is enabled
    DATA FROM EXA3DBADM02 FOR VERIFY ORACLE HIGH AVAILABILITY SERVICES AUTOMATIC STARTUP CONFIGURATION



SUCCESS: Oracle High Availability Services autostart is enabled.
    


    Hide
    


    Recovery and Create File Destinations
    


    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Experience and testing has shown that certain database initialization parameters should be set at specific values. These are the best practice values set at deployment time. By setting these database initialization parameters as recommended, known problems may be avoided and performance maximized. The parameters are common to all database instances. The impact of setting these parameters is minimal. The performance related settings provide guidance to maintain highest stability without sacrificing performance. Changing the default performance settings can be done after careful performance evaluation and clear understanding of the performance impact.


    Risk:

    If the database initialization parameters are not set as recommended, a variety of issues may be encountered, depending upon which initialization parameter is not set as recommended, and the actual set value.



    Action / Repair:

    "DATA" diskgroup is recommended for db_create_file_dest, but may be set to any valid diskgroup that is not the diskgroup specified by db_recovery_file_dest.

    "RECO" diskgroup is recommended for db_recovery_file_dest, but may be set to any valid diskgroup that is not the diskgroup specified by db_create_file_dest. 
    

    Needs attention on-
    

    Passed onexa3dbadm02:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3, exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database DB_CREATE_FILE_DEST and DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST are in different diskgroups
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm01 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Recovery and Create File Destinations 



db_recovery_file_dest = +RECO_EXA3
db_create_file_dest = +DATA_EXA3
    

    Status on exa3dbadm03:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database DB_CREATE_FILE_DEST and DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST are in different diskgroups
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm03 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Recovery and Create File Destinations 



db_recovery_file_dest = +RECO_EXA3
db_create_file_dest = +DATA_EXA3
    

    Status on exa3dbadm02:whexa3p3:
    PASS => Database DB_CREATE_FILE_DEST and DB_RECOVERY_FILE_DEST are in different diskgroups
    DATA FROM exa3dbadm02 - whexa3p3 DATABASE - Recovery and Create File Destinations 



db_recovery_file_dest = +RECO_EXA3
db_create_file_dest = +DATA_EXA3

    Verify health of data dictionary for non-multitenant database
    


    

    Success FactorDATABASE CONSOLIDATION BEST PRACTICES
    

    Recommendation
    Benefit / Impact:

    Helps you identify database dictionary inconsistencies that are manifested in unexpected entries in the RDBMS dictionary tables or invalid references between dictionary tables. 

    Risk:

    Database dictionary inconsistencies can lead to failures and impact life cycle management of the database.
    Inconsistencies reported with FAIL or CRITICAL may be exposed with internal ORA-600 errors.

    Action / Repair:

    Review the results provided in the report output for guidance on the issue observed and actions recommended. 
    In most cases guided remediation is provided to resolve the problem.
    Data dictionary health can be verified using script provided in MOS Note : 136697.1. 

    To rerun this check along use the following:
    ahfctl compliance -check 00B2421DC162C0B0E0639912F50A4749
    

    Links
    1.  Note: 136697.1 - hcheck.sql - Script to Check Data Dictionary for Known Problems
    

    Needs attention onexa3dbadm01:whexa3p3
    

    Passed on-
    

    


    Status on exa3dbadm01:whexa3p3:
    WARN => Database dictionary consistency check for non-multitenant database reported one or more failure
